Eastern Africa (06): Uganda ex South Sudan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6829994", "date": "2019-11-13 11:32:10", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA: KENYA (LAIKIPIA) ALERT, COMMENT\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jpdudley@alaska.edu> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya (LK) alert, 20191112.6775112]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nFAO's Early Warning Bulletin, \"Forecasting threats to the food chain affecting food security in countries and regions\" no. 33, October-December 2019, includes the following forecast for Central and Eastern Africa, in relation to Rift Valley fever (http://www.fao.org/3/ca6744en/ca6744en.pdf, pages 7-8):\n\n\"During the past 3 months, above-average and heavy rainfall and flash floods occurred in the region particularly during the end of August and early September as well as in early October 2019. The precipitation forecasts predict above-average rains for the coming period (October-December 2019) for Chad, Central African Republic, southern the Sudan and the whole eastern Africa region. According to the FAO RVF Monitoring/Early Warning tool, there are large areas at risk of RVF vector amplification in central-southern Chad, western-central Kenya, central-southern Sudan, eastern-southern Sudan, northern Uganda, and northern Tanzania. In August 2019, the 1st confirmed case ever of RVF in humans was reported in Bangui, Central African Republic. In early October 2019, media reported suspected cases of RVF in humans and animals in Red Sea state (north-eastern Sudan) and cases of hemorrhagic fever in humans in Kassala (eastern Sudan) and North Darfur states (western Sudan). Considering the past and recent RVF outbreaks occurrence in the region, Chad, Kenya, Sudan, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic could be considered at high risk of RVF occurrence. The other countries of the region could be considered at moderate risk of RVF due to the predicted suitability for RVF vector amplification as well as the movement of potentially infected animals.\"\n\nRapporteur [JD] comment:\nThe reports of severe and widespread flooding events in recent weeks are highly reminiscent of those that preceded the widespread outbreak of RVF in eastern Africa during May-August 2018 (see FEWS article, dated 8 Nov 2019, at https://fews.net/east-africa/seasonal-monitor/november-8-2019). Precipitation anomaly mapping from satellite imagery supports media reporting of exceptionally high levels of rainfall during early November and the preceding 90-day period of August-October in the same areas of eastern Africa most affected by a major outbreak of RVF in 2018.\n\nA comparison of 90 day rainfall anomalies from March-May 2018 and August-November 2019 indicates high risk for an even more extensive regional RVF outbreak in East Africa during the next few months, with very large high risk precipitation index areas covering most of Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan, Somalia, Uganda, and parts of Tanzania.\n\nDrought periods in southern Africa are often associated with unusually high levels of rainfall in East Africa -- and vice versa.\n\nBackground references\n---------------------\n1. Mariner J. Rift Valley Fever Surveillance. FAO Animal Production and Health Manual no. 21. 2018. Rome. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). 80 pages.\nhttp://www.fao.org/3/I8475EN/i8475en.pdf\n2. FAO/EMPRES. Early warning for RVF prevention: Satellite imagery; http://www.fao.org/3/Y4611E/y4611e07.htm#bm7.2\n3. 90-day total rainfall anomaly (mm) period: 14 Aug 2019-11 Nov 2019; https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/international/africa_arc/africa_arc_90day_ea_anom.gif.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n[Subscribers are encouraged to access the FEWS article dated 8 Nov 2019, referenced above, with special reference to the 4 pictures included (rainfall maps). From the said East Africa Seasonal Monitor, we hereby copy the segment addressing Kenya:\n\n\"In Kenya, flash floods were reported to have adversely affected about 25 counties, especially Marsabit, Wajir, Garissa, Turkana, and Kitui. The recent floods caused human and livestock fatalities and damage to infrastructure. Over 48 people lost their lives and 144 000 are estimated to have been displaced. However, the on-going short-rains performance has been largely beneficial for rangeland and cropping conditions across the most vulnerable pastoral and marginal agropastoral communities. There is an increased likelihood for the above-average crop yield prospects if the rainfall forecast for enhanced rains continue into December. On the other hand, there are concerns for pre-and post-harvest losses in the Western and North-Rift counties of Kenya due to on-going rains in the harvesting and drying period. There is also an elevated risk of further flooding at the peak of the rainfall season in November, which is associated with an increased incidence of malaria, water-borne diseases, and RVF.\"\n\nThe mechanisms that maintain the RVF arbovirus in nature and cause it to emerge in epidemic form are incompletely understood and might differ between areas. Transmission cycles are best understood in savanna regions, where the virus is thought to survive between outbreaks in the dried eggs of _Aedes_ mosquitoes found in shallow depressions in the soil (dambos). Infected mosquitoes are thought to hatch when the dambos fill after heavy rainfall and initiate transmission cycles involving additional mosquito species, and animals that act as amplifying hosts. The vertebrate amplifying hosts are thought to be critical in propagating epidemics. In Kenya's Savanna grasslands, the rainfall of between 500-1250 mm (20-50 inches) is concentrated into March-May (long rains) and September-October (short rains) and there is a long dry season in between; there are multi-annual fluctuations as well. Additional and updated details in ref 1 below.\n\nRVFV introductions into Egypt in 1977 and the Arabian Peninsula in 2000 followed epizootics in Sudan in 1976 and the Horn of Africa in 1998, respectively; the mode(s) of inter-boundary transmission yet to be fully clarified; in Egypt, the main suggested vector was _Culex pipiens_. The potential for the globalization of arboviruses has been demonstrated by various disease agents (such as West Nile, chikungunya, Zika viruses).\n\nMany thanks to Joe for his valuable comment.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Linthicum KJ, Britch SC, Anyamba A. Rift Valley fever: An emerging mosquito-borne disease. Annu Rev Entomol. 2016. 61: 395-415; https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-ento-010715-023819\n- Mod.AS\n\nThis would be a good time to consider livestock vaccination in areas designated as at high risk of RVF. Once an outbreak occurs, it is too late. Intensified surveillance for early detection of RVF cases in livestock and humans in high-risk areas is also advisable, as well as monitoring of populations of mosquito vectors for abundance and virus presence. However, these measures may be difficult logistically in flooded areas. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/7CB45377C5B8B126852573E800658AD9-depha_REF_ken080131_a.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21118]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n.................................................arn/ty/mj/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "malaria", "rift valley fever", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2019-08-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Horn of Africa", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "North - Rift", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kassala", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "MU", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "NN", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6787770", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (07): (RS,RN) human, livestock, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6787770", "date": "2019-11-13 11:32:10", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA: KENYA (LAIKIPIA) ALERT, COMMENT\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Nov 2019\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jpdudley@alaska.edu> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya (LK) alert, 20191112.6775112]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nFAO's Early Warning Bulletin, \"Forecasting threats to the food chain affecting food security in countries and regions\" no. 33, October-December 2019, includes the following forecast for Central and Eastern Africa, in relation to Rift Valley fever (http://www.fao.org/3/ca6744en/ca6744en.pdf, pages 7-8):\n\n\"During the past 3 months, above-average and heavy rainfall and flash floods occurred in the region particularly during the end of August and early September as well as in early October 2019. The precipitation forecasts predict above-average rains for the coming period (October-December 2019) for Chad, Central African Republic, southern the Sudan and the whole eastern Africa region. According to the FAO RVF Monitoring/Early Warning tool, there are large areas at risk of RVF vector amplification in central-southern Chad, western-central Kenya, central-southern Sudan, eastern-southern Sudan, northern Uganda, and northern Tanzania. In August 2019, the 1st confirmed case ever of RVF in humans was reported in Bangui, Central African Republic. In early October 2019, media reported suspected cases of RVF in humans and animals in Red Sea state (north-eastern Sudan) and cases of hemorrhagic fever in humans in Kassala (eastern Sudan) and North Darfur states (western Sudan). Considering the past and recent RVF outbreaks occurrence in the region, Chad, Kenya, Sudan, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic could be considered at high risk of RVF occurrence. The other countries of the region could be considered at moderate risk of RVF due to the predicted suitability for RVF vector amplification as well as the movement of potentially infected animals.\"\n\nRapporteur [JD] comment:\nThe reports of severe and widespread flooding events in recent weeks are highly reminiscent of those that preceded the widespread outbreak of RVF in eastern Africa during May-August 2018 (see FEWS article, dated 8 Nov 2019, at https://fews.net/east-africa/seasonal-monitor/november-8-2019). Precipitation anomaly mapping from satellite imagery supports media reporting of exceptionally high levels of rainfall during early November and the preceding 90-day period of August-October in the same areas of eastern Africa most affected by a major outbreak of RVF in 2018.\n\nA comparison of 90 day rainfall anomalies from March-May 2018 and August-November 2019 indicates high risk for an even more extensive regional RVF outbreak in East Africa during the next few months, with very large high risk precipitation index areas covering most of Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan, Somalia, Uganda, and parts of Tanzania.\n\nDrought periods in southern Africa are often associated with unusually high levels of rainfall in East Africa -- and vice versa.\n\nBackground references\n---------------------\n1. Mariner J. Rift Valley Fever Surveillance. FAO Animal Production and Health Manual no. 21. 2018. Rome. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). 80 pages.\nhttp://www.fao.org/3/I8475EN/i8475en.pdf\n2. FAO/EMPRES. Early warning for RVF prevention: Satellite imagery; http://www.fao.org/3/Y4611E/y4611e07.htm#bm7.2\n3. 90-day total rainfall anomaly (mm) period: 14 Aug 2019-11 Nov 2019; https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/international/africa_arc/africa_arc_90day_ea_anom.gif.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n[Subscribers are encouraged to access the FEWS article dated 8 Nov 2019, referenced above, with special reference to the 4 pictures included (rainfall maps). From the said East Africa Seasonal Monitor, we hereby copy the segment addressing Kenya:\n\n\"In Kenya, flash floods were reported to have adversely affected about 25 counties, especially Marsabit, Wajir, Garissa, Turkana, and Kitui. The recent floods caused human and livestock fatalities and damage to infrastructure. Over 48 people lost their lives and 144 000 are estimated to have been displaced. However, the on-going short-rains performance has been largely beneficial for rangeland and cropping conditions across the most vulnerable pastoral and marginal agropastoral communities. There is an increased likelihood for the above-average crop yield prospects if the rainfall forecast for enhanced rains continue into December. On the other hand, there are concerns for pre-and post-harvest losses in the Western and North-Rift counties of Kenya due to on-going rains in the harvesting and drying period. There is also an elevated risk of further flooding at the peak of the rainfall season in November, which is associated with an increased incidence of malaria, water-borne diseases, and RVF.\"\n\nThe mechanisms that maintain the RVF arbovirus in nature and cause it to emerge in epidemic form are incompletely understood and might differ between areas. Transmission cycles are best understood in savanna regions, where the virus is thought to survive between outbreaks in the dried eggs of _Aedes_ mosquitoes found in shallow depressions in the soil (dambos). Infected mosquitoes are thought to hatch when the dambos fill after heavy rainfall and initiate transmission cycles involving additional mosquito species, and animals that act as amplifying hosts. The vertebrate amplifying hosts are thought to be critical in propagating epidemics. In Kenya's Savanna grasslands, the rainfall of between 500-1250 mm (20-50 inches) is concentrated into March-May (long rains) and September-October (short rains) and there is a long dry season in between; there are multi-annual fluctuations as well. Additional and updated details in ref 1 below.\n\nRVFV introductions into Egypt in 1977 and the Arabian Peninsula in 2000 followed epizootics in Sudan in 1976 and the Horn of Africa in 1998, respectively; the mode(s) of inter-boundary transmission yet to be fully clarified; in Egypt, the main suggested vector was _Culex pipiens_. The potential for the globalization of arboviruses has been demonstrated by various disease agents (such as West Nile, chikungunya, Zika viruses).\n\nMany thanks to Joe for his valuable comment.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Linthicum KJ, Britch SC, Anyamba A. Rift Valley fever: An emerging mosquito-borne disease. Annu Rev Entomol. 2016. 61: 395-415; https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-ento-010715-023819\n- Mod.AS\n\nThis would be a good time to consider livestock vaccination in areas designated as at high risk of RVF. Once an outbreak occurs, it is too late. Intensified surveillance for early detection of RVF cases in livestock and humans in high-risk areas is also advisable, as well as monitoring of populations of mosquito vectors for abundance and virus presence. However, these measures may be difficult logistically in flooded areas. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/7CB45377C5B8B126852573E800658AD9-depha_REF_ken080131_a.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21118]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya (LK) alert, 20191112.6775112]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nFAO's Early Warning Bulletin, \"Forecasting threats to the food chain affecting food security in countries and regions\" no. 33, October-December 2019, includes the following forecast for Central and Eastern Africa, in relation to Rift Valley fever (http://www.fao.org/3/ca6744en/ca6744en.pdf, pages 7-8):\n\n\"During the past 3 months, above-average and heavy rainfall and flash floods occurred in the region particularly during the end of August and early September as well as in early October 2019. The precipitation forecasts predict above-average rains for the coming period (October-December 2019) for Chad, Central African Republic, southern the Sudan and the whole eastern Africa region. According to the FAO RVF Monitoring/Early Warning tool, there are large areas at risk of RVF vector amplification in central-southern Chad, western-central Kenya, central-southern Sudan, eastern-southern Sudan, northern Uganda, and northern Tanzania. In August 2019, the 1st confirmed case ever of RVF in humans was reported in Bangui, Central African Republic. In early October 2019, media reported suspected cases of RVF in humans and animals in Red Sea state (north-eastern Sudan) and cases of hemorrhagic fever in humans in Kassala (eastern Sudan) and North Darfur states (western Sudan). Considering the past and recent RVF outbreaks occurrence in the region, Chad, Kenya, Sudan, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic could be considered at high risk of RVF occurrence. The other countries of the region could be considered at moderate risk of RVF due to the predicted suitability for RVF vector amplification as well as the movement of potentially infected animals.\"\n\nRapporteur [JD] comment:\nThe reports of severe and widespread flooding events in recent weeks are highly reminiscent of those that preceded the widespread outbreak of RVF in eastern Africa during May-August 2018 (see FEWS article, dated 8 Nov 2019, at https://fews.net/east-africa/seasonal-monitor/november-8-2019). Precipitation anomaly mapping from satellite imagery supports media reporting of exceptionally high levels of rainfall during early November and the preceding 90-day period of August-October in the same areas of eastern Africa most affected by a major outbreak of RVF in 2018.\n\nA comparison of 90 day rainfall anomalies from March-May 2018 and August-November 2019 indicates high risk for an even more extensive regional RVF outbreak in East Africa during the next few months, with very large high risk precipitation index areas covering most of Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan, Somalia, Uganda, and parts of Tanzania.\n\nDrought periods in southern Africa are often associated with unusually high levels of rainfall in East Africa -- and vice versa.\n\nBackground references\n---------------------\n1. Mariner J. Rift Valley Fever Surveillance. FAO Animal Production and Health Manual no. 21. 2018. Rome. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). 80 pages.\nhttp://www.fao.org/3/I8475EN/i8475en.pdf\n2. FAO/EMPRES. Early warning for RVF prevention: Satellite imagery; http://www.fao.org/3/Y4611E/y4611e07.htm#bm7.2\n3. 90-day total rainfall anomaly (mm) period: 14 Aug 2019-11 Nov 2019; https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/international/africa_arc/africa_arc_90day_ea_anom.gif.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n[Subscribers are encouraged to access the FEWS article dated 8 Nov 2019, referenced above, with special reference to the 4 pictures included (rainfall maps). From the said East Africa Seasonal Monitor, we hereby copy the segment addressing Kenya:\n\n\"In Kenya, flash floods were reported to have adversely affected about 25 counties, especially Marsabit, Wajir, Garissa, Turkana, and Kitui. The recent floods caused human and livestock fatalities and damage to infrastructure. Over 48 people lost their lives and 144 000 are estimated to have been displaced. However, the on-going short-rains performance has been largely beneficial for rangeland and cropping conditions across the most vulnerable pastoral and marginal agropastoral communities. There is an increased likelihood for the above-average crop yield prospects if the rainfall forecast for enhanced rains continue into December. On the other hand, there are concerns for pre-and post-harvest losses in the Western and North-Rift counties of Kenya due to on-going rains in the harvesting and drying period. There is also an elevated risk of further flooding at the peak of the rainfall season in November, which is associated with an increased incidence of malaria, water-borne diseases, and RVF.\"\n\nThe mechanisms that maintain the RVF arbovirus in nature and cause it to emerge in epidemic form are incompletely understood and might differ between areas. Transmission cycles are best understood in savanna regions, where the virus is thought to survive between outbreaks in the dried eggs of _Aedes_ mosquitoes found in shallow depressions in the soil (dambos). Infected mosquitoes are thought to hatch when the dambos fill after heavy rainfall and initiate transmission cycles involving additional mosquito species, and animals that act as amplifying hosts. The vertebrate amplifying hosts are thought to be critical in propagating epidemics. In Kenya's Savanna grasslands, the rainfall of between 500-1250 mm (20-50 inches) is concentrated into March-May (long rains) and September-October (short rains) and there is a long dry season in between; there are multi-annual fluctuations as well. Additional and updated details in ref 1 below.\n\nRVFV introductions into Egypt in 1977 and the Arabian Peninsula in 2000 followed epizootics in Sudan in 1976 and the Horn of Africa in 1998, respectively; the mode(s) of inter-boundary transmission yet to be fully clarified; in Egypt, the main suggested vector was _Culex pipiens_. The potential for the globalization of arboviruses has been demonstrated by various disease agents (such as West Nile, chikungunya, Zika viruses).\n\nMany thanks to Joe for his valuable comment.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Linthicum KJ, Britch SC, Anyamba A. Rift Valley fever: An emerging mosquito-borne disease. Annu Rev Entomol. 2016. 61: 395-415; https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-ento-010715-023819\n- Mod.AS\n\nThis would be a good time to consider livestock vaccination in areas designated as at high risk of RVF. Once an outbreak occurs, it is too late. Intensified surveillance for early detection of RVF cases in livestock and humans in high-risk areas is also advisable, as well as monitoring of populations of mosquito vectors for abundance and virus presence. However, these measures may be difficult logistically in flooded areas. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/7CB45377C5B8B126852573E800658AD9-depha_REF_ken080131_a.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21118]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya (LK) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6775112", "date": "2019-10-14 12:30:41", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: (RIVER NILE, RED SEA) HUMAN, ANIMAL, ALERT, OIE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Star [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. Virol J 2010; 7: 97; https://virologyj.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1743-422X-7-97.\n- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Sudan: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed disease - Sudan: (RS) human, cattle, RFI 20191006.6712623\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya (MU,NN) cattle, sheep, OIE 20190301.6341784\n2018\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO 20180410.5735975\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO 20180313.5683274\nRift 20180309.5675819\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (04): (EL) 20180309.5675244\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (03): (EL) 20180206.5611318\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (02): (EL) There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Star [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. Virol J 2010; 7: 97; https://virologyj.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1743-422X-7-97.\n- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Sudan: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed disease - Sudan: (RS) human, cattle, RFI 20191006.6712623\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya (MU,NN) cattle, sheep, OIE 20190301.6341784\n2018\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO 20180410.5735975\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO 20180313.5683274\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (07): (EL) 20180312.5682186\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (06): (EL) livestock, RFI 20180310.5678018\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (05): (EL) bovine, OIE 20180309.5675819\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (04): (EL) 20180309.5675244\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (03): (EL) 20180206.5611318\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (02): (EL) 20180130.5595636\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\n2017\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - Sudan (02): (KA) RFI 20171123.5460631\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alolaib", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khartoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassala State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MU", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atbara", "country": {"archive_id": "6745546", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (04): human, livestock, spread, international impact", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6745546", "date": "2019-10-14 12:30:41", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: (RIVER NILE, RED SEA) HUMAN, ANIMAL, ALERT, OIE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Star [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. Virol J 2010; 7: 97; https://virologyj.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1743-422X-7-97.\n- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Sudan: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed disease - Sudan: (RS) human, cattle, RFI 20191006.6712623\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya (MU,NN) cattle, sheep, OIE 20190301.6341784\n2018\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO 20180410.5735975\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO 20180313.5683274\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (07): (EL) 20180312.5682186\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (06): (EL) livestock, RFI 20180310.5678018\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (05): (EL) bovine, OIE 20180309.5675819\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (04): (EL) 20180309.5675244\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (03): (EL) 20180206.5611318\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (02): (EL) 20180130.5595636\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\n2017\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - Sudan (02): (KA) RFI 20171123.5460631\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. {"archive_id": "6735332", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya (GA) livestock, alert, prevention", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6735332", "date": "2019-10-14 12:30:41", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: (RIVER NILE, RED SEA) HUMAN, ANIMAL, ALERT, OIE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Star [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. Virol J 2010; 7: 97; https://virologyj.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1743-422X-7-97.\n- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Sudan: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and {"archive_id": "6726806", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (02): (RS) human, livestock", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6726806", "date": "2019-10-14 12:30:41", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: (RIVER NILE, RED SEA) HUMAN, ANIMAL, ALERT, OIE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Star [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The report addresses an outbreak in a village in the [Arbaat] dam area, Alghunub Wa Alolaib, Red Sea State, affecting 950 susceptible goats, among which 21 \"cases\", 4 deaths, no culling or slaughter applied. The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. In 2010, a seroepidemiologic survey revealed a high prevalence of RVFV IgG among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala State (ref. 1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Hassanain AM, Noureldien W, Karsany MS, et al. Rift Valley fever among febrile patients at New Halfa hospital, eastern Sudan. Virol J 2010; 7: 97; https://virologyj.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1743-422X-7-97.\n- Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Sudan: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed disease - Sudan: (RS) human, cattle, RFI 20191006.6712623\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya (MU,NN) cattle, sheep, OIE 20190301.6341784\n2018\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO 20180410.5735975\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO 20180313.5683274\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (07): (EL) 20180312.5682186\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (06): (EL) livestock, RFI 20180310.5678018\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (05): (EL) bovine, OIE 20180309.5675819\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (04): (EL) 20180309.5675244\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (03): (EL) 20180206.5611318\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (02): (EL) 20180130.5595636\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\n2017\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - Sudan (02): (KA) RFI 20171123.5460631\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic [edited]\nhttps://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/13/attempts-to-control-rift-valley-fever-in-the-nile-river-state/\n\n\nMinistry of Health in the River Nile State, declared a state of maximum alert after the Federal Ministry of Health announced the presence of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in the region.\n\nThe state of alert was aimed to controlling Rift Valley fever (RVF), following its emergence in some localities in Berber, north of Bawqa, Ftouar, Joule, and Sulaimaniya, and in the Artoli region of the East Bank.\n\nA delegation from the Federal Ministry of Health arrived in the Nile yesterday [12 Oct 2019], headed by Director of Emergency Management Dr Babiker Al-Maqbool to find out the situation and provide technical assistance to contain the disease under the guidance of the Federal Minister of Health Dr Akram Ali Al-Tom.\n\nThe Minister of Health in charge of the state, Dr Abdel Moneim Bellah, held an enlightened enlargement meeting in Atbara in the presence of a large number of medical cadres.\n\nThe disease is transmitted from animals to humans through mosquitoes and infects people in contact with animals, as well as eating uneven [sic] meat and milk.\n\nThe Federal Minister of Health said on [Sat 12 Oct 2019] that: \"unknown fevers that have spread to the north of Berber in the northern Nile state are the Rift Valley fever.\"\n\nAbout a month ago in the state of the River Nile, unknown fevers have spread to the population and caused death and miscarriage of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier [12 Oct 2019] report in the same newspaper, informed the following:\n\"Hatem Fadl, an official in the epidemiology and emergency department at the Federal Ministry of Health, said that 4 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed among 17 samples taken last week, [which] were sent to the Central Laboratory in Khartoum. Hatem pointed out that the Federal Minister of Health commissioned a team to investigate the injuries, [which] arrived in the villages of Artoli, Al-Bawqa, and Fatwwar [Fri 11 Oct 2019], before the disease was officially announced today [12 Oct 2019]. He pointed out that RVF is common between humans and animals, so the Ministry of Health pledged to provide basic aid in cooperation with local authorities and resistance committees in these villages to combat the disease.\n\nSimilar fevers have recently spread in the Red Sea state in the Arbaat region, and was visited by Federal Health Minister Akram al-Tom.\"\n(https://khartoumstar.com/en/2019/10/12/ministry-of-health-rift-valley-fever-in-northern-sudan/).\n\nThe report above seems to present (national) laboratory confirmation of RVF currently affecting humans in Sudan's River Nile's state.\n\nAn earlier suspected RVF outbreak in Sudan's adjacent Red Sea State (see archive 20180410.5735975), has been confirmed; it was officially reported to the OIE on 13 Oct 2019 in an immediate notification (https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=32098). The given date of start of the outbreak is 25 Sep 2019. The report includes the following epidemiological comments:\n\"There were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019. There are no cattle or sheep populations in the area.\nIt is a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills. Surveillance, biosecurity measures, and increased awareness is ongoing.\"\n\nOfficial confirmation of the outbreaks in the Red Sea State is anticipated.\n\nThe 1st outbreak of RVF in Sudan was reported in 1973 among sheep and cattle in the White Nile State. In 1977, camels from Sudan were one of the suggested sources of RVF virus introduced, for the 1st time, into Egypt. Throughout the years, this virus was reported several times from humans and animals in Sudan. Ethiopia 19980222.0349\n.................................................arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-09-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alolaib", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khartoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassala State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MU", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atbara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "NN", "country": "Myanmar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6657915", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Central African Republic: WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6657915", "date": "2019-04-27 12:27:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (10): ANIMAL, HUMAN, SPREAD\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Apr 2019\nSource: Linfo.RE [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.linfo.re/ocean-indien/mayotte/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-a-mayotte-109-foyers-animaux-et-126-cas-humains\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1. Ministry of Agriculture and Food, France. Presentation: Rift Valley fever (RVF) situation in Mayotte, a French department in the Indian Ocean. EU - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF), 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/reg-com_ahw_20190321_rvf_mayotte-fra.pdf.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (09): animal, human, control, prevention 20190422.6434655\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (08): increase in cases, human, cattle 20190420.6433086\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (07): increase in cases, human, cattle 20190331.6395707\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (06): animal, human, control, epidemiology 20190328.6391591\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (05): more cases, human, cattle 20190317.6371859\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (04): more cases, human, cattle 20190303.6346454\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (03): increase in cases, human, cattle 20190222.6331808\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (02): increase in cases, human, cattle 20190211.6310620\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte: increase in cases, humans, cattle 20190202.6291963\nRift Valley fever: vertical transmission, comments, details 20190108.6248825\n2018\n----\nRift Valley fever: vertical transmission 20181210.6203158\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte: 2007-2008 20090129.0409\n.................................................arn/rd/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-04-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6630726", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mayotte (15): fewer cases, human, cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6630726", "date": "2019-04-27 12:27:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (10): ANIMAL, HUMAN, SPREAD\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Apr 2019\nSource: Linfo.RE [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.linfo.re/ocean-indien/mayotte/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-a-mayotte-109-foyers-animaux-et-126-cas-humains\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1. Ministry of Agriculture and Food, France. Presentation: Rift Valley fever (RVF) situation in Mayotte, a French department in the Indian Ocean. EU - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF), 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/reg-com_ahw_20190321_rvf_mayotte-fra.pdf.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (14): human, cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6556386", "date": "2019-04-27 12:27:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (10): ANIMAL, HUMAN, SPREAD\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Apr 2019\nSource: Linfo.RE [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.linfo.re/ocean-indien/mayotte/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-a-mayotte-109-foyers-animaux-et-126-cas-humains\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1. Ministry of Agriculture and Food, France. Presentation: Rift Valley fever (RVF) situation in Mayotte, a French department in the Indian Ocean. EU - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF), 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/reg-com_ahw_20190321_rvf_mayotte-fra.pdf.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (13): increase in cases, human, cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6501190", "date": "2019-04-27 12:27:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (10): ANIMAL, HUMAN, SPREAD\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Apr 2019\nSource: Linfo.RE [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.linfo.re/ocean-indien/mayotte/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-a-mayotte-109-foyers-animaux-et-126-cas-humains\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1.
