The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1. Mayotte: 2007-2008 20090129.0409\n.................................................arn/rd/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-04-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6444217", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mayotte (10): animal, human, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6444217", "date": "2019-04-27 12:27:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (10): ANIMAL, HUMAN, SPREAD\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Apr 2019\nSource: Linfo.RE [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.linfo.re/ocean-indien/mayotte/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-a-mayotte-109-foyers-animaux-et-126-cas-humains\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. The epidemiological situation as of 26 April 2019 [follows]:\n\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018), samples collected by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 109 foci of sick animals (including 86 bovine animals). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 126 human cases of RVF from the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since the beginning of April [2019]. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF), reminds the importance of preventive measures against the disease [the preventive measures, addressing public health, were included in post 20190420.6433086].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the past week, 20-26 Apr 2019, 5 new RVF foci (outbreaks) in animals (domestic ruminants) have been added to the 104 foci accumulated until the end of the previous week ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nThe number of new weekly human cases is 4, added to the 122 patients counted until the end of the previous week. RVF in animals is, most likely, the source of human infection.\n\nMayotte's some 4000 farms keep 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 data, Ref. 1). A vaccination program is technically and economically feasible. Vaccination is expected to discontinue the ongoing circulation of the virus on the island, prevent animal suffering, economical losses, and a serious human disease.\n\nThe French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (Ref .1): \"What about vaccination? -- To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.\" Such authorization deserves early consideration. - Mod.AS\n\nReference\n1. Ministry of Agriculture and Food, France. Presentation: Rift Valley fever (RVF) situation in Mayotte, a French department in the Indian Ocean. EU - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF), 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/reg-com_ahw_20190321_rvf_mayotte-fra.pdf.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (09): animal, human, control, prevention 20190422.6434655\nRift Valley fever - Mayotte (08): increase in cases, human, cattle "date": "2019-03-01 04:40:15", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (02): KENYA (MURANG'A, NYANDARUA) CATTLE, SHEEP, OIE\n***************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Feb 2019\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=29714\n\n\nRift Valley fever, Kenya\n------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Feb 2019 from Dr Obadiah Nyaga Njagi, director of veterinary services, directorate of veterinary services, State Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries, Nairobi, Kenya\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 25 Jan 2019\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Feb 2019\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Jul 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nOutbreak 1: Kihingo, Murang'a\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Jan 2019\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 160 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Shamata, Nyandarua\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Feb 2019\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 70 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 230 / 8 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 3.5 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 0.7 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with infected animal(s) at grazing/watering, vectors\nEpidemiological comments: Cattle was the primary species affected. This can be attributed to a high ratio of cattle relative to other species. Abortions were recorded in all stages of gestation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), quarantine, disinfection, ante- and post-mortem inspections, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nCentral veterinary investigation laboratory, Kabete (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCattle / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\nSheep / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Abortions in cattle have been reported in Nyandarua County (in Kenya's former Central province) since December 2018. Due to the drought conditions prevailing at that time, which are regarded unfavourable for vector amplification, Rift Valley fever (RVF) was not suspected. However, when 2 RVF cases were diagnosed in humans in February 2019 in Ol Kalou, the capital of Nyandarua County (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20190213.6315356), surveillance in animals, particularly addressing aborting cattle, was intensified. This led to the discovery of RVF in animals as described in the OIE notification. Mass vaccination followed.\n\nIn June-July 2018, a major RVF epidemic hit Kenya, particularly in its eastern area, affecting both humans and animals; 10 outbreaks were reported. These outbreaks were located in the counties of Wajir, Tana River, Isiolo, Siaya, Baringo, Marsabit, Mandera, and Meru. The event was resolved on 30 Jul 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=26827. In the same period, RVF infections occurred also in Uganda and Rwanda. - Mods.AS/CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nMurang'a, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12065\nNyanduma Location, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13440]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa: Kenya 20190213.6315356\nRift Valley fever: vertical transmission, comments, details Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 230 / 8 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 3.5 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 0.7 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with infected animal(s) at grazing/watering, vectors\nEpidemiological comments: Cattle was the primary species affected. This can be attributed to a high ratio of cattle relative to other species. Abortions were recorded in all stages of gestation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), quarantine, disinfection, ante- and post-mortem inspections, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nCentral veterinary investigation laboratory, Kabete (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCattle / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\nSheep / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Abortions in cattle have been reported in Nyandarua County (in Kenya's former Central province) since December 2018. Due to the drought conditions prevailing at that time, which are regarded unfavourable for vector amplification, Rift Valley fever (RVF) was not suspected. However, when 2 RVF cases were diagnosed in humans in February 2019 in Ol Kalou, the capital of Nyandarua County (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20190213.6315356), surveillance in animals, particularly addressing aborting cattle, was intensified. This led to the discovery of RVF in animals as described in the OIE notification. Mass vaccination followed.\n\nIn June-July 2018, a major RVF epidemic hit Kenya, particularly in its eastern area, affecting both humans and animals; 10 outbreaks were reported. These outbreaks were located in the counties of Wajir, Tana River, Isiolo, Siaya, Baringo, Marsabit, Mandera, and Meru. The event was resolved on 30 Jul 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=26827. In the same period, RVF infections occurred also in Uganda and Rwanda. - Mods.AS/CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nMurang'a, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12065\nNyanduma Location, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13440]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa: Kenya 20190213.6315356\nRift Valley fever: vertical transmission, comments, details [and dated] 28 Feb 2019 from Dr Obadiah Nyaga Njagi, director of veterinary services, directorate of veterinary services, State Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries, Nairobi, Kenya\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 25 Jan 2019\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Feb 2019\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Jul 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (2)\nOutbreak 1: Kihingo, Murang'a\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Jan 2019\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 160 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Shamata, Nyandarua\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Feb 2019\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 70 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 2\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 230 / 8 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 3.5 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 0.7 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with infected animal(s) at grazing/watering, vectors\nEpidemiological comments: Cattle was the primary species affected. This can be attributed to a high ratio of cattle relative to other species. Abortions were recorded in all stages of gestation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), quarantine, disinfection, ante- and post-mortem inspections, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nCentral veterinary investigation laboratory, Kabete (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCattle / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\nSheep / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Abortions in cattle have been reported in Nyandarua County (in Kenya's former Central province) since December 2018. Due to the drought conditions prevailing at that time, which are regarded unfavourable for vector amplification, Rift Valley fever (RVF) was not suspected. However, when 2 RVF cases were diagnosed in humans in February 2019 in Ol Kalou, the capital of Nyandarua County (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20190213.6315356), surveillance in animals, particularly addressing aborting cattle, was intensified. This led to the discovery of RVF in animals as described in the OIE notification. Mass vaccination followed.\n\nIn June-July 2018, a major RVF epidemic hit Kenya, particularly in its eastern area, affecting both humans and animals; 10 outbreaks were reported. These outbreaks were located in the counties of Wajir, Tana River, Isiolo, Siaya, Baringo, Marsabit, Mandera, and Meru. The event was resolved on 30 Jul 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=26827. Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 230 / 8 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 140 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 3.5 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 0.7 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with infected animal(s) at grazing/watering, vectors\nEpidemiological comments: Cattle was the primary species affected. This can be attributed to a high ratio of cattle relative to other species. Abortions were recorded in all stages of gestation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), quarantine, disinfection, ante- and post-mortem inspections, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nCentral veterinary investigation laboratory, Kabete (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCattle / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\nSheep / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Abortions in cattle have been reported in Nyandarua County (in Kenya's former Central province) since December 2018. Due to the drought conditions prevailing at that time, which are regarded unfavourable for vector amplification, Rift Valley fever (RVF) was not suspected. However, when 2 RVF cases were diagnosed in humans in February 2019 in Ol Kalou, the capital of Nyandarua County (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20190213.6315356), surveillance in animals, particularly addressing aborting cattle, was intensified. This led to the discovery of RVF in animals as described in the OIE notification. Mass vaccination followed.\n\nIn June-July 2018, a major RVF epidemic hit Kenya, particularly in its eastern area, affecting both humans and animals; 10 outbreaks were reported. These outbreaks were located in the counties of Wajir, Tana River, Isiolo, Siaya, Baringo, Marsabit, Mandera, and Meru. The event was resolved on 30 Jul 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=26827. In the same period, RVF infections occurred also in Uganda and Rwanda. - Mods.AS/CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nMurang'a, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12065\nNyanduma Location, Central, Kenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13440]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa: Kenya 20190213.6315356\nRift Valley fever: vertical transmission, comments, details species affected. This can be attributed to a high ratio of cattle relative to other species. Abortions were recorded in all stages of gestation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), quarantine, disinfection, ante- and post-mortem inspections, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nCentral veterinary investigation laboratory, Kabete (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nCattle / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\nSheep / IgM-capture ELISA / 27 Feb 2019 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. This led to the discovery of RVF in animals as described in the OIE notification. Mass vaccination followed.\n\nIn June-July 2018, a major RVF epidemic hit Kenya, particularly in its eastern area, affecting both humans and animals; 10 outbreaks were reported. These outbreaks were located in the counties of Wajir, Tana River, Isiolo, Siaya, Baringo, Marsabit, Mandera, and Meru. The event was resolved on 30 Jul 2018. Mayotte (03): increase in cases, human, cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6331808", "date": "2018-09-03 23:43:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (30): UGANDA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2018\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttps://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/rift-valley-fever-outbreak-claims-11-in-lyantonde-several-admitted\n\n\nThere is a confirmed outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Lyantonde district. The disease has already claimed 11 people and left several others in critical condition in 2 months, according to local authorities.\n\nDr. Moses Nkanika, the Lyantonde District Health Officer-DHO, says there is a possibility that the victims consumed meat from infected cows, sheep and goats. He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. In Kansagama sub-county, more than 10 people in Mityekula village, Kagaala parish have been admitted in critical condition after consuming meat from an infected cow. Bebwa Abern, the Mityekula village secretary, says one of the residents slaughtered a sick cow and sold meat to fellow residents.\n\nRVF is a viral disease that primarily affects animals but has the capacity to infect humans and can result in death, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nRonald Bameka, the Lyantonde District Veterinary Officer, says over 15 cows and 22 goats have died since the outbreak. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. No evidence has been reported to substantiate that claim.\n\nRVF virus is endemic in eastern Africa, and sporadic cases occur there in livestock and humans. This year (2018), large areas of Uganda and eastern Africa have undergone heavy rains and flooding, providing extensive breeding sites for RVF virus vector mosquitoes.\n\nThe loss of human and livestock life is indeed unfortunate. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. Personal protective equipment should be used by healthcare providers.\n\nMaps of Uganda: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97 - Mod.TY\n\nThough the current RVF event in Uganda started in June 2018, having first been recognized in human cases, information on cases in animals were published initially in early August 2018 (see 20180802.5943566). Results of tests are expected. No report to the OIE has been submitted so far. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (29): Uganda (NG, RR) bovine, human 20180817.5966611\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (28): Uganda 20180816.5970435\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (27): Uganda, Kenya, animal, spread 20180811.5959420\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (23): Uganda, animal, control 20180802.5943566\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): Uganda, WHO 20180724.5925173\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Uganda 20180720.5915630\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Uganda 20180717.5910736\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (14): animal vaccination, FAO alert 20180713.5897883\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (13): Uganda, WHO: 20180711.5898523\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kitazigolokwa village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Mityekula village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kiruhura", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mityekula", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isingiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansagama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6315356", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa: Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6315356", "date": "2018-09-03 23:43:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (30): UGANDA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2018\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttps://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/rift-valley-fever-outbreak-claims-11-in-lyantonde-several-admitted\n\n\nThere is a confirmed outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Lyantonde district. The disease has already claimed 11 people and left several others in critical condition in 2 months, according to local authorities.\n\nDr. Moses Nkanika, the Lyantonde District Health Officer-DHO, says there is a possibility that the victims consumed meat from infected cows, sheep and goats. He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. In Kansagama sub-county, more than 10 people in Mityekula village, Kagaala parish have been admitted in critical condition after consuming meat from an infected cow. Bebwa Abern, the Mityekula village secretary, says one of the residents slaughtered a sick cow and sold meat to fellow residents.\n\nRVF is a viral disease that primarily affects animals but has the capacity to infect humans and can result in death, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nRonald Bameka, the Lyantonde District Veterinary Officer, says over 15 cows and 22 goats have died since the outbreak. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. No evidence has been reported to substantiate that claim.\n\nRVF virus is endemic in eastern Africa, and sporadic cases occur there in livestock and humans. This year (2018), large areas of Uganda and eastern Africa have undergone heavy rains and flooding, providing extensive breeding sites for RVF virus vector mosquitoes.\n\nThe loss of human and livestock life is indeed unfortunate. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. Personal protective equipment should be used by healthcare providers.\n\nMaps of Uganda: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97 - Mod.TY\n\nThough the current RVF event in Uganda started in June 2018, having first been recognized in human cases, information on cases in animals were published initially in early August 2018 (see 20180802.5943566). Results of tests are expected. No report to the OIE has been submitted so far. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (29): Uganda (NG, RR) bovine, human 20180817.5966611\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (28): Uganda 20180816.5970435\nRift Valley fever - He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. EASTERN AFRICA (30): UGANDA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2018\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttps://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/rift-valley-fever-outbreak-claims-11-in-lyantonde-several-admitted\n\n\nThere is a confirmed outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Lyantonde district. The disease has already claimed 11 people and left several others in critical condition in 2 months, according to local authorities.\n\nDr. Moses Nkanika, the Lyantonde District Health Officer-DHO, says there is a possibility that the victims consumed meat from infected cows, sheep and goats. He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. In Kansagama sub-county, more than 10 people in Mityekula village, Kagaala parish have been admitted in critical condition after consuming meat from an infected cow. Bebwa Abern, the Mityekula village secretary, says one of the residents slaughtered a sick cow and sold meat to fellow residents.\n\nRVF is a viral disease that primarily affects animals but has the capacity to infect humans and can result in death, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nRonald Bameka, the Lyantonde District Veterinary Officer, says over 15 cows and 22 goats have died since the outbreak. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. No evidence has been reported to substantiate that claim.\n\nRVF virus is endemic in eastern Africa, and sporadic cases occur there in livestock and humans. This year (2018), large areas of Uganda and eastern Africa have undergone heavy rains and flooding, providing extensive breeding sites for RVF virus vector mosquitoes.\n\nThe loss of human and livestock life is indeed unfortunate. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. Personal protective equipment should be used by healthcare providers.\n\nMaps of Uganda: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97 - Mod.TY\n\nThough the current RVF event in Uganda started in June 2018, having first been recognized in human cases, information on cases in animals were published initially in early August 2018 (see 20180802.5943566). Results of tests are expected. Eastern Africa (18): Uganda 20180720.5915630\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Uganda 20180717.5910736\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (14): animal vaccination, FAO alert 20180713.5897883\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (13): Uganda, WHO: 20180711.5898523\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kitazigolokwa village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Mityekula village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kiruhura", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mityekula", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isingiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansagama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6203158", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever: vertical transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6203158", "date": "2018-09-03 23:43:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (30): UGANDA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2018\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttps://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/rift-valley-fever-outbreak-claims-11-in-lyantonde-several-admitted\n\n\nThere is a confirmed outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Lyantonde district. The disease has already claimed 11 people and left several others in critical condition in 2 months, according to local authorities.\n\nDr. Moses Nkanika, the Lyantonde District Health Officer-DHO, says there is a possibility that the victims consumed meat from infected cows, sheep and goats. He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. In Kansagama sub-county, more than 10 people in Mityekula village, Kagaala parish have been admitted in critical condition after consuming meat from an infected cow. Bebwa Abern, the Mityekula village secretary, says one of the residents slaughtered a sick cow and sold meat to fellow residents.\n\nRVF is a viral disease that primarily affects animals but has the capacity to infect humans and can result in death, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nRonald Bameka, the Lyantonde District Veterinary Officer, says over 15 cows and 22 goats have died since the outbreak. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. No evidence has been reported to substantiate that claim.\n\nRVF virus is endemic in eastern Africa, and sporadic cases occur there in livestock and humans. This year (2018), large areas of Uganda and eastern Africa have undergone heavy rains and flooding, providing extensive breeding sites for RVF virus vector mosquitoes.\n\nThe loss of human and livestock life is indeed unfortunate. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. Personal protective equipment should be used by healthcare providers.\n\nMaps of Uganda: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97 - Mod.TY\n\nThough the current RVF event in Uganda started in June 2018, having first been recognized in human cases, information on cases in animals were published initially in early August 2018 (see 20180802.5943566). Results of tests are expected. No report to the OIE has been submitted so far. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (29): Uganda (NG, RR) bovine, human 20180817.5966611\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (28): Uganda 20180816.5970435\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (27): Uganda, Kenya, animal, spread 20180811.5959420\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (23): Uganda, animal, control 20180802.5943566\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): Uganda, WHO 20180724.5925173\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Uganda 20180720.5915630\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Uganda 20180717.5910736\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (14): animal vaccination, FAO alert 20180713.5897883\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (13): Uganda, WHO: 20180711.5898523\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kitazigolokwa village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Mityekula village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kiruhura", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mityekula", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isingiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansagama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6014484", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - The disease has already claimed 11 people and left several others in critical condition in 2 months, according to local authorities.\n\nDr. Moses Nkanika, the Lyantonde District Health Officer-DHO, says there is a possibility that the victims consumed meat from infected cows, sheep and goats. He says 2 other patients died after being referred to Mabarara Regional Hospital. Nine of the deaths have been reported in Kitazigolokwa village, Katovu parish in Lyantonde rural sub-county.\n\nNkanika said that they have received several cases from different sub-counties, and the most complicated are referred to Mbarara Regional hospital. He noted that they are on high alert to the spread of the disease.\n\nDr. Okoth Obo, the Medical Superintendent of Lyantonde Hospital, said they established an isolation center to handle RVF cases, adding that they have received 10 patients in recent weeks.\n\nPatrick Rwozi, the Katovu Parish councilor, says some of the victims died after 2 or 3 days in admission. In Kansagama sub-county, more than 10 people in Mityekula village, Kagaala parish have been admitted in critical condition after consuming meat from an infected cow. He says that over 200 animals are at high risk, which may lead to a huge loss to livestock dealers in Lyantonde.\n\nHe warns that meat from infected animals is being sneaked into the market posing a high risk to the consumers, adding that they have so far arrested 3 people for slaughtering sick cows and selling meat to unsuspecting residents.\n\nAccording to Bameka, he wrote to the ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries and the ministry of health seeking their intervention, but neither has responded.\n\nIn order to contain the spread of the fever, Fred Muhangi, the Lyantonde LCV Chairperson, says the district has already paid for radio programs to sensitize the public about the outbreak.\n\nHe says that they have also stepped up their operations against the sale of uninspected meat as well as unauthorized animal movement in the district. The RVF outbreak comes at a time when the district is still under a foot-and-mouth-disease quarantine, which has hindered the livestock business.\n\nThe Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Dr. Diana Atwine, says different teams of experts have already been dispatched to Lyantonde, Mbarara, Isingiro and Kiruhura where the outbreak was announced.\n\nThe teams will educated people about the outbreak and the danger of eating meat from infected cows.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports from Uganda placed the blame for occurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) on incoming refugees. No evidence has been reported to substantiate that claim.\n\nRVF virus is endemic in eastern Africa, and sporadic cases occur there in livestock and humans. This year (2018), large areas of Uganda and eastern Africa have undergone heavy rains and flooding, providing extensive breeding sites for RVF virus vector mosquitoes.\n\nThe loss of human and livestock life is indeed unfortunate. Fortunately, the district is sponsoring radio programs and field teams to issue precautionary warnings to the public for handling or slaughtering ill animals to prevent RVF virus transmission and are arresting individuals who have sold meat from ill animals. Eastern Africa (13): Uganda, WHO: 20180711.5898523\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kitazigolokwa village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Mityekula village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kiruhura", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mityekula", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isingiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansagama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5966611", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (29): Uganda (NG, RR) bovine, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5966611", "date": "2018-07-31 12:42:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (22): RWANDA, BOVINE, RELAXED CONTROL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Journalducameroun.com, APA News report [summ., edited]\nhttps://www.journalducameroun.com/en/rift-valley-fever-rwanda-lifts-quarantine-on-cattle-movement/\n\n\nThe Rwandan Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, on [Mon 30 Jul 2018] announced it was lifting the quarantine on the movement of cattle that was imposed to control the deadly Rift Valley fever [RVF] in several parts of Eastern province. A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. No human cases have been reported in Rwanda during the recent event.\n\nThe tests upon which RVF, an OIE-listed disease, has been confirmed and statistics pertaining to the number, locations, morbidity, and mortality rates in Rwanda's animal population, are expected to be included in an official report to the OIE, as anticipated from all OIE member countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Eastern Province, Rwanda: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15277]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (21): Kenya, animal, spread 20180725.5927531\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO 20180410.5735975\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO 20180313.5683274\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (07): (EL) 20180312.5682186\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (06): (EL) livestock, RFI 20180310.5678018\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan (05): (EL) bovine, OIE 20180309.5675819\n.................................................arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2018-05-18 00:00:00", "1638-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Rwanda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rwamagana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Ngoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kirehe", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5970435", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (28): Uganda", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5970435", "date": "2018-07-31 12:42:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (22): RWANDA, BOVINE, RELAXED CONTROL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Journalducameroun.com, APA News report [summ., edited]\nhttps://www.journalducameroun.com/en/rift-valley-fever-rwanda-lifts-quarantine-on-cattle-movement/\n\n\nThe Rwandan Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, on [Mon 30 Jul 2018] announced it was lifting the quarantine on the movement of cattle that was imposed to control the deadly Rift Valley fever [RVF] in several parts of Eastern province. A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. No human cases have been reported in Rwanda during the recent event.\n\nThe tests upon which RVF, an OIE-listed disease, has been confirmed and statistics pertaining to the number, locations, morbidity, and mortality rates in Rwanda's animal population, are expected to be included in an official report to the OIE, as anticipated from all OIE member countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Eastern Province, Rwanda: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15277]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (21): Kenya, animal, spread 20180725.5927531\nRift Valley fever - A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. Eastern Africa (25): Rwanda, bovine, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5953335", "date": "2018-07-31 12:42:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (22): RWANDA, BOVINE, RELAXED CONTROL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Journalducameroun.com, APA News report [summ., edited]\nhttps://www.journalducameroun.com/en/rift-valley-fever-rwanda-lifts-quarantine-on-cattle-movement/\n\n\nThe Rwandan Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, on [Mon 30 Jul 2018] announced it was lifting the quarantine on the movement of cattle that was imposed to control the deadly Rift Valley fever [RVF] in several parts of Eastern province. A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. No human cases have been reported in Rwanda during the recent event.\n\nThe tests upon which RVF, an OIE-listed disease, has been confirmed and statistics pertaining to the number, locations, morbidity, and mortality rates in Rwanda's animal population, are expected to be included in an official report to the OIE, as anticipated from all OIE member countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Eastern Province, Rwanda: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15277]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (21): Kenya, animal, spread 20180725.5927531\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (24): Kenya, animal, spread, vacc, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5950711", "date": "2018-07-31 12:42:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (22): RWANDA, BOVINE, RELAXED CONTROL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Journalducameroun.com, APA News report [summ., edited]\nhttps://www.journalducameroun.com/en/rift-valley-fever-rwanda-lifts-quarantine-on-cattle-movement/\n\n\nThe Rwandan Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, on [Mon 30 Jul 2018] announced it was lifting the quarantine on the movement of cattle that was imposed to control the deadly Rift Valley fever [RVF] in several parts of Eastern province. A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. No human cases have been reported in Rwanda during the recent event.\n\nThe tests upon which RVF, an OIE-listed disease, has been confirmed and statistics pertaining to the number, locations, morbidity, and mortality rates in Rwanda's animal population, are expected to be included in an official report to the OIE, as anticipated from all OIE member countries. - A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. Eastern Africa (22): Rwanda, bovine, relaxed control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5938668", "date": "2018-07-31 12:42:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (22): RWANDA, BOVINE, RELAXED CONTROL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Journalducameroun.com, APA News report [summ., edited]\nhttps://www.journalducameroun.com/en/rift-valley-fever-rwanda-lifts-quarantine-on-cattle-movement/\n\n\nThe Rwandan Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, on [Mon 30 Jul 2018] announced it was lifting the quarantine on the movement of cattle that was imposed to control the deadly Rift Valley fever [RVF] in several parts of Eastern province. A quarantine on cattle in the country's 4 affected eastern districts has been imposed since mid-June [2018] after about 100 heads of cattle were killed by the virus.\n\nIn a notice issued [Mon 30 Jul 2018], the minister Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, G\u00e9rardine Mukeshimana, said the quarantine is no longer serving the purpose of slowing the spread of the deadly Rift Valley fever.\n\nReports indicate that the outbreak was first detected on 18 May 2018 in 4 districts in Eastern Rwanda including Ngoma, Kirehe, Rwamagana, and Kayonza.\n\nOf the 147 604 cows in the affected districts, the ministry says 99 died while 452 aborted.\n\nThe ministry says it has treated 1638 cows, with 36 930 sheep and 245 goats vaccinated against the disease.\n\nTo combat further deaths among animals, the ministry says it has dispatched veterinary doctors across the affected districts.\n\nOfficial reports indicate that no human case has been reported so far in Rwanda, yet the number of affected livestock is thought to be much higher.\n\nAccording to the Director General of Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB), Dr Patrick Karangwa, the cause of the outbreak is unusually heavy rains, which have created ponds and lakes where mosquitoes can breed, in this region which is normally dry.\n\n\"Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals\", Dr Karangwa said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[RVF, expressed mainly by cattle death and abortions, became active in Rwanda in April 2018, in the districts of Ngoma, Kirehe and Kayonza, in the southwest of the Eastern Province. Later, Kamonyi, a southern province was added.\n\nAn administrative map of Rwanda and detailed districts maps are available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Rwanda#Eastern_Province.\n\nIn the absence of data on the number of susceptible animals on the affected holdings, the mortality rate in cattle is not known. Based on accumulated field observations and experimental RVF infection trials, the mortality in adult cattle would, generally, not exceed 10 percent. No human cases have been reported in Rwanda during the recent event.\n\nThe tests upon which RVF, an OIE-listed disease, has been confirmed and statistics pertaining to the number, locations, morbidity, and mortality rates in Rwanda's animal population, are expected to be included in an official report to the OIE, as anticipated from all OIE member countries. -
