FAO - Eastern Africa, alert message\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2018\nSource: FAO Animal Production & Health Division: RVF Alert for Eastern African Countries [edited]\n\n\nAfter a period of abnormal, heavy rainfall and floods in the Eastern African region, an outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) was 1st reported in humans in Kenya; later it was confirmed that the disease was present in animals. These outbreaks are ongoing and pose a threat to the whole Eastern African region. Although, the upcoming season from July onwards will be unsuitable for the vector populations in most of the Eastern African region (except for Ethiopia, South Sudan, and southern Sudan), the potential spread of the disease through animal movements and informal trade routes within and outside of Kenya is likely to occur. Therefore, FAO advises the veterinary services and livestock farmers' communities in the region to remain vigilant to the potential occurrence and spread of RVF in humans and/or animals. In particular, the risk of RVF spread is considered to be very high in Kenya and moderate in Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Uganda, and United Republic of Tanzania. In addition, given the current and predicted average precipitation forecasts for the period June-September 2018, southern Sudan and western Ethiopia may be also characterized by suitable environmental conditions for RVF vector amplification.\n\nThe outbreak in Kenya is not the 1st RVF re-emergence in the region: during the past 7 months, RVF infections have been reported in Uganda (November 2017) and South Sudan (December 2017). Informal cross-border movement of livestock, conflicts, and lack of veterinary services can facilitate the spread of RVF within the affected countries in East Africa.\n\n[A Map, included in the alert message, presented (a) Predicted RVF risk areas for May 2018, and (b) predicted precipitation anomalies for the period July-September 2018].\n\nIn order to prevent and mitigate any occurrence of RVF in the region,\nFAO ADVISES COUNTRIES AT RISK TO:\na) Increase awareness of RVF clinical signs among farmers and workers in abattoirs and animal markets through newspapers, radio, mobile phones or other means of communication.\nb) Include aspects of occupational and exposure hazards (butchers, slaughter plant personnel, veterinarians and assistants) in communication campaigns and public awareness;\nc) Strengthen disease surveillance: active surveillance through serological surveillance of sentinel herds and syndrome surveillance for animals in at-risk areas (especially unusual abortion storms at any stage of pregnancy among small ruminants, camels and cattle). This should include surveillance in markets or places where large numbers are traded or congregate;\nd) Advocate the immediate notification of any RVF outbreak to the OIE through the World Animal Health Information System.\ne) Best practices for risk reduction:\n- Gloves and other appropriate protective clothing should be worn when handling sick animals or their tissues, or when slaughtering animals;\n- Fresh blood, raw milk or animal tissue should be thoroughly cooked before consumption;\n- Protecting against the risk of mosquito bites by using impregnated mosquito nets, personal insect repellent if available, light colored clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers), and by avoiding outdoor activity at peak biting times of the vector species.\nf) Promote targeted vaccination by trained personnel of susceptible animals in known at-risk areas\n- The use of vaccination as a control option for RVF is aimed at limiting virus circulation in enzootic areas and preventing epidemics in disease free areas and is most effective when used in conjunction with other control strategies, including surveillance, quarantine and movement controls;\n- Mass vaccination is one of the tools for preventing RVF epidemics in animals. However, vaccination is not recommended in the event of known or ongoing RVF virus circulation, as inappropriate vaccination can exacerbate the spread of virus transmission.\n\nNote that the FAO remains available to provide support for RVF preparedness/readiness for countries at risk and emergency response for countries facing outbreaks with the aim of protecting public and animal health, saving livelihoods and maintaining food security.\n\nIMPORTANT LINKS\n1. Rift Valley fever surveillance (FAO Manual)\n2. The last hurdles towards Rift Valley fever control (FAO Report)\n3. Africa El Ni\u00f1o and increased risk of Rift Valley fever - Warning to countries (EMPRES Watch) http://www.fao.org/3/a-i5282e.pdf#_blank\n4. Preparation of Rift Valley Fever Contingency Plans (FAO Manual) http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/Y4140E/Y4140E00.HTM#_blank\n5. Recognizing Rift Valley Fever (FAO Manual) http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/Y4611E/Y4611E00.HTM#_blank\n6. FAO Emergency Management Centre for Animal Health site http://www.fao.org/emergencies/how-we-work/prepare-and-respond/emc-ah/en/\n7. CDC RVF posters https://www.cdc.gov/vhf/rvf/resources/posters.html#_blank\n8. OIE RVF page http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf#_blank\n9. OIE Rev. sci. tech. Off. int. Epiz., 2014, 33 (2), 555-567 https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/8f7b/b3edf7c0d9ed8383bbb6e98016e2fb2252c5.pdf#_blank\n10. WHO RVF page http://www.who.int/csr/disease/riftvalleyfev/en/#_blank\n11. WHO fact sheet http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en#_blank\n12. USDA/NASA RVF update https://www.ars.usda.gov/southeast-area/gainesville-fl/center-for-medical-agricultural-and-veterinary-entomology/docs/rvf_monthlyupdates/#_blank\n13. CPC/NOAA seasonal precipitation forecast http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/international/nmme/html_monthly/precip_anom_africa_body.html#_blank\n14. IRI seasonal precipitation forecast https://iri.columbia.edu/our-expertise/climate/forecasts/seasonal-climate-forecasts/#_blank\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Julio Pinto\nFAO AGAH/GLEWS\nRome\n\n[The above alert message, signed by Dr Juan Lubroth, Chief Veterinary Officer, Animal Health Service, Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Rome, was distributed by email to the CVO's in the Eastern Africa countries on [Fri 29 Jun 2018]. This alert message is not available on-line; we are grateful to FAO's Dr Pinto for forwarding this useful document upon ProMED-mail's request. Its actuality is retained.\n\nSince the official confirmation of RVF in the country (on Fri 8 Jun 2018), Kenya officially notified a total of 6 outbreaks in Wajir (n=2), Isiolo (n=2), Tana River (n=1) and Siaya (n=1) counties.\n\nAccording to a reliable source, the number of Kenya's counties where RVF has been confirmed in animals since the start of the event exceeds the said 4. The most recent follow-up report was submitted to the OIE on [Mon 2 Jul 2018]. A summary with links to the reports and a map is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=26827.\n\nLivestock ring vaccination in the affected areas is on-going. The ban on movement and slaughter of animals from affected and at-risk counties remains in place. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nEastern Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64351]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): FAO, forecast 20180709.5895268\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (11): Rwanda (SU), bovine, spread [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-07-16 00:00:00", "2017-11-16 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "Kajiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kajiado West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5898523", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (13): Uganda, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5898523", "date": "2018-06-25 18:31:40", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (06): KENYA, SOUTH AFRICA\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Kenya\n[2] South Africa\n\n******\n[1] Kenya\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: Daily Nation [edited]\nhttps://www.nation.co.ke/counties/wajir/Govt-rushes-to-curb-Rift-Valley-fever-/3444790-4627920-o96n0f/index.html\n\n\nIn the past one month, 7 more people have died of Rift Valley fever, bringing the toll to 26, a report from the Ministry of Health's Disease Surveillance and Response Unit says.\n\nA total of 6 people died in Wajir, while one person succumbed in Marsabit. Some 24 cases were reported in Wajir and 2 in Marsabit.\n\nSiaya County on Friday [22 Jun 2018] issued an alert after one person died from the mosquito-borne disease, which was confirmed by tests at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (Kemri).\n\n\"Tests for Ebola and Marburg virus were negative,\" Dr Omondi Owino, Siaya's chief officer for Health, said.\n\nThe Health Ministry report says males were the most affected, at 70 percent. The most affected age group is 21-30 years.\n\nBased on enhanced surveillance of Rift Valley fever-like syndromes in humans and livestock, 6 counties have been identified as having the highest risk of an outbreak, including Tharaka-Nithi, Garissa, Tana River, Lamu, Garissa, Kajiado and Baringo.\n\nMombasa and Nairobi are on heightened alert due to the risk of imported human and animal cases.\n\nThe outbreak was 1st reported in Eldas Sub-County, Wajir, with a sample sent to Kemri testing positive for the virus on 7 Jun [2018].\n\nThe report said the outbreak was prevalent in insecurity-prone regions, and this might make it difficult to contain the virus. \"The communities are hard to reach (due to their nomadic lifestyle) and they depend majorly on animal products and have difficulties in accessing alternative diets,\" the report said.\n\nThe ministry has formed a team of experts from government and non-governmental organisations to provide technical guidance to counties.\n\n\"Counties affected have been directed to send blood specimens to Kemri for confirmation while the ban on movement and slaughter of animals from the affected and at-risk counties is put in place,\" Dr Okunga said.\n\nThe ministry has provided 500 000 doses of RVF vaccine [for animals] to high-risk counties based on risk analysis, while indoor residual spraying and animal spraying with pyrethroids is being carried out at the epicentre.\n\nHowever, vector surveillance and control for humans and animals in high-risk counties are yet to start. \"This will start soon. We are going to ensure that the surveillance starts as soon as possible and investigation teams sent out to all high-risk counties to provide technical guidance before the outbreak,\" he said.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that mainly affects livestock while people are mainly infected as a result of handling sick animals, either slaughtering them or assisting animals while giving birth. The other mode of transmission from animals, which is relatively low, is by mosquitoes and bites from other insects. The disease causes abortion in animals.\n\nDr Okunga cautioned residents not to directly handle sick animals or slaughter them without consulting veterinary or public health officers.\n\nResidents have also been encouraged to use mosquito [bed] nets.\n\n\"Anyone with a sick animal -- mainly sheep and cows -- must report to the nearest authorities immediately, and cases of abortions or loss of pregnancy in these animals must be reported too,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Angela Oketch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The RVF outbreak continues in both humans and animals. Contacting and informing the nomadic population across the broad area of the outbreak will be a challenge, as will administration of the vaccine to their animals. Mosquito vector surveillance should provide some real-time indications of the occurrence of the virus in the affected and nearby areas. Vector control, however, will be difficult. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of Kenya:\nhttps://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg;\nand of Wajir, Kenya:\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: National Center for Communicable Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/human-cases-of-rift-valley-fever-south-africa-2018/]\n\n\nFollowing confirmation of a Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in sheep on a farm in Jacobsdal area, Free State in May 2018 (NICD web alert, 22 May 2018), human and vector surveillance was conducted on the affected farm by the Provincial Department of Health and NICD. Mosquitoes collected on the affected farm tested negative for RVF virus, suggesting that active transmission had diminished due to decreased mosquito populations.\n\nFarmworkers and residents, who had been involved in the handling of potentially contaminated animal tissues during the sheep outbreak, were interviewed and sampled for RVF testing at NICD. Of 10 persons sampled, 4 individuals were retrospectively confirmed to have been infected with RVF virus; 4 individuals were shown to have probably been infected with RVFV, pending further tests on follow-up blood samples for confirmation; 2 individuals were not infected with RVFV despite handling potentially contaminated tissues. Of these, 6 of the 8 cases reported having experienced mild symptoms (fever, muscle pain, headache) in the preceding month, while none developed a severe disease that necessitated hospitalization. Healthcare workers must be aware of RVF and be vigilant for patients who meet the case definition, and, in such instances, submit specimens to the NICD-NHLS for laboratory testing (Healthcare worker guidelines and Case Investigation Form).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[It is not surprising that there is evidence of RVF virus infection in farm workers, fortunately without severe disease, in the areas where the sheep were infected. In the 21 Jun 2018 report (see ProMED-mail archive no. Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338), Peter Oberem, Afrivet farm CEO, is quoted as stating that 250 sheep died in May [2018] of Rift Valley fever on a farm in Jacobsdal in the Free State [also see ProMED-mail archive no. 20180517.5799859]. He continued: \"...reported cases so late in the season -- it is already winter in the southern hemisphere -- is worrying. It's not because we can expect a full-blown epidemic right away, but cases now point to a very good chance of a serious outbreak in summer [2018]. The biggest mistake farmers can make is to be complacent in winter,\" says Oberem. - Mod.TY, citing the post of infected sheep by Mod.AS.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Jacobsdal, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64294.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): regional cooperation 20180625.5874116\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya 20180622.5869367\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (06): (WJ) 20180619.5863401\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (05): (WJ) WHO 20180619.5862204\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (Free State) livestock, OIE 20180517.5799859\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: RFI 20110222.0586\n2010\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20100520.1675\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................sb/mpp/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2018-06-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mombasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobsdal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eldas Sub - County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AFRICA", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5895268", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): FAO, forecast", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5895268", "date": "2018-06-25 18:31:40", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (06): KENYA, SOUTH AFRICA\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Kenya\n[2] South Africa\n\n******\n[1] Kenya\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: Daily Nation [edited]\nhttps://www.nation.co.ke/counties/wajir/Govt-rushes-to-curb-Rift-Valley-fever-/3444790-4627920-o96n0f/index.html\n\n\nIn the past one month, 7 more people have died of Rift Valley fever, bringing the toll to 26, a report from the Ministry of Health's Disease Surveillance and Response Unit says.\n\nA total of 6 people died in Wajir, while one person succumbed in Marsabit. Some 24 cases were reported in Wajir and 2 in Marsabit.\n\nSiaya County on Friday [22 Jun 2018] issued an alert after one person died from the mosquito-borne disease, which was confirmed by tests at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (Kemri).\n\n\"Tests for Ebola and Marburg virus were negative,\" Dr Omondi Owino, Siaya's chief officer for Health, said.\n\nThe Health Ministry report says males were the most affected, at 70 percent. We are going to ensure that the surveillance starts as soon as possible and investigation teams sent out to all high-risk counties to provide technical guidance before the outbreak,\" he said.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that mainly affects livestock while people are mainly infected as a result of handling sick animals, either slaughtering them or assisting animals while giving birth. The other mode of transmission from animals, which is relatively low, is by mosquitoes and bites from other insects. The disease causes abortion in animals.\n\nDr Okunga cautioned residents not to directly handle sick animals or slaughter them without consulting veterinary or public health officers.\n\nResidents have also been encouraged to use mosquito [bed] nets.\n\n\"Anyone with a sick animal -- mainly sheep and cows -- must report to the nearest authorities immediately, and cases of abortions or loss of pregnancy in these animals must be reported too,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Angela Oketch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The RVF outbreak continues in both humans and animals. Vector control, however, will be difficult. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of Kenya:\nhttps://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg;\nand of Wajir, Kenya:\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: National Center for Communicable Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/human-cases-of-rift-valley-fever-south-africa-2018/]\n\n\nFollowing confirmation of a Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in sheep on a farm in Jacobsdal area, Free State in May 2018 (NICD web alert, 22 May 2018), human and vector surveillance was conducted on the affected farm by the Provincial Department of Health and NICD. Mosquitoes collected on the affected farm tested negative for RVF virus, suggesting that active transmission had diminished due to decreased mosquito populations.\n\nFarmworkers and residents, who had been involved in the handling of potentially contaminated animal tissues during the sheep outbreak, were interviewed and sampled for RVF testing at NICD. Of 10 persons sampled, 4 individuals were retrospectively confirmed to have been infected with RVF virus; 4 individuals were shown to have probably been infected with RVFV, pending further tests on follow-up blood samples for confirmation; 2 individuals were not infected with RVFV despite handling potentially contaminated tissues. Of these, 6 of the 8 cases reported having experienced mild symptoms (fever, muscle pain, headache) in the preceding month, while none developed a severe disease that necessitated hospitalization. Healthcare workers must be aware of RVF and be vigilant for patients who meet the case definition, and, in such instances, submit specimens to the NICD-NHLS for laboratory testing (Healthcare worker guidelines and Case Investigation Form).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[It is not surprising that there is evidence of RVF virus infection in farm workers, fortunately without severe disease, in the areas where the sheep were infected. In the 21 Jun 2018 report (see ProMED-mail archive no. Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338), Peter Oberem, Afrivet farm CEO, is quoted as stating that 250 sheep died in May [2018] of Rift Valley fever on a farm in Jacobsdal in the Free State [also see ProMED-mail archive no. 20180517.5799859]. He continued: \"...reported cases so late in the season -- it is already winter in the southern hemisphere -- is worrying. It's not because we can expect a full-blown epidemic right away, but cases now point to a very good chance of a serious outbreak in summer [2018]. The biggest mistake farmers can make is to be complacent in winter,\" says Oberem. - Mod.TY, citing the post of infected sheep by Mod.AS.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Jacobsdal, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64294.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): regional cooperation 20180625.5874116\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya 20180622.5869367\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (06): (WJ) 20180619.5863401\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (05): (WJ) WHO 20180619.5862204\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (Free State) livestock, OIE 20180517.5799859\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................sb/mpp/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2018-06-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mombasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobsdal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eldas Sub - County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AFRICA", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5886934", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (10): Kenya, WHO, livestock vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5886934", "date": "2018-06-25 18:31:40", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (06): KENYA, SOUTH AFRICA\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Kenya\n[2] South Africa\n\n******\n[1] Kenya\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: Daily Nation [edited]\nhttps://www.nation.co.ke/counties/wajir/Govt-rushes-to-curb-Rift-Valley-fever-/3444790-4627920-o96n0f/index.html\n\n\nIn the past one month, 7 more people have died of Rift Valley fever, bringing the toll to 26, a report from the Ministry of Health's Disease Surveillance and Response Unit says.\n\nA total of 6 people died in Wajir, while one person succumbed in Marsabit. Some 24 cases were reported in Wajir and 2 in Marsabit.\n\nSiaya County on Friday [22 Jun 2018] issued an alert after one person died from the mosquito-borne disease, which was confirmed by tests at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (Kemri).\n\n\"Tests for Ebola and Marburg virus were negative,\" Dr Omondi Owino, Siaya's chief officer for Health, said.\n\nThe Health Ministry report says males were the most affected, at 70 percent. The most affected age group is 21-30 years.\n\nBased on enhanced surveillance of Rift Valley fever-like syndromes in humans and livestock, 6 counties have been identified as having the highest risk of an outbreak, including Tharaka-Nithi, Garissa, Tana River, Lamu, Garissa, Kajiado and Baringo.\n\nMombasa and Nairobi are on heightened alert due to the risk of imported human and animal cases.\n\nThe outbreak was 1st reported in Eldas Sub-County, Wajir, with a sample sent to Kemri testing positive for the virus on 7 Jun [2018].\n\nThe report said the outbreak was prevalent in insecurity-prone regions, and this might make it difficult to contain the virus. \"The communities are hard to reach (due to their nomadic lifestyle) and they depend majorly on animal products and have difficulties in accessing alternative diets,\" the report said.\n\nThe ministry has formed a team of experts from government and non-governmental organisations to provide technical guidance to counties.\n\n\"Counties affected have been directed to send blood specimens to Kemri for confirmation while the ban on movement and slaughter of animals from the affected and at-risk counties is put in place,\" Dr Okunga said.\n\nThe ministry has provided 500 000 doses of RVF vaccine [for animals] to high-risk counties based on risk analysis, while indoor residual spraying and animal spraying with pyrethroids is being carried out at the epicentre.\n\nHowever, vector surveillance and control for humans and animals in high-risk counties are yet to start. \"This will start soon. We are going to ensure that the surveillance starts as soon as possible and investigation teams sent out to all high-risk counties to provide technical guidance before the outbreak,\" he said.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that mainly affects livestock while people are mainly infected as a result of handling sick animals, either slaughtering them or assisting animals while giving birth. The other mode of transmission from animals, which is relatively low, is by mosquitoes and bites from other insects. The disease causes abortion in animals.\n\nDr Okunga cautioned residents not to directly handle sick animals or slaughter them without consulting veterinary or public health officers.\n\nResidents have also been encouraged to use mosquito [bed] nets.\n\n\"Anyone with a sick animal -- mainly sheep and cows -- must report to the nearest authorities immediately, and cases of abortions or loss of pregnancy in these animals must be reported too,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Angela Oketch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The RVF outbreak continues in both humans and animals. Contacting and informing the nomadic population across the broad area of the outbreak will be a challenge, as will administration of the vaccine to their animals. Mosquito vector surveillance should provide some real-time indications of the occurrence of the virus in the affected and nearby areas. Vector control, however, will be difficult. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of Kenya:\nhttps://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg;\nand of Wajir, Kenya:\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: National Center for Communicable Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/human-cases-of-rift-valley-fever-south-africa-2018/]\n\n\nFollowing confirmation of a Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in sheep on a farm in Jacobsdal area, Free State in May 2018 (NICD web alert, 22 May 2018), human and vector surveillance was conducted on the affected farm by the Provincial Department of Health and NICD. Mosquitoes collected on the affected farm tested negative for RVF virus, suggesting that active transmission had diminished due to decreased mosquito populations.\n\nFarmworkers and residents, who had been involved in the handling of potentially contaminated animal tissues during the sheep outbreak, were interviewed and sampled for RVF testing at NICD. Of 10 persons sampled, 4 individuals were retrospectively confirmed to have been infected with RVF virus; 4 individuals were shown to have probably been infected with RVFV, pending further tests on follow-up blood samples for confirmation; 2 individuals were not infected with RVFV despite handling potentially contaminated tissues. Of these, 6 of the 8 cases reported having experienced mild symptoms (fever, muscle pain, headache) in the preceding month, while none developed a severe disease that necessitated hospitalization. Healthcare workers must be aware of RVF and be vigilant for patients who meet the case definition, and, in such instances, submit specimens to the NICD-NHLS for laboratory testing (Healthcare worker guidelines and Case Investigation Form).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[It is not surprising that there is evidence of RVF virus infection in farm workers, fortunately without severe disease, in the areas where the sheep were infected. In the 21 Jun 2018 report (see ProMED-mail archive no. Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338), Peter Oberem, Afrivet farm CEO, is quoted as stating that 250 sheep died in May [2018] of Rift Valley fever on a farm in Jacobsdal in the Free State [also see ProMED-mail archive no. 20180517.5799859]. He continued: \"...reported cases so late in the season -- it is already winter in the southern hemisphere -- is worrying. It's not because we can expect a full-blown epidemic right away, but cases now point to a very good chance of a serious outbreak in summer [2018]. The biggest mistake farmers can make is to be complacent in winter,\" says Oberem. - Mod.TY, citing the post of infected sheep by Mod.AS.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Jacobsdal, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64294.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): regional cooperation 20180625.5874116\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya 20180622.5869367\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (06): (WJ) 20180619.5863401\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (05): (WJ) WHO 20180619.5862204\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (Free State) livestock, OIE 20180517.5799859\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................sb/mpp/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2018-06-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mombasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobsdal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eldas Sub - EASTERN AFRICA (06): KENYA, SOUTH AFRICA\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Kenya\n[2] South Africa\n\n******\n[1] Kenya\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: Daily Nation [edited]\nhttps://www.nation.co.ke/counties/wajir/Govt-rushes-to-curb-Rift-Valley-fever-/3444790-4627920-o96n0f/index.html\n\n\nIn the past one month, 7 more people have died of Rift Valley fever, bringing the toll to 26, a report from the Ministry of Health's Disease Surveillance and Response Unit says.\n\nA total of 6 people died in Wajir, while one person succumbed in Marsabit. Some 24 cases were reported in Wajir and 2 in Marsabit.\n\nSiaya County on Friday [22 Jun 2018] issued an alert after one person died from the mosquito-borne disease, which was confirmed by tests at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (Kemri).\n\n\"Tests for Ebola and Marburg virus were negative,\" Dr Omondi Owino, Siaya's chief officer for Health, said.\n\nThe Health Ministry report says males were the most affected, at 70 percent. We are going to ensure that the surveillance starts as soon as possible and investigation teams sent out to all high-risk counties to provide technical guidance before the outbreak,\" he said.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that mainly affects livestock while people are mainly infected as a result of handling sick animals, either slaughtering them or assisting animals while giving birth. The other mode of transmission from animals, which is relatively low, is by mosquitoes and bites from other insects. The disease causes abortion in animals.\n\nDr Okunga cautioned residents not to directly handle sick animals or slaughter them without consulting veterinary or public health officers.\n\nResidents have also been encouraged to use mosquito [bed] nets.\n\n\"Anyone with a sick animal -- mainly sheep and cows -- must report to the nearest authorities immediately, and cases of abortions or loss of pregnancy in these animals must be reported too,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Angela Oketch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The RVF outbreak continues in both humans and animals. Contacting and informing the nomadic population across the broad area of the outbreak will be a challenge, as will administration of the vaccine to their animals. Vector control, however, will be difficult. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of Kenya:\nhttps://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg;\nand of Wajir, Kenya:\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: National Center for Communicable Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/human-cases-of-rift-valley-fever-south-africa-2018/]\n\n\nFollowing confirmation of a Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in sheep on a farm in Jacobsdal area, Free State in May 2018 (NICD web alert, 22 May 2018), human and vector surveillance was conducted on the affected farm by the Provincial Department of Health and NICD. Mosquitoes collected on the affected farm tested negative for RVF virus, suggesting that active transmission had diminished due to decreased mosquito populations.\n\nFarmworkers and residents, who had been involved in the handling of potentially contaminated animal tissues during the sheep outbreak, were interviewed and sampled for RVF testing at NICD. Of 10 persons sampled, 4 individuals were retrospectively confirmed to have been infected with RVF virus; 4 individuals were shown to have probably been infected with RVFV, pending further tests on follow-up blood samples for confirmation; 2 individuals were not infected with RVFV despite handling potentially contaminated tissues. Of these, 6 of the 8 cases reported having experienced mild symptoms (fever, muscle pain, headache) in the preceding month, while none developed a severe disease that necessitated hospitalization. Healthcare workers must be aware of RVF and be vigilant for patients who meet the case definition, and, in such instances, submit specimens to the NICD-NHLS for laboratory testing (Healthcare worker guidelines and Case Investigation Form).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[It is not surprising that there is evidence of RVF virus infection in farm workers, fortunately without severe disease, in the areas where the sheep were infected. In the 21 Jun 2018 report (see ProMED-mail archive no. Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338), Peter Oberem, Afrivet farm CEO, is quoted as stating that 250 sheep died in May [2018] of Rift Valley fever on a farm in Jacobsdal in the Free State [also see ProMED-mail archive no. 20180517.5799859]. He continued: \"...reported cases so late in the season -- it is already winter in the southern hemisphere -- is worrying. It's not because we can expect a full-blown epidemic right away, but cases now point to a very good chance of a serious outbreak in summer [2018]. The biggest mistake farmers can make is to be complacent in winter,\" says Oberem. - Mod.TY, citing the post of infected sheep by Mod.AS.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Jacobsdal, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64294.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20180620.5865028\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (06): (WJ) 20180619.5863401\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (05): (WJ) WHO 20180619.5862204\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................sb/mpp/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2018-06-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mombasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobsdal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eldas Sub - County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AFRICA", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5877838", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (07): Kenya, animals, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5877838", "date": "2018-06-25 18:31:40", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (06): KENYA, SOUTH AFRICA\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Kenya\n[2] South Africa\n\n******\n[1] Kenya\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: Daily Nation [edited]\nhttps://www.nation.co.ke/counties/wajir/Govt-rushes-to-curb-Rift-Valley-fever-/3444790-4627920-o96n0f/index.html\n\n\nIn the past one month, 7 more people have died of Rift Valley fever, bringing the toll to 26, a report from the Ministry of Health's Disease Surveillance and Response Unit says.\n\nA total of 6 people died in Wajir, while one person succumbed in Marsabit. Some 24 cases were reported in Wajir and 2 in Marsabit.\n\nSiaya County on Friday [22 Jun 2018] issued an alert after one person died from the mosquito-borne disease, which was confirmed by tests at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (Kemri).\n\n\"Tests for Ebola and Marburg virus were negative,\" Dr Omondi Owino, Siaya's chief officer for Health, said.\n\nThe Health Ministry report says males were the most affected, at 70 percent. The most affected age group is 21-30 years.\n\nBased on enhanced surveillance of Rift Valley fever-like syndromes in humans and livestock, 6 counties have been identified as having the highest risk of an outbreak, including Tharaka-Nithi, Garissa, Tana River, Lamu, Garissa, Kajiado and Baringo.\n\nMombasa and Nairobi are on heightened alert due to the risk of imported human and animal cases.\n\nThe outbreak was 1st reported in Eldas Sub-County, Wajir, with a sample sent to Kemri testing positive for the virus on 7 Jun [2018].\n\nThe report said the outbreak was prevalent in insecurity-prone regions, and this might make it difficult to contain the virus. \"The communities are hard to reach (due to their nomadic lifestyle) and they depend majorly on animal products and have difficulties in accessing alternative diets,\" the report said.\n\nThe ministry has formed a team of experts from government and non-governmental organisations to provide technical guidance to counties.\n\n\"Counties affected have been directed to send blood specimens to Kemri for confirmation while the ban on movement and slaughter of animals from the affected and at-risk counties is put in place,\" Dr Okunga said.\n\nThe ministry has provided 500 000 doses of RVF vaccine [for animals] to high-risk counties based on risk analysis, while indoor residual spraying and animal spraying with pyrethroids is being carried out at the epicentre.\n\nHowever, vector surveillance and control for humans and animals in high-risk counties are yet to start. \"This will start soon. We are going to ensure that the surveillance starts as soon as possible and investigation teams sent out to all high-risk counties to provide technical guidance before the outbreak,\" he said.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that mainly affects livestock while people are mainly infected as a result of handling sick animals, either slaughtering them or assisting animals while giving birth. The other mode of transmission from animals, which is relatively low, is by mosquitoes and bites from other insects. The disease causes abortion in animals.\n\nDr Okunga cautioned residents not to directly handle sick animals or slaughter them without consulting veterinary or public health officers.\n\nResidents have also been encouraged to use mosquito [bed] nets.\n\n\"Anyone with a sick animal -- mainly sheep and cows -- must report to the nearest authorities immediately, and cases of abortions or loss of pregnancy in these animals must be reported too,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Angela Oketch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The RVF outbreak continues in both humans and animals. Contacting and informing the nomadic population across the broad area of the outbreak will be a challenge, as will administration of the vaccine to their animals. Mosquito vector surveillance should provide some real-time indications of the occurrence of the virus in the affected and nearby areas. Vector control, however, will be difficult. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of Kenya:\nhttps://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg;\nand of Wajir, Kenya:\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa\nDate: Sun 24 Jun 2018\nSource: National Center for Communicable Diseases [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/human-cases-of-rift-valley-fever-south-africa-2018/]\n\n\nFollowing confirmation of a Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in sheep on a farm in Jacobsdal area, Free State in May 2018 (NICD web alert, 22 May 2018), human and vector surveillance was conducted on the affected farm by the Provincial Department of Health and NICD. Mosquitoes collected on the affected farm tested negative for RVF virus, suggesting that active transmission had diminished due to decreased mosquito populations.\n\nFarmworkers and residents, who had been involved in the handling of potentially contaminated animal tissues during the sheep outbreak, were interviewed and sampled for RVF testing at NICD. Of 10 persons sampled, 4 individuals were retrospectively confirmed to have been infected with RVF virus; 4 individuals were shown to have probably been infected with RVFV, pending further tests on follow-up blood samples for confirmation; 2 individuals were not infected with RVFV despite handling potentially contaminated tissues. Of these, 6 of the 8 cases reported having experienced mild symptoms (fever, muscle pain, headache) in the preceding month, while none developed a severe disease that necessitated hospitalization. Healthcare workers must be aware of RVF and be vigilant for patients who meet the case definition, and, in such instances, submit specimens to the NICD-NHLS for laboratory testing (Healthcare worker guidelines and Case Investigation Form).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[It is not surprising that there is evidence of RVF virus infection in farm workers, fortunately without severe disease, in the areas where the sheep were infected. In the 21 Jun 2018 report (see ProMED-mail archive no. Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination 20180622.5870338), Peter Oberem, Afrivet farm CEO, is quoted as stating that 250 sheep died in May [2018] of Rift Valley fever on a farm in Jacobsdal in the Free State [also see ProMED-mail archive no. 20180517.5799859]. He continued: \"...reported cases so late in the season -- it is already winter in the southern hemisphere -- is worrying. It's not because we can expect a full-blown epidemic right away, but cases now point to a very good chance of a serious outbreak in summer [2018]. The biggest mistake farmers can make is to be complacent in winter,\" says Oberem. - Mod.TY, citing the post of infected sheep by Mod.AS.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Jacobsdal, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64294.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................sb/mpp/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2018-06-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-06-24 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mombasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobsdal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Siaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eldas Sub - County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AFRICA", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5874116", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): regional cooperation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5874116", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. The patient reported having consumed meat from a sick animal; the patient died the same day. On 4 Jun [2018], 2 relatives of the index patient were admitted. Blood samples were collected and sent to the Kenya Medical Research Institute, one of which was confirmed positive for Rift Valley fever on 6 Jun [2018].\n\nAs of 16 Jun [2018], a total of 26 human cases have been reported from Wajir (24 cases) and Marsabit (2 cases) counties, including 7 confirmed cases and 6 deaths (case fatality ratio (CFR) = 23 percent); 6 patients have been discharged, while one is still hospitalized. A high number of deaths and abortions among livestock, including camels and goats, has been reported in Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, Marsabit, Tana River, and Wajir counties. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. An alert was issued to all County Directors in February 2018 and a general national alert was communicated in May 2018.\n\nThe following actions have been taken since the outbreak was confirmed:\n- On 8 Jun [2018], the MoH and Ministry of Agriculture convened an emergency meeting with the Ministry of Livestock (MoL) and key stakeholders. A health sector task force meeting was held, and partners pledged their support to Rift Valley fever control.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], the MoH activated the Emergency Operations Centre, with an Event Manager and supporting technical team.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], a multi-sectoral investigation teams was deployed in Wajir County to support the county health teams. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. In Wajir County, 5 treatment centres have been established.\n- Active case searching and community sensitization activities are ongoing in the affected areas. Guidelines for vector control and other informational materials have been dispatched to Wajir County, and messages are being disseminated through Community Health Volunteers.\n- A ban on slaughtering animals and restriction of livestock movement has been imposed in the affected areas.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are not uncommon in Kenya. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. However, the high number of reported deaths and abortions in livestock is concerning, especially because the event affects nomadic communities for which diet is predominantly based on animal products. The high volume of movement of cattle and people in this area increases the risk of further spread of the outbreak both within Kenya, and to neighbouring countries.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. The majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. Herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians have an increased risk of infection. Awareness of the risk factors of Rift Valley fever infection and measures to prevent mosquito bites are the only ways to reduce human infection and deaths. Public health messages for risk reduction should focus on:\n\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission resulting from unsafe animal husbandry and slaughtering practices. Practicing hand hygiene and wearing gloves and other personal protective equipment when handling sick animals or their tissues or when slaughtering animals is recommended.\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission arising from the unsafe consumption of raw or unpasteurized milk or animal tissue. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Vaccination campaigns are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle propagation of the virus. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. These ministries issued an alert for the risk of Rift Valley fever due to heavy rains and flooding and named 15 counties as high-risk areas (see Rift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703). The loss of camels and small ruminants has social and economic consequences for their owners. Where access to banks is limited, these animals become a store of value as well as a critical source of family income and food. It is difficult to predict how long the outbreak may last.\n\nThe rains and flooding have doubtless increased the populations of RVF virus mosquito vectors in the area. A vigorous vaccination campaign should reduce risk of infection for the animal populations. There is no commercially available vaccine for humans, so public education is the best way to influence behavior in ways to reduce risk of acquiring an infection. - Mod.TY\n\nKenya submitted its 1st follow-up report addressing RVF on 15 Jun 2018, adding the county Tana River to Wajir, where the initial RVF animal cases were identified in livestock (camels). The report, with map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26928.\n\nAccording to the WHO Relief Web report of 18 Jun 2018, the number of counties in Kenya's Eastern province, where RVF is currently affecting animals, has risen to 6, adding Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, and Marsabit to the list. This rapid spread of the disease in animals is in need of veterinary confirmation. As indicated in the report, vaccination campaigns in animals are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle dissemination of the virus. More on RVF control activities can be found in FAO's updated manual at http://www.fao.org/3/i8475en/I8475EN.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: RFI 20110222.0586\n2010\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20100520.1675\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tana River", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa , Kadjiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wajir County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5870338", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa (02): animal, preventive vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5870338", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. The patient reported having consumed meat from a sick animal; the patient died the same day. On 4 Jun [2018], 2 relatives of the index patient were admitted. Blood samples were collected and sent to the Kenya Medical Research Institute, one of which was confirmed positive for Rift Valley fever on 6 Jun [2018].\n\nAs of 16 Jun [2018], a total of 26 human cases have been reported from Wajir (24 cases) and Marsabit (2 cases) counties, including 7 confirmed cases and 6 deaths (case fatality ratio (CFR) = 23 percent); 6 patients have been discharged, while one is still hospitalized. A high number of deaths and abortions among livestock, including camels and goats, has been reported in Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, Marsabit, Tana River, and Wajir counties. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. An alert was issued to all County Directors in February 2018 and a general national alert was communicated in May 2018.\n\nThe following actions have been taken since the outbreak was confirmed:\n- On 8 Jun [2018], the MoH and Ministry of Agriculture convened an emergency meeting with the Ministry of Livestock (MoL) and key stakeholders. A health sector task force meeting was held, and partners pledged their support to Rift Valley fever control.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], the MoH activated the Emergency Operations Centre, with an Event Manager and supporting technical team.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], a multi-sectoral investigation teams was deployed in Wajir County to support the county health teams. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. In Wajir County, 5 treatment centres have been established.\n- Active case searching and community sensitization activities are ongoing in the affected areas. Guidelines for vector control and other informational materials have been dispatched to Wajir County, and messages are being disseminated through Community Health Volunteers.\n- A ban on slaughtering animals and restriction of livestock movement has been imposed in the affected areas.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are not uncommon in Kenya. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. However, the high number of reported deaths and abortions in livestock is concerning, especially because the event affects nomadic communities for which diet is predominantly based on animal products. The high volume of movement of cattle and people in this area increases the risk of further spread of the outbreak both within Kenya, and to neighbouring countries.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. The majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. Herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians have an increased risk of infection. Awareness of the risk factors of Rift Valley fever infection and measures to prevent mosquito bites are the only ways to reduce human infection and deaths. Public health messages for risk reduction should focus on:\n\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission resulting from unsafe animal husbandry and slaughtering practices. Practicing hand hygiene and wearing gloves and other personal protective equipment when handling sick animals or their tissues or when slaughtering animals is recommended.\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission arising from the unsafe consumption of raw or unpasteurized milk or animal tissue. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Vaccination campaigns are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle propagation of the virus. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. These ministries issued an alert for the risk of Rift Valley fever due to heavy rains and flooding and named 15 counties as high-risk areas (see Rift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703). The loss of camels and small ruminants has social and economic consequences for their owners. Where access to banks is limited, these animals become a store of value as well as a critical source of family income and food. It is difficult to predict how long the outbreak may last.\n\nThe rains and flooding have doubtless increased the populations of RVF virus mosquito vectors in the area. A vigorous vaccination campaign should reduce risk of infection for the animal populations. There is no commercially available vaccine for humans, so public education is the best way to influence behavior in ways to reduce risk of acquiring an infection. - Mod.TY\n\nKenya submitted its 1st follow-up report addressing RVF on 15 Jun 2018, adding the county Tana River to Wajir, where the initial RVF animal cases were identified in livestock (camels). The report, with map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26928.\n\nAccording to the WHO Relief Web report of 18 Jun 2018, the number of counties in Kenya's Eastern province, where RVF is currently affecting animals, has risen to 6, adding Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, and Marsabit to the list. This rapid spread of the disease in animals is in need of veterinary confirmation. As indicated in the report, vaccination campaigns in animals are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle dissemination of the virus. More on RVF control activities can be found in FAO's updated manual at http://www.fao.org/3/i8475en/I8475EN.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: RFI 20110222.0586\n2010\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20100520.1675\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tana River", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa , Kadjiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wajir County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5869367", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever -
