Eastern Africa (03): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5866921", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. The patient reported having consumed meat from a sick animal; the patient died the same day. On 4 Jun [2018], 2 relatives of the index patient were admitted. Blood samples were collected and sent to the Kenya Medical Research Institute, one of which was confirmed positive for Rift Valley fever on 6 Jun [2018].\n\nAs of 16 Jun [2018], a total of 26 human cases have been reported from Wajir (24 cases) and Marsabit (2 cases) counties, including 7 confirmed cases and 6 deaths (case fatality ratio (CFR) = 23 percent); 6 patients have been discharged, while one is still hospitalized. A high number of deaths and abortions among livestock, including camels and goats, has been reported in Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, Marsabit, Tana River, and Wajir counties. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. An alert was issued to all County Directors in February 2018 and a general national alert was communicated in May 2018.\n\nThe following actions have been taken since the outbreak was confirmed:\n- On 8 Jun [2018], the MoH and Ministry of Agriculture convened an emergency meeting with the Ministry of Livestock (MoL) and key stakeholders. A health sector task force meeting was held, and partners pledged their support to Rift Valley fever control.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], the MoH activated the Emergency Operations Centre, with an Event Manager and supporting technical team.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], a multi-sectoral investigation teams was deployed in Wajir County to support the county health teams. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. In Wajir County, 5 treatment centres have been established.\n- Active case searching and community sensitization activities are ongoing in the affected areas. Guidelines for vector control and other informational materials have been dispatched to Wajir County, and messages are being disseminated through Community Health Volunteers.\n- A ban on slaughtering animals and restriction of livestock movement has been imposed in the affected areas.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are not uncommon in Kenya. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. However, the high number of reported deaths and abortions in livestock is concerning, especially because the event affects nomadic communities for which diet is predominantly based on animal products. The high volume of movement of cattle and people in this area increases the risk of further spread of the outbreak both within Kenya, and to neighbouring countries.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. The majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. Herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians have an increased risk of infection. Awareness of the risk factors of Rift Valley fever infection and measures to prevent mosquito bites are the only ways to reduce human infection and deaths. Public health messages for risk reduction should focus on:\n\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission resulting from unsafe animal husbandry and slaughtering practices. Practicing hand hygiene and wearing gloves and other personal protective equipment when handling sick animals or their tissues or when slaughtering animals is recommended.\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission arising from the unsafe consumption of raw or unpasteurized milk or animal tissue. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Vaccination campaigns are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle propagation of the virus. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. These ministries issued an alert for the risk of Rift Valley fever due to heavy rains and flooding and named 15 counties as high-risk areas (see Rift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703). The loss of camels and small ruminants has social and economic consequences for their owners. Where access to banks is limited, these animals become a store of value as well as a critical source of family income and food. It is difficult to predict how long the outbreak may last.\n\nThe rains and flooding have doubtless increased the populations of RVF virus mosquito vectors in the area. A vigorous vaccination campaign should reduce risk of infection for the animal populations. There is no commercially available vaccine for humans, so public education is the best way to influence behavior in ways to reduce risk of acquiring an infection. - Mod.TY\n\nKenya submitted its 1st follow-up report addressing RVF on 15 Jun 2018, adding the county Tana River to Wajir, where the initial RVF animal cases were identified in livestock (camels). The report, with map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26928.\n\nAccording to the WHO Relief Web report of 18 Jun 2018, the number of counties in Kenya's Eastern province, where RVF is currently affecting animals, has risen to 6, adding Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, and Marsabit to the list. This rapid spread of the disease in animals is in need of veterinary confirmation. As indicated in the report, vaccination campaigns in animals are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle dissemination of the virus. More on RVF control activities can be found in FAO's updated manual at http://www.fao.org/3/i8475en/I8475EN.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: RFI 20110222.0586\n2010\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20100520.1675\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tana River", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa , Kadjiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wajir County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5865028", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5865028", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. The patient reported having consumed meat from a sick animal; the patient died the same day. On 4 Jun [2018], 2 relatives of the index patient were admitted. Blood samples were collected and sent to the Kenya Medical Research Institute, one of which was confirmed positive for Rift Valley fever on 6 Jun [2018].\n\nAs of 16 Jun [2018], a total of 26 human cases have been reported from Wajir (24 cases) and Marsabit (2 cases) counties, including 7 confirmed cases and 6 deaths (case fatality ratio (CFR) = 23 percent); 6 patients have been discharged, while one is still hospitalized. A high number of deaths and abortions among livestock, including camels and goats, has been reported in Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, Marsabit, Tana River, and Wajir counties. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. An alert was issued to all County Directors in February 2018 and a general national alert was communicated in May 2018.\n\nThe following actions have been taken since the outbreak was confirmed:\n- On 8 Jun [2018], the MoH and Ministry of Agriculture convened an emergency meeting with the Ministry of Livestock (MoL) and key stakeholders. A health sector task force meeting was held, and partners pledged their support to Rift Valley fever control.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], the MoH activated the Emergency Operations Centre, with an Event Manager and supporting technical team.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], a multi-sectoral investigation teams was deployed in Wajir County to support the county health teams. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. In Wajir County, 5 treatment centres have been established.\n- Active case searching and community sensitization activities are ongoing in the affected areas. Guidelines for vector control and other informational materials have been dispatched to Wajir County, and messages are being disseminated through Community Health Volunteers.\n- A ban on slaughtering animals and restriction of livestock movement has been imposed in the affected areas.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are not uncommon in Kenya. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. However, the high number of reported deaths and abortions in livestock is concerning, especially because the event affects nomadic communities for which diet is predominantly based on animal products. The high volume of movement of cattle and people in this area increases the risk of further spread of the outbreak both within Kenya, and to neighbouring countries.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. The majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. Herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians have an increased risk of infection. Awareness of the risk factors of Rift Valley fever infection and measures to prevent mosquito bites are the only ways to reduce human infection and deaths. Public health messages for risk reduction should focus on:\n\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission resulting from unsafe animal husbandry and slaughtering practices. Practicing hand hygiene and wearing gloves and other personal protective equipment when handling sick animals or their tissues or when slaughtering animals is recommended.\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission arising from the unsafe consumption of raw or unpasteurized milk or animal tissue. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Vaccination campaigns are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle propagation of the virus. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. These ministries issued an alert for the risk of Rift Valley fever due to heavy rains and flooding and named 15 counties as high-risk areas (see Rift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703). The loss of camels and small ruminants has social and economic consequences for their owners. Where access to banks is limited, these animals become a store of value as well as a critical source of family income and food. It is difficult to predict how long the outbreak may last.\n\nThe rains and flooding have doubtless increased the populations of RVF virus mosquito vectors in the area. A vigorous vaccination campaign should reduce risk of infection for the animal populations. There is no commercially available vaccine for humans, so public education is the best way to influence behavior in ways to reduce risk of acquiring an infection. - Mod.TY\n\nKenya submitted its 1st follow-up report addressing RVF on 15 Jun 2018, adding the county Tana River to Wajir, where the initial RVF animal cases were identified in livestock (camels). The report, with map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26928.\n\nAccording to the WHO Relief Web report of 18 Jun 2018, the number of counties in Kenya's Eastern province, where RVF is currently affecting animals, has risen to 6, adding Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, and Marsabit to the list. This rapid spread of the disease in animals is in need of veterinary confirmation. As indicated in the report, vaccination campaigns in animals are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle dissemination of the virus. More on RVF control activities can be found in FAO's updated manual at http://www.fao.org/3/i8475en/I8475EN.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703\n2011\n----\nUndiagnosed disease, camel - Kenya: RFI 20110222.0586\n2010\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20100520.1675\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tana River", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa , Kadjiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wajir County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5863493", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (06): (WJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5863401", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tana River", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marsabit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa , Kadjiado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wajir County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5862204", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (05): (WJ) WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5862204", "date": "2018-06-19 08:48:36", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (05): (WAJIR) WHO\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/18-june-2018-rift-valley-fever-kenya/en/\n\n\nOn 8 Jun 2018, the Ministry of Health (MoH) for Kenya confirmed an outbreak of Rift Valley fever. The 1st patient was admitted to a hospital in Wajir County in northeastern Kenya on 2 Jun [2018] with fever, body weakness, and bleeding from the gums and mouth. The patient reported having consumed meat from a sick animal; the patient died the same day. On 4 Jun [2018], 2 relatives of the index patient were admitted. Blood samples were collected and sent to the Kenya Medical Research Institute, one of which was confirmed positive for Rift Valley fever on 6 Jun [2018].\n\nAs of 16 Jun [2018], a total of 26 human cases have been reported from Wajir (24 cases) and Marsabit (2 cases) counties, including 7 confirmed cases and 6 deaths (case fatality ratio (CFR) = 23 percent); 6 patients have been discharged, while one is still hospitalized. A high number of deaths and abortions among livestock, including camels and goats, has been reported in Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, Marsabit, Tana River, and Wajir counties. People living in these counties were reportedly consuming meat from dead and sick animals.\n\nPreparedness activities for Rift Valley fever have been ongoing since February 2018 in reaction to the heavy rains and flooding in Kenya. An alert was issued to all County Directors in February 2018 and a general national alert was communicated in May 2018.\n\nThe following actions have been taken since the outbreak was confirmed:\n- On 8 Jun [2018], the MoH and Ministry of Agriculture convened an emergency meeting with the Ministry of Livestock (MoL) and key stakeholders. A health sector task force meeting was held, and partners pledged their support to Rift Valley fever control.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], the MoH activated the Emergency Operations Centre, with an Event Manager and supporting technical team.\n- On 14 Jun [2018], a multi-sectoral investigation teams was deployed in Wajir County to support the county health teams. Another team will soon be dispatched to support the Marsabit County team.\n- As part of ongoing preparedness activities, active surveillance for Rift Valley fever is being strengthened in affected and at-risk counties, as well as contact tracing in Wajir and Marsabit counties. In Wajir County, 5 treatment centres have been established.\n- Active case searching and community sensitization activities are ongoing in the affected areas. Guidelines for vector control and other informational materials have been dispatched to Wajir County, and messages are being disseminated through Community Health Volunteers.\n- A ban on slaughtering animals and restriction of livestock movement has been imposed in the affected areas.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are not uncommon in Kenya. The last documented outbreak occurred from November 2014 through January 2015 in northeastern Kenya; in 2006, a large outbreak killed more than 150 people. The CFR has varied widely in documented outbreaks, but the overall CFR tends to be less than one percent.\n\nKenya's prior experience with responding to Rift Valley fever outbreaks combined with the preparedness activities undertaken over the preceding months is of benefit. However, the high number of reported deaths and abortions in livestock is concerning, especially because the event affects nomadic communities for which diet is predominantly based on animal products. The high volume of movement of cattle and people in this area increases the risk of further spread of the outbreak both within Kenya, and to neighbouring countries.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. The majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. Herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians have an increased risk of infection. Awareness of the risk factors of Rift Valley fever infection and measures to prevent mosquito bites are the only ways to reduce human infection and deaths. Public health messages for risk reduction should focus on:\n\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission resulting from unsafe animal husbandry and slaughtering practices. Practicing hand hygiene and wearing gloves and other personal protective equipment when handling sick animals or their tissues or when slaughtering animals is recommended.\n- Reducing the risk of animal-to-human transmission arising from the unsafe consumption of raw or unpasteurized milk or animal tissue. In endemic regions, all animal products should be thoroughly cooked before eating.\n- Reducing the risk of mosquito bites through the implementation of vector control activities (e.g. insecticide spraying and using larvicide to reduce mosquito breeding sites), use of insecticide-impregnated mosquito nets and repellents, and wearing light coloured clothing (long-sleeved shirts and trousers).\n- Restricting or banning the movement of livestock to reduce spread of the virus from infected to uninfected areas.\n- Routine animal vaccination is recommended to prevent Rift Valley fever outbreaks. Vaccination campaigns are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle propagation of the virus. Outbreaks of Rift Valley fever in animals precede human cases, thus the establishment of an active animal health surveillance system is essential to providing early warning for veterinary and public health authorities.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions to the Kenya based on the current information available on this event.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kenya Ministries of Health and of Agriculture are working together in a One Health effort to reduce risk of Rift Valley fever (RVF) for humans and for animals in this outbreak. These ministries issued an alert for the risk of Rift Valley fever due to heavy rains and flooding and named 15 counties as high-risk areas (see Rift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention 20180531.5830703). The loss of camels and small ruminants has social and economic consequences for their owners. Where access to banks is limited, these animals become a store of value as well as a critical source of family income and food. It is difficult to predict how long the outbreak may last.\n\nThe rains and flooding have doubtless increased the populations of RVF virus mosquito vectors in the area. A vigorous vaccination campaign should reduce risk of infection for the animal populations. There is no commercially available vaccine for humans, so public education is the best way to influence behavior in ways to reduce risk of acquiring an infection. - Mod.TY\n\nKenya submitted its 1st follow-up report addressing RVF on 15 Jun 2018, adding the county Tana River to Wajir, where the initial RVF animal cases were identified in livestock (camels). The report, with map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26928.\n\nAccording to the WHO Relief Web report of 18 Jun 2018, the number of counties in Kenya's Eastern province, where RVF is currently affecting animals, has risen to 6, adding Garissa, Kadjiado, Kitui, and Marsabit to the list. This rapid spread of the disease in animals is in need of veterinary confirmation. As indicated in the report, vaccination campaigns in animals are not recommended during an outbreak as they may intensify transmission among the herd through needle dissemination of the virus. More on RVF control activities can be found in FAO's updated manual at http://www.fao.org/3/i8475en/I8475EN.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Kenya: https://softkenya.com/kenya/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Counties-in-Kenya.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/597]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (04): (WJ) 20180615.5858590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE 20180609.5847976\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (02): (WJ) susp 20180609.5847216\nRift valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention (NE), alert, prevention 20081114.3586\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: multiple virus lineages 20080915.2881\n.................................................mpp/ty/msp/mpp/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": "date": "2018-05-17 13:47:22", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE) LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26639\n\n\nRift Valley fever, South Africa\n-------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Apr 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 May 2018\nReport date: 16 May 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (RVF_2018_001): Letsemeng, Free State\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Apr 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: cattle, sheep, goats, and camels sera samples for active surveillance at the livestock border market.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: vectors\nEpidemiological comments: coordinates modified to protect confidentiality as required by South African screening, quarantine\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: IDEXX Laboratories (private laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nSheep / immunohistochemical test) / 16 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following comment is from a media release published by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Republic of South Africa on 16 May 2018, available at https://www.agrisa.co.za/rift-valley-fever-confirmed-in-fs/\n\n\"Rift Valley fever has been confirmed at one farm in the Jacobsdal area in the Free State. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26639\n\n\nRift Valley fever, South Africa\n-------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Apr 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 May 2018\nReport date: 16 May 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (RVF_2018_001): Letsemeng, Free State\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Apr 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: cattle, sheep, goats, and camels sera samples for active surveillance at the livestock border market.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: vectors\nEpidemiological comments: coordinates modified to protect confidentiality as required by South African Legislation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), screening, quarantine\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: IDEXX Laboratories (private laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nSheep / immunohistochemical test) / 16 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following comment is from a media release published by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Republic of South Africa on 16 May 2018, available at https://www.agrisa.co.za/rift-valley-fever-confirmed-in-fs/\n\n\"Rift Valley fever has been confirmed at one farm in the Jacobsdal area in the Free State. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5847976", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (03): (WJ) camel, human, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5847976", "date": "2018-05-17 13:47:22", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE) LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26639\n\n\nRift Valley fever, South Africa\n-------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Apr 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 May 2018\nReport date: 16 May 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (RVF_2018_001): Letsemeng, Free State\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Apr 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: cattle, sheep, goats, and camels sera samples for active surveillance at the livestock border market.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: vectors\nEpidemiological comments: coordinates modified to protect confidentiality as required by South African Legislation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), screening, quarantine\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: IDEXX Laboratories (private laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nSheep / immunohistochemical test) / 16 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following comment is from a media release published by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Republic of South Africa on 16 May 2018, available at https://www.agrisa.co.za/rift-valley-fever-confirmed-in-fs/\n\n\"Rift Valley fever has been confirmed at one farm in the Jacobsdal area in the Free State. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE) LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26639\n\n\nRift Valley fever, South Africa\n-------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Apr 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 May 2018\nReport date: 16 May 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (RVF_2018_001): Letsemeng, Free State\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Apr 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: cattle, sheep, goats, and camels sera samples for active surveillance at the livestock border market.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: vectors\nEpidemiological comments: coordinates modified to protect confidentiality as required by South African Legislation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), screening, quarantine\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: IDEXX Laboratories (private laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nSheep / immunohistochemical test) / 16 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following comment is from a media release published by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Republic of South Africa on 16 May 2018, available at https://www.agrisa.co.za/rift-valley-fever-confirmed-in-fs/\n\n\"Rift Valley fever has been confirmed at one farm in the Jacobsdal area in the Free State. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", Africa"}, {"location": "rvf_2018_001", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rift Valley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5830703", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya: alert, prevention", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5830703", "date": "2018-05-17 13:47:22", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE) LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(20) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26639\n\n\nRift Valley fever, South Africa\n-------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 28 Apr 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 May 2018\nReport date: 16 May 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 May 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (RVF_2018_001): Letsemeng, Free State\nDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Apr 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: cattle, sheep, goats, and camels sera samples for active surveillance at the livestock border market.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: vectors\nEpidemiological comments: coordinates modified to protect confidentiality as required by South African Legislation.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), screening, quarantine\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: IDEXX Laboratories (private laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nSheep / immunohistochemical test) / 16 May 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following comment is from a media release published by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Republic of South Africa on 16 May 2018, available at https://www.agrisa.co.za/rift-valley-fever-confirmed-in-fs/\n\n\"Rift Valley fever has been confirmed at one farm in the Jacobsdal area in the Free State. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nRift Valley fever - So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.\" - South Sudan (09): (EL) human, animal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5735975", "date": "2018-01-30 23:46:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (02): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-suspected-rift-valley-fever-cases-rise-20-39483/\n\n\nWith the addition of 7 suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases reported from Yirol East County, South Sudan, 20 suspect cases have been reported in the past month.\n\nOf the cases, 3 are confirmed and 3 probable cases who died and had epidemiological links to the confirmed cases.\n\nOn 28 Dec 2017, the Ministry of Health of South Sudan reported a cluster of 3 severe hemorrhagic cases, which were epidemiologically linked by place (all occurred in Thonabutkok village, Yirol East County) and time (all in December 2017). Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area also showed evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness.\n\nOn 19 Jan 2018, a joint Ministry of Health/WHO rapid response team arrived in Yirol East and have investigated the 2 most recent suspect cases, collected and shipped samples to Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI) for testing, and discussed the establishment of a mechanism for case investigation and sample collection with the State Minister of Health and partners. They also trained teams in active case finding and trained 15 local healthcare workers in RVF case management.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 7 human and 7 animal samples, 3 from humans tested serologically positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF), and one animal sample was positive. In that locality, one goat and one sheep aborted, 8 goats died, and one cow was ill (http://who.int/hac/crises/ssd/figures/south-sudan-rvf-21january2017.pdf).\n\nIn an RVF outbreak, abortions and deaths in small ruminant animals are common. People can become infected by handling abortuses, carcasses, or blood of infected animals, or by bite of infected mosquitoes. Animal handlers, butchers and veterinarians are at particular risk of infection by RVF virus.\n\nThere have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of several reference laboratories, the etiological agent of that South Sudan hemorrhagic fever outbreak was not determined. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). In 1999, an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease in humans occurred in the southern part of Sudan due to infections with the bacterium _Borrelia recurrentis_, the cause of louse-borne relapsing fever.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53091. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan: (EL) fatal 20180109.5545676\n2016\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (05): new comment 20160707.4332000\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (04): addtl comment 20160704.4324160\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (03): comment 20160702.4322974\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan 20160519.4233420\n2015\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (07): (Darfur) comment 20151208.3849227\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (03): (SF) displaced persons, RFI 20141101.2921031\n.................................................sb/mpp//ml/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5683274", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Sudan (08): (EL) animal, human, WHO, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5683274", "date": "2018-01-30 23:46:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (02): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-suspected-rift-valley-fever-cases-rise-20-39483/\n\n\nWith the addition of 7 suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases reported from Yirol East County, South Sudan, 20 suspect cases have been reported in the past month.\n\nOf the cases, 3 are confirmed and 3 probable cases who died and had epidemiological links to the confirmed cases.\n\nOn 28 Dec 2017, the Ministry of Health of South Sudan reported a cluster of 3 severe hemorrhagic cases, which were epidemiologically linked by place (all occurred in Thonabutkok village, Yirol East County) and time (all in December 2017). Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area also showed evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness.\n\nOn 19 Jan 2018, a joint Ministry of Health/WHO rapid response team arrived in Yirol East and have investigated the 2 most recent suspect cases, collected and shipped samples to Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI) for testing, and discussed the establishment of a mechanism for case investigation and sample collection with the State Minister of Health and partners. They also trained teams in active case finding and trained 15 local healthcare workers in RVF case management.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 7 human and 7 animal samples, 3 from humans tested serologically positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF), and one animal sample was positive. In that locality, one goat and one sheep aborted, 8 goats died, and one cow was ill (http://who.int/hac/crises/ssd/figures/south-sudan-rvf-21january2017.pdf).\n\nIn an RVF outbreak, abortions and deaths in small ruminant animals are common. People can become infected by handling abortuses, carcasses, or blood of infected animals, or by bite of infected mosquitoes. Animal handlers, butchers and veterinarians are at particular risk of infection by RVF virus.\n\nThere have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of several reference laboratories, the etiological agent of that South Sudan hemorrhagic fever outbreak was not determined. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). In 1999, an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease in humans occurred in the southern part of Sudan due to infections with the bacterium _Borrelia recurrentis_, the cause of louse-borne relapsing fever.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53091. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan: (EL) fatal 20180109.5545676\n2016\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (05): new comment 20160707.4332000\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (04): addtl comment 20160704.4324160\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (03): comment 20160702.4322974\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness -
