Sudan (03): (SF) displaced persons, RFI 20141101.2921031\n.................................................sb/mpp//ml/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5682186", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Sudan (07): (EL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5682186", "date": "2018-01-30 23:46:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (02): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-suspected-rift-valley-fever-cases-rise-20-39483/\n\n\nWith the addition of 7 suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases reported from Yirol East County, South Sudan, 20 suspect cases have been reported in the past month.\n\nOf the cases, 3 are confirmed and 3 probable cases who died and had epidemiological links to the confirmed cases.\n\nOn 28 Dec 2017, the Ministry of Health of South Sudan reported a cluster of 3 severe hemorrhagic cases, which were epidemiologically linked by place (all occurred in Thonabutkok village, Yirol East County) and time (all in December 2017). Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area also showed evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness.\n\nOn 19 Jan 2018, a joint Ministry of Health/WHO rapid response team arrived in Yirol East and have investigated the 2 most recent suspect cases, collected and shipped samples to Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI) for testing, and discussed the establishment of a mechanism for case investigation and sample collection with the State Minister of Health and partners. They also trained teams in active case finding and trained 15 local healthcare workers in RVF case management.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 7 human and 7 animal samples, 3 from humans tested serologically positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF), and one animal sample was positive. In that locality, one goat and one sheep aborted, 8 goats died, and one cow was ill (http://who.int/hac/crises/ssd/figures/south-sudan-rvf-21january2017.pdf).\n\nIn an RVF outbreak, abortions and deaths in small ruminant animals are common. People can become infected by handling abortuses, carcasses, or blood of infected animals, or by bite of infected mosquitoes. Animal handlers, butchers and veterinarians are at particular risk of infection by RVF virus.\n\nThere have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of several reference laboratories, the etiological agent of that South Sudan hemorrhagic fever outbreak was not determined. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). In 1999, an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease in humans occurred in the southern part of Sudan due to infections with the bacterium _Borrelia recurrentis_, the cause of louse-borne relapsing fever.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53091. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan: (EL) fatal 20180109.5545676\n2016\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (05): new comment 20160707.4332000\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (04): addtl comment 20160704.4324160\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (03): comment 20160702.4322974\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan 20160519.4233420\n2015\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (07): (Darfur) comment 20151208.3849227\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (06): (Darfur) RFI 20151207.3844646\nUndiagnosed outbreak - Sudan (05): (ND) fever, rash, refugee camp, children, RFI 20151110.3780916\n2014\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (07): (ND, SK) dengue susp, RFI 20141201.3001675\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (03): (SF) displaced persons, RFI 20141101.2921031\n.................................................sb/mpp//ml/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5678018", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Sudan (06): (EL) livestock, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5678018", "date": "2018-01-30 23:46:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (02): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-suspected-rift-valley-fever-cases-rise-20-39483/\n\n\nWith the addition of 7 suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases reported from Yirol East County, South Sudan, 20 suspect cases have been reported in the past month.\n\nOf the cases, 3 are confirmed and 3 probable cases who died and had epidemiological links to the confirmed cases.\n\nOn 28 Dec 2017, the Ministry of Health of South Sudan reported a cluster of 3 severe hemorrhagic cases, which were epidemiologically linked by place (all occurred in Thonabutkok village, Yirol East County) and time (all in December 2017). Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area also showed evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness.\n\nOn 19 Jan 2018, a joint Ministry of Health/WHO rapid response team arrived in Yirol East and have investigated the 2 most recent suspect cases, collected and shipped samples to Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI) for testing, and discussed the establishment of a mechanism for case investigation and sample collection with the State Minister of Health and partners. They also trained teams in active case finding and trained 15 local healthcare workers in RVF case management.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 7 human and 7 animal samples, 3 from humans tested serologically positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF), and one animal sample was positive. In that locality, one goat and one sheep aborted, 8 goats died, and one cow was ill (http://who.int/hac/crises/ssd/figures/south-sudan-rvf-21january2017.pdf).\n\nIn an RVF outbreak, abortions and deaths in small ruminant animals are common. People can become infected by handling abortuses, carcasses, or blood of infected animals, or by bite of infected mosquitoes. Animal handlers, butchers and veterinarians are at particular risk of infection by RVF virus.\n\nThere have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of several reference laboratories, the etiological agent of that South Sudan hemorrhagic fever outbreak was not determined. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). In 1999, an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease in humans occurred in the southern part of Sudan due to infections with the bacterium _Borrelia recurrentis_, the cause of louse-borne relapsing fever.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53091. - Sudan (03): (SF) displaced persons, RFI 20141101.2921031\n.................................................sb/mpp//ml/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5595636", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Sudan (02): (EL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5595636", "date": "2018-01-30 23:46:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (02): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-suspected-rift-valley-fever-cases-rise-20-39483/\n\n\nWith the addition of 7 suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases reported from Yirol East County, South Sudan, 20 suspect cases have been reported in the past month.\n\nOf the cases, 3 are confirmed and 3 probable cases who died and had epidemiological links to the confirmed cases.\n\nOn 28 Dec 2017, the Ministry of Health of South Sudan reported a cluster of 3 severe hemorrhagic cases, which were epidemiologically linked by place (all occurred in Thonabutkok village, Yirol East County) and time (all in December 2017). Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area also showed evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness.\n\nOn 19 Jan 2018, a joint Ministry of Health/WHO rapid response team arrived in Yirol East and have investigated the 2 most recent suspect cases, collected and shipped samples to Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI) for testing, and discussed the establishment of a mechanism for case investigation and sample collection with the State Minister of Health and partners. They also trained teams in active case finding and trained 15 local healthcare workers in RVF case management.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 7 human and 7 animal samples, 3 from humans tested serologically positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF), and one animal sample was positive. In that locality, one goat and one sheep aborted, 8 goats died, and one cow was ill (http://who.int/hac/crises/ssd/figures/south-sudan-rvf-21january2017.pdf).\n\nIn an RVF outbreak, abortions and deaths in small ruminant animals are common. People can become infected by handling abortuses, carcasses, or blood of infected animals, or by bite of infected mosquitoes. Animal handlers, butchers and veterinarians are at particular risk of infection by RVF virus.\n\nThere have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of several reference laboratories, the etiological agent of that South Sudan hemorrhagic fever outbreak was not determined. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). In 1999, an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease in humans occurred in the southern part of Sudan due to infections with the bacterium _Borrelia recurrentis_, the cause of louse-borne relapsing fever.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53091. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EB) WHO, susp, RFI 20180119.5568536\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan: (EL) fatal 20180109.5545676\n2016\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (05): new comment 20160707.4332000\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (04): addtl comment 20160704.4324160\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (03): comment 20160702.4322974\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan 20160519.4233420\n2015\n----\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (07): (Darfur) comment 20151208.3849227\nUndiagnosed hemorrhagic fever - Sudan (03): (SF) displaced persons, RFI 20141101.2921031\n.................................................sb/mpp//ml/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5582524", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Gambia: (BJ) WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5582524", "date": "2017-07-21 21:34:54", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MALI (02): (KOULIKORO)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 July 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/rift-valley-fever-case-reported-mali-82063/\n\n\nHealth officials in the west African country of Mali confirmed a single case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus infection in a 10-year-old boy from Oulessebougou.\n\nThis case was identified through laboratory investigations into 3 suspected yellow fever cases. All 3 samples tested negative for all arboviruses included on the molecular panel, namely: dengue, West Nile, RVF, chikungunya, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and Ebola. However, one sample was anti-RVF virus IgM positive on serology testing by ELISA.\n\nEarlier this month [July 2017], the district rapid response team was deployed to the affected village to conduct outbreak investigation. The team observed that the affected village is served by a large diameter well, with shepherds in seasonal movement with their livestock living nearby and regularly visiting the village.\n\nScore of samples were taken from villagers and domestic animals. Test results are pending.\n\nThe World Health Organization says the occurrence of a sporadic case of RVF in a village in Mali is not surprising.\n\nDuring August-November 2016, communities in the Tahoua Region, Niger (on the border with Mali) experienced an outbreak of RVF. And in January this year [2017], OIE confirmed RVF virus as the cause of abortions in sheep and goats across the border in Menaka, Mali (some 1700 km [1056 mi] from the abovementioned outbreaks).\n\nNevertheless, the detection of even a single case warrants an immediate emergency response, as such cases are often an early indication of widespread infection in livestock populations, associated with abortions with devastating economic impacts. Though the disease in humans is often subclinical or mild, 8 to 10 percent of cases develop severe symptoms, including ocular disease, encephalitis and/or haemorrhagic fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is endemic in may sub-Saharan countries, including Mali. Cases occur sporadically in livestock and in humans. Mod.AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised [in some domestic animals] by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n\"Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n\"RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n\"Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n\"Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n\"During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n\"The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.\"\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has received relatively few reports of RVF in Mali, there have been cases reported this year (2017) in neighboring Mauritania and Niger.\n\nOulessebougou is located 80 km (50 mi) south of Bamako in southwestern Mali. A political map of Mali can be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/mali_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29544. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 20170605.5085590\nRift Valley fever - Niger: livestock, human, risk assessment, FAO 20170404.4947846\nRift Valley fever - Mali: (GO) ovine, caprine, OIE 20170128.4799130\n2016\n----\nRift Valley fever - France ex Mali, 2015 20160506.4207036\n.................................................sb/jh/ty/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1056-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oulessebougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5582417", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Uganda", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5465725", "date": "2017-07-21 21:34:54", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MALI (02): (KOULIKORO)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 July 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/rift-valley-fever-case-reported-mali-82063/\n\n\nHealth officials in the west African country of Mali confirmed a single case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus infection in a 10-year-old boy from Oulessebougou.\n\nThis case was identified through laboratory investigations into 3 suspected yellow fever cases. All 3 samples tested negative for all arboviruses included on the molecular panel, namely: dengue, West Nile, RVF, chikungunya, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and Ebola. However, one sample was anti-RVF virus IgM positive on serology testing by ELISA.\n\nEarlier this month [July 2017], the district rapid response team was deployed to the affected village to conduct outbreak investigation. The team observed that the affected village is served by a large diameter well, with shepherds in seasonal movement with their livestock living nearby and regularly visiting the village.\n\nScore of samples were taken from villagers and domestic animals. Test results are pending.\n\nThe World Health Organization says the occurrence of a sporadic case of RVF in a village in Mali is not surprising.\n\nDuring August-November 2016, communities in the Tahoua Region, Niger (on the border with Mali) experienced an outbreak of RVF. And in January this year [2017], OIE confirmed RVF virus as the cause of abortions in sheep and goats across the border in Menaka, Mali (some 1700 km [1056 mi] from the abovementioned outbreaks).\n\nNevertheless, the detection of even a single case warrants an immediate emergency response, as such cases are often an early indication of widespread infection in livestock populations, associated with abortions with devastating economic impacts. Though the disease in humans is often subclinical or mild, 8 to 10 percent of cases develop severe symptoms, including ocular disease, encephalitis and/or haemorrhagic fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is endemic in may sub-Saharan countries, including Mali. Cases occur sporadically in livestock and in humans. Mod.AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised [in some domestic animals] by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n\"Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n\"RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n\"Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n\"Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n\"During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n\"The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.\"\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has received relatively few reports of RVF in Mali, there have been cases reported this year (2017) in neighboring Mauritania and Niger.\n\nOulessebougou is located 80 km (50 mi) south of Bamako in southwestern Mali. A political map of Mali can be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/mali_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29544. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 20170605.5085590\nRift Valley fever - Niger: livestock, human, risk assessment, FAO 20170404.4947846\nRift Valley fever - Mali: (GO) ovine, caprine, OIE 20170128.4799130\n2016\n----\nRift Valley fever - France ex Mali, 2015 20160506.4207036\n.................................................sb/jh/ty/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1056-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oulessebougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5363727", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Turkey: animals, serosurveillance, 1st report, 2000-2006", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5363727", "date": "2017-07-21 21:34:54", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MALI (02): (KOULIKORO)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 July 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/rift-valley-fever-case-reported-mali-82063/\n\n\nHealth officials in the west African country of Mali confirmed a single case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus infection in a 10-year-old boy from Oulessebougou.\n\nThis case was identified through laboratory investigations into 3 suspected yellow fever cases. All 3 samples tested negative for all arboviruses included on the molecular panel, namely: dengue, West Nile, RVF, chikungunya, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and Ebola. However, one sample was anti-RVF virus IgM positive on serology testing by ELISA.\n\nEarlier this month [July 2017], the district rapid response team was deployed to the affected village to conduct outbreak investigation. The team observed that the affected village is served by a large diameter well, with shepherds in seasonal movement with their livestock living nearby and regularly visiting the village.\n\nScore of samples were taken from villagers and domestic animals. Test results are pending.\n\nThe World Health Organization says the occurrence of a sporadic case of RVF in a village in Mali is not surprising.\n\nDuring August-November 2016, communities in the Tahoua Region, Niger (on the border with Mali) experienced an outbreak of RVF. And in January this year [2017], OIE confirmed RVF virus as the cause of abortions in sheep and goats across the border in Menaka, Mali (some 1700 km [1056 mi] from the abovementioned outbreaks).\n\nNevertheless, the detection of even a single case warrants an immediate emergency response, as such cases are often an early indication of widespread infection in livestock populations, associated with abortions with devastating economic impacts. Though the disease in humans is often subclinical or mild, 8 to 10 percent of cases develop severe symptoms, including ocular disease, encephalitis and/or haemorrhagic fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is endemic in may sub-Saharan countries, including Mali. Cases occur sporadically in livestock and in humans. Mod.AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised [in some domestic animals] by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n\"Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n\"RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n\"Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n\"Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n\"During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n\"The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.\"\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has received relatively few reports of RVF in Mali, there have been cases reported this year (2017) in neighboring Mauritania and Niger.\n\nOulessebougou is located 80 km (50 mi) south of Bamako in southwestern Mali. A political map of Mali can be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/mali_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29544. - All 3 samples tested negative for all arboviruses included on the molecular panel, namely: dengue, West Nile, RVF, chikungunya, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and Ebola. However, one sample was anti-RVF virus IgM positive on serology testing by ELISA.\n\nEarlier this month [July 2017], the district rapid response team was deployed to the affected village to conduct outbreak investigation. The team observed that the affected village is served by a large diameter well, with shepherds in seasonal movement with their livestock living nearby and regularly visiting the village.\n\nScore of samples were taken from villagers and domestic animals. Test results are pending.\n\nThe World Health Organization says the occurrence of a sporadic case of RVF in a village in Mali is not surprising.\n\nDuring August-November 2016, communities in the Tahoua Region, Niger (on the border with Mali) experienced an outbreak of RVF. And in January this year [2017], OIE confirmed RVF virus as the cause of abortions in sheep and goats across the border in Menaka, Mali (some 1700 km [1056 mi] from the abovementioned outbreaks).\n\nNevertheless, the detection of even a single case warrants an immediate emergency response, as such cases are often an early indication of widespread infection in livestock populations, associated with abortions with devastating economic impacts. Though the disease in humans is often subclinical or mild, 8 to 10 percent of cases develop severe symptoms, including ocular disease, encephalitis and/or haemorrhagic fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is endemic in may sub-Saharan countries, including Mali. Cases occur sporadically in livestock and in humans. Mod.AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised [in some domestic animals] by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n\"Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n\"RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n\"Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n\"Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n\"During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n\"The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.\"\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has received relatively few reports of RVF in Mali, there have been cases reported this year (2017) in neighboring Mauritania and Niger.\n\nOulessebougou is located 80 km (50 mi) south of Bamako in southwestern Mali. A political map of Mali can be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/mali_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29544. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 20170605.5085590\nRift Valley fever - Niger: livestock, human, risk assessment, FAO 20170404.4947846\nRift Valley fever - Mali: (GO) ovine, caprine, OIE 20170128.4799130\n2016\n----\nRift Valley fever - France ex Mali, 2015 20160506.4207036\n.................................................sb/jh/ty/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "influenza-like illness", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1056-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oulessebougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5085590", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mauritania: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5085590", "date": "2016-09-29 17:41:35", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (03): (TAHOUA) LIVESTOCK, HUMAN\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies Preparedness, Response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-september-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nOn 30 Aug 2016, WHO received reports about unexplained deaths among humans, along with death and abortion in livestock in the North Western parts of Niger, and the areas bordering Mali.\n\nFrom 2 Aug to 22 Sep 2016, 64 human cases including 23 deaths have been reported in Tchintabaraden health district in Tahoua region. The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. Ministries of Health and Agriculture/Livestock have developed a national response plan.\n\nThe WHO Country Office continues to provide technical and financial support for surveillance, outbreak investigation, technical guidelines regarding case definition, case management, shipment of samples and risk communication.\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. The above report clarifies the case number and provides valuable social and economic elements important in this outbreak. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.\"\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Niger (02): (TH) livestock, human 20160922.4506785\nRift Valley fever - Niger: (TH) livestock, OIE 20160920.4501514\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (04): (KA) 20160613.4283794\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (03): (KA) caprine, OIE 20160401.4133260\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (02): (KA) 20160317.4099896\nRift Valley fever - Uganda: (KA) 20160313.4090478\n2015\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania (03): ovine, caprine, OIE 20151107.3774473\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (02) 20151026.3744543\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: (TG) 20151007.3694282\n2014\n----\nRift Valley fever - Botswana: (CH) bovine, OIE 20140727.2638358\nRift Valley fever - Senegal: (DK) bovine, OIE, 20140318.2341029\n2013\n----\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\nRift Valley Fever, Sheep, goat and Camelidae - Mauritania, Senegal: OIE 20131018.2008030\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n.................................................mpp/dk/ty/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-08-30 00:00:00", "2016-09-22 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sanitaire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dorcas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tchintabaraden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tahoua", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4947846", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Niger: livestock, human, risk assessment, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4947846", "date": "2016-09-29 17:41:35", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (03): (TAHOUA) LIVESTOCK, HUMAN\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies Preparedness, Response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-september-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nOn 30 Aug 2016, WHO received reports about unexplained deaths among humans, along with death and abortion in livestock in the North Western parts of Niger, and the areas bordering Mali.\n\nFrom 2 Aug to 22 Sep 2016, 64 human cases including 23 deaths have been reported in Tchintabaraden health district in Tahoua region. The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. Ministries of Health and Agriculture/Livestock have developed a national response plan.\n\nThe WHO Country Office continues to provide technical and financial support for surveillance, outbreak investigation, technical guidelines regarding case definition, case management, shipment of samples and risk communication.\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. The above report clarifies the case number and provides valuable social and economic elements important in this outbreak. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.\"\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. Niger (06): (TH) WHO, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4666462", "date": "2016-09-29 17:41:35", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (03): (TAHOUA) LIVESTOCK, HUMAN\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies Preparedness, Response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-september-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nOn 30 Aug 2016, WHO received reports about unexplained deaths among humans, along with death and abortion in livestock in the North Western parts of Niger, and the areas bordering Mali.\n\nFrom 2 Aug to 22 Sep 2016, 64 human cases including 23 deaths have been reported in Tchintabaraden health district in Tahoua region. The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. Ministries of Health and Agriculture/Livestock have developed a national response plan.\n\nThe WHO Country Office continues to provide technical and financial support for surveillance, outbreak investigation, technical guidelines regarding case definition, case management, shipment of samples and risk communication.\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. The above report clarifies the case number and provides valuable social and economic elements important in this outbreak. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.\"\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Niger (02): (TH) livestock, human 20160922.4506785\nRift Valley fever - Niger: (TH) livestock, OIE 20160920.4501514\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (04): (KA) 20160613.4283794\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (03): (KA) caprine, OIE 20160401.4133260\nRift Valley fever - Uganda (02): (KA) 20160317.4099896\nRift Valley fever - Uganda: (KA) 20160313.4090478\n2015\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania (03): ovine, caprine, OIE 20151107.3774473\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (02) 20151026.3744543\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: (TG) 20151007.3694282\n2014\n----\nRift Valley fever - Botswana: (CH) bovine, OIE 20140727.2638358\nRift Valley fever - Senegal: (DK) bovine, OIE, 20140318.2341029\n2013\n----\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\nRift Valley Fever, Sheep, goat and Camelidae - Mauritania, Senegal: OIE 20131018.2008030\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n.................................................mpp/dk/ty/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-08-30 00:00:00", "2016-09-22 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sanitaire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dorcas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tchintabaraden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tahoua", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4643103", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Niger (05): (TH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4643103", "date": "2016-09-29 17:41:35", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (03): (TAHOUA) LIVESTOCK, HUMAN\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies Preparedness, Response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-september-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nOn 30 Aug 2016, WHO received reports about unexplained deaths among humans, along with death and abortion in livestock in the North Western parts of Niger, and the areas bordering Mali.\n\nFrom 2 Aug to 22 Sep 2016, 64 human cases including 23 deaths have been reported in Tchintabaraden health district in Tahoua region. The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. Ministries of Health and Agriculture/Livestock have developed a national response plan.\n\nThe WHO Country Office continues to provide technical and financial support for surveillance, outbreak investigation, technical guidelines regarding case definition, case management, shipment of samples and risk communication.\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. The above report clarifies the case number and provides valuable social and economic elements important in this outbreak. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.\"\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, \"Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants.
