vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nNo other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Centre (CNERV) (National laboratory)/ Sheep, goats / IgM-capture ELISA / 15 Oct 2013 / Positive\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory (LNERV) - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (Dakar) (Regional Reference Laboratory)/ Camelidae/ seroneutralization test (SNT)/ 14 Oct 2013 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\nSenegal\n-------\nDuring September 2013, Senegal reported the reoccurrence of the disease to the OIE (ProMED archive number 20130924.1964250). Two new outbreaks were reported in the latest follow-up report (10 Oct 2013). These outbreaks were situated in the Saint Louis region, and the total number of affected animals were 208 goats (37 cases, 8 deaths). The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n\n2012\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (05): WHO fatalities 20121005.1326899\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: human, susp, RFI 20121002.1318661\n\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Two new outbreaks were reported in the latest follow-up report (10 Oct 2013). These outbreaks were situated in the Saint Louis region, and the total number of affected animals were 208 goats (37 cases, 8 deaths). The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n\n2012\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (05): WHO 20121102.1387490\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (04): (NT) alert 20121024.1362610\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (03): vector species 20121008.1331095\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (02): fatalities 20121005.1326899\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: human, susp, RFI 20121002.1318661\n\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n.................................................crd/arn/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-16 00:00:00", "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint Louis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3744543", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mauritania (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3744543", "date": "2013-10-18 23:46:13", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, SHEEP, GOAT AND CAMELIDAE - MAURITANIA, SENEGAL: OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14258\n\nRift Valley Fever, Mauritania\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 17 Oct 2013 from Dr Lemrabott Nemine, Directeur de l Elevage, Direction de l elevage, Ministere du Developpement Rural, Nouakchott, Mauritania\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Oct 2013\nReport date: 17 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 17 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: October 2012\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: CHGARA, CHGARA, ROSSO, ROSSO\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Sep 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 150 / 30 / 0 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 2: PK 60, PK60, MEDERDRA, MEDERDRA\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 3: TADRESSA, TADRESSA, MAGTA LAHJAR, MAGTA-LAHJAR\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: KADJEL ABOU, KADJEL ABOU, BABABE, BABABE\nDate of start of the outbreak: 10 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 350 / 120 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 500 / 150 / 0 / 0 / 0\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep, goats / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\nCamelidae / 11 percent / 3 percent / 27.27 percent / 3 percent\nSheep / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:\nVectors\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nControl of arthropods\nMovement control inside the country\nNo vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nNo other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Centre (CNERV) (National laboratory)/ Sheep, goats / IgM-capture ELISA / 15 Oct 2013 / Positive\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory (LNERV) - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (Dakar) (Regional Reference Laboratory)/ Camelidae/ seroneutralization test (SNT)/ 14 Oct 2013 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\nSenegal\n-------\nDuring September 2013, Senegal reported the reoccurrence of the disease to the OIE (ProMED archive number 20130924.1964250). Two new outbreaks were reported in the latest follow-up report (10 Oct 2013). These outbreaks were situated in the Saint Louis region, and the total number of affected animals were 208 goats (37 cases, 8 deaths). The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n\n2012\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (05): WHO fatalities 20121005.1326899\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: human, susp, RFI 20121002.1318661\n\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: ["other", "rift valley fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2638358", "date": "2013-10-18 23:46:13", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, SHEEP, GOAT AND CAMELIDAE - MAURITANIA, SENEGAL: OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14258\n\nRift Valley Fever, Mauritania\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 17 Oct 2013 from Dr Lemrabott Nemine, Directeur de l Elevage, Direction de l elevage, Ministere du Developpement Rural, Nouakchott, Mauritania\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Oct 2013\nReport date: 17 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 17 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: October 2012\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: CHGARA, CHGARA, ROSSO, ROSSO\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Sep 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 150 / 30 / 0 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 2: PK 60, PK60, MEDERDRA, MEDERDRA\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 3: TADRESSA, TADRESSA, MAGTA LAHJAR, MAGTA-LAHJAR\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: KADJEL ABOU, KADJEL ABOU, BABABE, BABABE\nDate of start of the outbreak: 10 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 350 / 120 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 500 / 150 / 0 / 0 / 0\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep, goats / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\nCamelidae / 11 percent / 3 percent / 27.27 percent / 3 percent\nSheep / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:\nVectors\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nControl of arthropods\nMovement control inside the country\nNo vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nNo other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Centre (CNERV) (National laboratory)/ Sheep, goats / IgM-capture ELISA / 15 Oct 2013 / Positive\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory (LNERV) - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (Dakar) (Regional Reference Laboratory)/ Camelidae/ seroneutralization test (SNT)/ 14 Oct 2013 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\nSenegal\n-------\nDuring September 2013, Senegal reported the reoccurrence of the disease to the OIE (ProMED archive number 20130924.1964250). Two new outbreaks were reported in the latest follow-up report (10 Oct 2013). These outbreaks were situated in the Saint Louis region, and the total number of affected animals were 208 goats (37 cases, 8 deaths). The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n\n2012\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (05): WHO fatalities 20121005.1326899\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: human, susp, RFI 20121002.1318661\n\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14258\n\nRift Valley Fever, Mauritania\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 17 Oct 2013 from Dr Lemrabott Nemine, Directeur de l Elevage, Direction de l elevage, Ministere du Developpement Rural, Nouakchott, Mauritania\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 17 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Oct 2013\nReport date: 17 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 17 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: October 2012\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: CHGARA, CHGARA, ROSSO, ROSSO\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Sep 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 150 / 30 / 0 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 2: PK 60, PK60, MEDERDRA, MEDERDRA\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak 3: TADRESSA, TADRESSA, MAGTA LAHJAR, MAGTA-LAHJAR\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: KADJEL ABOU, KADJEL ABOU, BABABE, BABABE\nDate of start of the outbreak: 10 Oct 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 350 / 120 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nSheep, goats / 500 / 150 / 0 / 0 / 0\nCamelidae / 100 / 11 / 3 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 300 / 90 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep, goats / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\nCamelidae / 11 percent / 3 percent / 27.27 percent / 3 percent\nSheep / 30 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection:\nVectors\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nControl of arthropods\nMovement control inside the country\nNo vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nNo other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Centre (CNERV) (National laboratory)/ Sheep, goats / IgM-capture ELISA / 15 Oct 2013 / Positive\nNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory (LNERV) - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (Dakar) (Regional Reference Laboratory)/ Camelidae/ seroneutralization test (SNT)/ 14 Oct 2013 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\nSenegal\n-------\nDuring September 2013, Senegal reported the reoccurrence of the disease to the OIE (ProMED archive number 20130924.1964250). Two new outbreaks were reported in the latest follow-up report (10 Oct 2013). These outbreaks were situated in the Saint Louis region, and the total number of affected animals were 208 goats (37 cases, 8 deaths). The complete details on these latest outbreaks in Senegal are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14211\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. RVF is a serious disease in small ruminants, mortality - especially in lambs and, to a somewhat lower rate in kids, is known to be common. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current \"Outbreak Bulletin\" provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - Mod CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt.]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Dorcas gazelle - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE 20130924.1964250\n\n2012\n----\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (05): WHO 20121102.1387490\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (04): (NT) alert 20121024.1362610\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (03): vector species 20121008.1331095\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania (02): fatalities 20121005.1326899\nRift Valley fever - Mauritania: human, susp, RFI 20121002.1318661\n\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n.................................................crd/arn/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 \"Rift Valley Fever\" at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n.................................................crd/arn/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-28 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-10-16 00:00:00", "1120-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-10-30 00:00:00", "2012-12-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nouakchott", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dorcas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phlebovirus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint Louis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2007467", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Sudan: (EE, UN) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2007467", "date": "2011-11-29 21:06:58", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, HUMAN - FRANCE (02): ex ZIMBABWE (MASHONALAND EAST)\nNOT\n**************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 29 Nov 2011\nFrom: Marc Grandadam [edited]\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\n\n\nRift Valley Fever, France ex Zimbabwe: not confirmed\n----------------------------------------------------\nOn Thu 20 Oct 2011, a case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) imported into\nFrance from Zimbabwe was reported by ProMED-mail (Rift Valley fever,\nhuman - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st Archive Number: 20111020.3132).\nAs reporting of RVF is mandatory in France, the patient's samples were\nsent to the National Reference Laboratory for Arboviruses for\nconfirmation.\n\nThe 1st serum, obtained at day 25 after symptom onset was\nreinvestigated for the presence of anti-arbovirus antibodies (i.e.,\nDengue; Chikungunya; West Nile; Rift Valley fever). Only a borderline\nIgM reactivity against RVF virus antigen was detected. A 2nd sample\nobtained at day 67 after onset was found negative for both IgM and IgG\nfor all antigens tested. The lack of enhancement of IgM response and\nno IgG seroconversion led us to conclude that the transient IgM\nresponse in the initial sample was a non-specific reaction.\nConsequently RVF infection has been classifies as 'not confirmed.'\n\nDiagnosis of imported cases has proven to be valuable for the global\nsurveillance of arboviruses. Thus, clinicians should be aware that\npathologies (case definition; diagnostic procedures including\ninterpretation criteria), especially where mandatory reporting at the\nnational or the international levels, is required.\n\n--\nDr Marc Grandadam\nNational Reference Centre for Arboviruses\nInstitut Pasteur\nParis\nFrance\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\nand\nDr Deny Malvy\nService de Medicine Tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Grandadam and Malvy for providing this\ninformation and correcting the record. - Mod.CP\n]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, human - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st\n20111020.3132\n2010\n---\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania 20101202.4332\nRift Valley fever, human - Namibia (05): susp 20100906.3199\n2009\n---\nRift Valley fever, ovine, human - South Africa: (MP) 20090920.3297\n2008\n---\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03): (AS), human, not 20081222.4024\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Madagascar 20080419.1399\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Comoros (02) 20071203.3902\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Comoros, RFI 20071129.3855\nRift valley fever, human - Kenya: RFI 20070921.3144\n2003\n---\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Senegal: (SL) 1st report, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1964250", "date": "2011-11-29 21:06:58", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, HUMAN - FRANCE (02): ex ZIMBABWE (MASHONALAND EAST)\nNOT\n**************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 29 Nov 2011\nFrom: Marc Grandadam [edited]\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\n\n\nRift Valley Fever, France ex Zimbabwe: not confirmed\n----------------------------------------------------\nOn Thu 20 Oct 2011, a case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) imported into\nFrance from Zimbabwe was reported by ProMED-mail (Rift Valley fever,\nhuman - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st Archive Number: 20111020.3132).\nAs reporting of RVF is mandatory in France, the patient's samples were\nsent to the National Reference Laboratory for Arboviruses for\nconfirmation.\n\nThe 1st serum, obtained at day 25 after symptom onset was\nreinvestigated for the presence of anti-arbovirus antibodies (i.e.,\nDengue; Chikungunya; West Nile; Rift Valley fever). Only a borderline\nIgM reactivity against RVF virus antigen was detected. A 2nd sample\nobtained at day 67 after onset was found negative for both IgM and IgG\nfor all antigens tested. The lack of enhancement of IgM response and\nno IgG seroconversion led us to conclude that the transient IgM\nresponse in the initial sample was a non-specific reaction.\nConsequently RVF infection has been classifies as 'not confirmed.'\n\nDiagnosis of imported cases has proven to be valuable for the global\nsurveillance of arboviruses. Thus, clinicians should be aware that\npathologies (case definition; diagnostic procedures including\ninterpretation criteria), especially where mandatory reporting at the\nnational or the international levels, is required.\n\n--\nDr Marc Grandadam\nNational Reference Centre for Arboviruses\nInstitut Pasteur\nParis\nFrance\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\nand\nDr Deny Malvy\nService de Medicine Tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Grandadam and Malvy for providing this\ninformation and correcting the record. - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st Archive Number: 20111020.3132).\nAs reporting of RVF is mandatory in France, the patient's samples were\nsent to the National Reference Laboratory for Arboviruses for\nconfirmation.\n\nThe 1st serum, obtained at day 25 after symptom onset was\nreinvestigated for the presence of anti-arbovirus antibodies (i.e.,\nDengue; Chikungunya; West Nile; Rift Valley fever). Only a borderline\nIgM reactivity against RVF virus antigen was detected. A 2nd sample\nobtained at day 67 after onset was found negative for both IgM and IgG\nfor all antigens tested. The lack of enhancement of IgM response and\nno IgG seroconversion led us to conclude that the transient IgM\nresponse in the initial sample was a non-specific reaction.\nConsequently RVF infection has been classifies as 'not confirmed.'\n\nDiagnosis of imported cases has proven to be valuable for the global\nsurveillance of arboviruses. Thus, clinicians should be aware that\npathologies (case definition; diagnostic procedures including\ninterpretation criteria), especially where mandatory reporting at the\nnational or the international levels, is required.\n\n--\nDr Marc Grandadam\nNational Reference Centre for Arboviruses\nInstitut Pasteur\nParis\nFrance\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\nand\nDr Deny Malvy\nService de Medicine Tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Grandadam and Malvy for providing this\ninformation and correcting the record. - Mod.CP\n]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, human - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st\n20111020.3132\n2010\n---\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania 20101202.4332\nRift Valley fever, human - Namibia (05): susp 20100906.3199\n2009\n---\nRift Valley fever, ovine, human - South Africa: (MP) 20090920.3297\n2008\n---\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03): (AS), human, not 20081222.4024\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Madagascar 20080419.1399\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Comoros (02) 20071203.3902\nRift Valley fever, human, bovine - Comoros, RFI 20071129.3855\nRift valley fever, human - Kenya: RFI 20070921.3144\n2003\n---\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n---\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n.................................................cp/ejp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-10-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ZIMBABWE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "916603", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, human - France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=916603", "date": "2010-12-02 19:00:05", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, LIVESTOCK, HUMAN - MAURITANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Dec 2010\nSource: Romandie, Agence France-Press report [in French, trans.\nCorr.SB, edited]\n<http://www.romandie.com/infos/news2/101202124936.qrdv24sl.asp>\n\n\nAn outbreak of Rift Valley [fever] has erupted in the Mauritanian\ntown of Aoujeft (North), causing loss of life amongst people and\ncattle, Mauritanian officials said Thursday [2 Dec 2010]. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n\"Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,\" stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
