You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "641114", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE livestock, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=641114", "date": "2010-12-02 19:00:05", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, LIVESTOCK, HUMAN - MAURITANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Dec 2010\nSource: Romandie, Agence France-Press report [in French, trans.\nCorr.SB, edited]\n<http://www.romandie.com/infos/news2/101202124936.qrdv24sl.asp>\n\n\nAn outbreak of Rift Valley [fever] has erupted in the Mauritanian\ntown of Aoujeft (North), causing loss of life amongst people and\ncattle, Mauritanian officials said Thursday [2 Dec 2010]. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n\"Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,\" stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "637270", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, ovine - South Africa (02): vaccination policy, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=637270", "date": "2010-12-02 19:00:05", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, LIVESTOCK, HUMAN - MAURITANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Dec 2010\nSource: Romandie, Agence France-Press report [in French, trans.\nCorr.SB, edited]\n<http://www.romandie.com/infos/news2/101202124936.qrdv24sl.asp>\n\n\nAn outbreak of Rift Valley [fever] has erupted in the Mauritanian\ntown of Aoujeft (North), causing loss of life amongst people and\ncattle, Mauritanian officials said Thursday [2 Dec 2010]. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n\"Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,\" stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-12-02 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "608145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, livestock  - Mauritania (02): OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=608145", "date": "2010-12-02 19:00:05", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, LIVESTOCK, HUMAN - MAURITANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Dec 2010\nSource: Romandie, Agence France-Press report [in French, trans.\nCorr.SB, edited]\n<http://www.romandie.com/infos/news2/101202124936.qrdv24sl.asp>\n\n\nAn outbreak of Rift Valley [fever] has erupted in the Mauritanian\ntown of Aoujeft (North), causing loss of life amongst people and\ncattle, Mauritanian officials said Thursday [2 Dec 2010]. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n\"Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,\" stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n\"Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,\" stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania (02): (AD) RFI 20101106.4028\nUndiagnosed fatalities - Mauritania: (AD) RFI 20101104.3992\n2003\n----\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\n1999\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (04) 19990101.0001\n1998\n----\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (03) 19981114.2197\nRift valley fever - Mauritania (02) 19981111.2181\nRift valley fever - Mauritania: RFI 19981105.2155\n..............................................sb/cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. \"It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,\" Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n\"textbook-style\", which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. \"And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,\" he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. The workshop\ncontinues until Saturday [19 Jun 2010].\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, the RVF outbreak in Namibia remained restricted to animals;\nno human infections were reported.\n\nThe 2 OIE reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 7\nreported outbreak are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, animal - Namibia: OIE 20100514.1577\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (18): WHO 20100513.1557\nRift valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100512.1548\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. \"It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,\" Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n\"textbook-style\", which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. \"And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,\" he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. The workshop\ncontinues until Saturday [19 Jun 2010].\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, the RVF outbreak in Namibia remained restricted to animals;\nno human infections were reported.\n\nThe 2 OIE reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 7\nreported outbreak are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, animal - Namibia: OIE 20100514.1577\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (18): WHO 20100513.1557\nRift valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100512.1548\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may also unsubscribe\nat <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\npostmaster@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-11-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2010-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swakopmund", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "478858", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, animal - Namibia (04): FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=478858", "date": "2010-06-18 15:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, ANIMAL - NAMIBIA (02)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian report [abridged, edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/201006170586.html>\n\n\nNamibia: RVF under control for the time being\n---------------------------------------------\nNamibia got off lightly from the recent outbreak of Rift Valley fever\n(RVF). However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. \"It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,\" Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n\"textbook-style\", which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. \"And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,\" he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. The workshop\ncontinues until Saturday [19 Jun 2010].\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, the RVF outbreak in Namibia remained restricted to animals;\nno human infections were reported.\n\nThe 2 OIE reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 7\nreported outbreak are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, animal - Namibia: OIE 20100514.1577\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (18): WHO 20100513.1557\nRift valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100512.1548\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. \"It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,\" Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n\"textbook-style\", which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. \"And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,\" he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. The workshop\ncontinues until Saturday [19 Jun 2010].\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, the RVF outbreak in Namibia remained restricted to animals;\nno human infections were reported.\n\nThe 2 OIE reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 7\nreported outbreak are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, animal - Namibia: OIE 20100514.1577\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (18): WHO 20100513.1557\nRift valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100512.1548\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. \"It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,\" Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n\"textbook-style\", which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. \"And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,\" he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. The workshop\ncontinues until Saturday [19 Jun 2010].\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fortunately, the RVF outbreak in Namibia remained restricted to animals;\nno human infections were reported.\n\nThe 2 OIE reports and an interactive map showing the locations of the 7\nreported outbreak are available at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, animal - Namibia: OIE 20100514.1577\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (18): WHO 20100513.1557\nRift valley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100512.1548\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. South Africa (02): control strategy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=441775", "date": "2010-05-11 17:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (17): TOURIST, NOT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 May 2010\nFrom: Stephan Gunther [edited]\n<stephan.gunther@gmx.net>\n\n\nAcute illness in a German tourist on returning from South Africa,\nupdate on laboratory findings\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Bernhard-Nocht-Institute (BNI), Hamburg, and the\nRobert-Koch-Institute Berlin, Germany, recently released a\npreliminary report on a German tourist with acute illness after\nreturning from South Africa (ProMED-mail Archive Number\n20100505.1450, 5 May 2010).\n\nAn acute-phase blood sample tested positive for Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) virus-specific IgM and IgG at BNI, and therefore it was\nconsidered likely that the case-patient acquired infection with RVF\nvirus while travelling in South Africa. Additional laboratory\nanalyses, conducted both in Germany and in South Africa, however,\ncould not confirm this preliminary diagnosis.\n\nTesting of a 2nd, convalescent serum sample at BNI did not reveal an\nincrease in anti-RVF virus antibody titres indicating that the\nantibodies are not related to the illness following the travel to\nSouth Africa. The serum samples, which were sent to and investigated\nat the Special Pathogens Unit, National Institute for Communicable\nDiseases of the National Health Laboratory Service (SPU NICD-NHLS),\nSandringham, South Africa, tested negative for RVF virus-specific\nantibodies in different tests, including ELISA and virus neutralizing assays.\n\nWhile the reason for the discrepant findings remains unclear, in 3\nlaboratories, including BNI and SPU NICD-NHLS, seroconversion to\nRickettsia-specific IgM and IgG was detected, indicating recent\ninfection with _Rickettsia_ sp. We conclude from these new findings\nthat the acute illness in the case-patient after returning from South\nAfrica was caused by infection with _Rickettsia_ and not with RVF virus.\n\n--\nProf. Stephan Gunther\nDepartment of Virology\nBernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht-Str. 74, 20359 Hamburg, Germany\n<guenther@bni.uni-hamburg.de>\n\nProf. Janusz T. Paweska\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases of the National Health\nLaboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4, Sandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\nModderfontein Road 1, Gauteng, South Africa\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professors Stephan Gunther and Janusz Paweska for\nproviding this information concerning the revised diagnosis of the\nacute illness suffered by a tourist recently returned to Germany from\na visit to South Africa.\n\nThis incident may provide some reassurance for visitors to South\nAfrica that the probability of contracting Rift Valley fever virus\nduring recreational travel in that country is low. Nonetheless\nvisitors should avoid contact with diseased livestock and protect\nthemselves from mosquito bites. Likewise diagnostic services in\nEurope should remain vigilant. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (16) 20100509.1512\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (14): tourist 20100505.1450\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (13) 20100429.1390\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (12) 20100422.1303\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (11) 20100415.1223\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (10) 20100409.1158\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Namibia: OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=427854", "date": "2010-05-11 17:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (17): TOURIST, NOT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 May 2010\nFrom: Stephan Gunther [edited]\n<stephan.gunther@gmx.net>\n\n\nAcute illness in a German tourist on returning from South Africa,\nupdate on laboratory findings\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Bernhard-Nocht-Institute (BNI), Hamburg, and the\nRobert-Koch-Institute Berlin, Germany, recently released a\npreliminary report on a German tourist with acute illness after\nreturning from South Africa (ProMED-mail Archive Number\n20100505.1450, 5 May 2010).\n\nAn acute-phase blood sample tested positive for Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) virus-specific IgM and IgG at BNI, and therefore it was\nconsidered likely that the case-patient acquired infection with RVF\nvirus while travelling in South Africa. Additional laboratory\nanalyses, conducted both in Germany and in South Africa, however,\ncould not confirm this preliminary diagnosis.\n\nTesting of a 2nd, convalescent serum sample at BNI did not reveal an\nincrease in anti-RVF virus antibody titres indicating that the\nantibodies are not related to the illness following the travel to\nSouth Africa. The serum samples, which were sent to and investigated\nat the Special Pathogens Unit, National Institute for Communicable\nDiseases of the National Health Laboratory Service (SPU NICD-NHLS),\nSandringham, South Africa, tested negative for RVF virus-specific\nantibodies in different tests, including ELISA and virus neutralizing assays.\n\nWhile the reason for the discrepant findings remains unclear, in 3\nlaboratories, including BNI and SPU NICD-NHLS, seroconversion to\nRickettsia-specific IgM and IgG was detected, indicating recent\ninfection with _Rickettsia_ sp. We conclude from these new findings\nthat the acute illness in the case-patient after returning from South\nAfrica was caused by infection with _Rickettsia_ and not with RVF virus.\n\n--\nProf. Stephan Gunther\nDepartment of Virology\nBernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht-Str. 74, 20359 Hamburg, Germany\n<guenther@bni.uni-hamburg.de>\n\nProf. Janusz T. Paweska\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases of the National Health\nLaboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4, Sandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\nModderfontein Road 1, Gauteng, South Africa\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professors Stephan Gunther and Janusz Paweska for\nproviding this information concerning the revised diagnosis of the\nacute illness suffered by a tourist recently returned to Germany from\na visit to South Africa.\n\nThis incident may provide some reassurance for visitors to South\nAfrica that the probability of contracting Rift Valley fever virus\nduring recreational travel in that country is low. Nonetheless\nvisitors should avoid contact with diseased livestock and protect\nthemselves from mosquito bites. Likewise diagnostic services in\nEurope should remain vigilant. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (16) 20100509.1512\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (14): tourist 20100505.1450\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (13) 20100429.1390\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (12) 20100422.1303\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (11) 20100415.1223\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (10) 20100409.1158\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Nonetheless\nvisitors should avoid contact with diseased livestock and protect\nthemselves from mosquito bites. South Africa (16)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=424084", "date": "2010-05-11 17:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (17): TOURIST, NOT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 May 2010\nFrom: Stephan Gunther [edited]\n<stephan.gunther@gmx.net>\n\n\nAcute illness in a German tourist on returning from South Africa,\nupdate on laboratory findings\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Bernhard-Nocht-Institute (BNI), Hamburg, and the\nRobert-Koch-Institute Berlin, Germany, recently released a\npreliminary report on a German tourist with acute illness after\nreturning from South Africa (ProMED-mail Archive Number\n20100505.1450, 5 May 2010).\n\nAn acute-phase blood sample tested positive for Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) virus-specific IgM and IgG at BNI, and therefore it was\nconsidered likely that the case-patient acquired infection with RVF\nvirus while travelling in South Africa. Additional laboratory\nanalyses, conducted both in Germany and in South Africa, however,\ncould not confirm this preliminary diagnosis.\n\nTesting of a 2nd, convalescent serum sample at BNI did not reveal an\nincrease in anti-RVF virus antibody titres indicating that the\nantibodies are not related to the illness following the travel to\nSouth Africa. The serum samples, which were sent to and investigated\nat the Special Pathogens Unit, National Institute for Communicable\nDiseases of the National Health Laboratory Service (SPU NICD-NHLS),\nSandringham, South Africa, tested negative for RVF virus-specific\nantibodies in different tests, including ELISA and virus neutralizing assays.\n\nWhile the reason for the discrepant findings remains unclear, in 3\nlaboratories, including BNI and SPU NICD-NHLS, seroconversion to\nRickettsia-specific IgM and IgG was detected, indicating recent\ninfection with _Rickettsia_ sp. We conclude from these new findings\nthat the acute illness in the case-patient after returning from South\nAfrica was caused by infection with _Rickettsia_ and not with RVF virus.\n\n--\nProf. Stephan Gunther\nDepartment of Virology\nBernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht-Str. 74, 20359 Hamburg, Germany\n<guenther@bni.uni-hamburg.de>\n\nProf. Janusz T. Paweska\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases of the National Health\nLaboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4, Sandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\nModderfontein Road 1, Gauteng, South Africa\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professors Stephan Gunther and Janusz Paweska for\nproviding this information concerning the revised diagnosis of the\nacute illness suffered by a tourist recently returned to Germany from\na visit to South Africa.\n\nThis incident may provide some reassurance for visitors to South\nAfrica that the probability of contracting Rift Valley fever virus\nduring recreational travel in that country is low. Nonetheless\nvisitors should avoid contact with diseased livestock and protect\nthemselves from mosquito bites. Likewise diagnostic services in\nEurope should remain vigilant. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (16) 20100509.1512\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (15): WHO 20100505.1459\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (14): tourist 20100505.1450\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (13) 20100429.1390\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (12) 20100422.1303\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (11) 20100415.1223\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (10) 20100409.1158\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (09): multi-province 20100407.1119\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. A map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed\nat <http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[see also;\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999]\n.........................................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. A map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed\nat <http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[see also;\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999]\n.........................................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. A map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed\nat <http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[see also;\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province) 20100403.1076\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO 20100331.1016\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (06): (WC) 20100330.1006\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (05): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100328.0972\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (04): (FS, EC, NC, GT, NW) 20100324.0935\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP) 20100321.0902\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02): (FS) 20100316.0845\nRift Valley fever - South Africa: (FS, NC) 20100309.0761\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999]\n.........................................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
