For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Free State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Free State", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "413934", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa (12)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=413934", "date": "2010-04-07 17:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (09): MULTI-PROVINCE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 7 Apr 2010\nSource: AllAfrica.com [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/201004070649.html>\n\n\nThe National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) has confirmed\n5 new human laboratory cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF). This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. A map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed\nat <http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. The department has urged people living in the\naffected areas to seek medical attention at their nearest health\nfacilities should they have any symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak remains centered in Free State province. The number of\nhuman cases has increased from the 82 cases recorded on Fri 3 Apr\n2010 to 87 and the number of human deaths from 5 to 6. The additional\ndeath was recorded in Northern Cape province. The number of human\ncases remains low in comparison with previous outbreaks, but the\nnumber of deaths is unusual, since Rift Valley fever in humans is\ngenerally a mild infection.\n\nFor detailed information on Rift Valley fever in South Africa, go to\nthe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nwebsite at: <http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>,\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 87. Of the 87 confirmed cases, 68\ncases and 4 deaths are from the Free State, 7 [cases] from the\nEastern Cape, 11 cases and 2 deaths from the Northern Cape and one\n[case] from the North West province.\n\nThe Departments of Health and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD continue to respond to the outbreak.\n\"Laboratory, epidemiology and surveillance interventions, health\npromotion interventions, environmental health measures, and\nmanagement of confirmed cases are being prioritised,\" said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock or farms linked to\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within the Free State, and the\nDepartment of Agriculture in the province has started the vaccination\nof animals to contain the spread of the virus. The Eastern Cape,\nGauteng, Northern Cape and North West provinces have also reported\nRVF among animals.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes termination of\ngestation and deaths of young livestock. Humans become infected from\ncontact with infected tissues of livestock and less frequently from\nmosquito bites. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Free State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Free State", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "405055", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=405055", "date": "2010-03-09 23:00:57", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE, NORTH CAPE)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nSource: News 24.com, SAPA report [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/77cc2a21b8314490ba8d3dd07ccf2708/08-03-2010-05-02/Rift_Valley_Fever_outbreak>\n\n\nRift Valley Fever outbreak\n--------------------------\nThere were 7 confirmed cases of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in the Free\nState and Northern Cape and one death reported, the deputy minister\nof health said on Monday [8 Mar 2010].\n\n\"A 45-year-old patient who was admitted to a mine hospital on 26 Feb\n2010 with a provisional diagnosis of Congo fever, died a day later\nand confirmation of RVF was made on 4 Mar 2010,\" said Molefi Sefularo\nin a statement. \"The 6 others, who had mild disease, continue to be\nunder observation and treatment.\" Sefularo, who was on an inspection\ntour of the Pelonomi hospital in the Free State to inspect the level\nof readiness of health facilities for the FIFA World Cup, said the\ndisease posed no threat to the event. \"I would like to place it on\nrecord that this occurrence does not constitute a crisis. The\noutbreak is being contained,\" he said.\n\nRVF is a communicable virus, endemic in South Africa and other\nAfrican countries. In animals, the virus is transmitted by mosquitoes\nand causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths of young sheep, cattle\nand goats. It [can be] transmitted to humans through contact with\ninfected livestock through direct or indirect contact with blood or\norgans of infected animals; the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering of animals or assisting with animal\nbirths; conducting veterinary services or through being cut by\ninfected knives or needles among other things.\n\nSefularo said 15 farms had reported laboratory confirmed animal cases\nwith extensive livestock deaths. The affected farms were primarily\nclustered around the Lejweleputswa District in the Bultfontein area.\nHe said no human-to-human transmission had occurred. Symptoms of the\nvirus were mild fever, headaches and muscle pain.\n\nSefularo appealed to farming communities in the Free State and\nNorthern Cape to avoid high risk husbandry procedures and\nslaughtering practices by using gloves and protective clothing and to\navoid the consumption of fresh blood, raw milk or animal tissue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported elsewhere\nin Africa.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, abbatoir\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular disease (0.5-2\npercent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or\nhaemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality\nrate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has\nbeen less than 1 percent in those documented. Most fatalities occur\nin patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nAs outbreaks of RVF in animals precede human cases, the establishment\nof an active animal health surveillance system to detect new cases is\nessential in providing early warning for veterinary and human public\nhealth authorities. Further information can be obtained at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa, showing the adjacent\nprovinces of the Free State and North Cape, can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-02-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pelonomi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "the Free State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "403731", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa (07): WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=403731", "date": "2010-03-09 23:00:57", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE, NORTH CAPE)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nSource: News 24.com, SAPA report [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/77cc2a21b8314490ba8d3dd07ccf2708/08-03-2010-05-02/Rift_Valley_Fever_outbreak>\n\n\nRift Valley Fever outbreak\n--------------------------\nThere were 7 confirmed cases of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in the Free\nState and Northern Cape and one death reported, the deputy minister\nof health said on Monday [8 Mar 2010].\n\n\"A 45-year-old patient who was admitted to a mine hospital on 26 Feb\n2010 with a provisional diagnosis of Congo fever, died a day later\nand confirmation of RVF was made on 4 Mar 2010,\" said Molefi Sefularo\nin a statement. \"The 6 others, who had mild disease, continue to be\nunder observation and treatment.\" Sefularo, who was on an inspection\ntour of the Pelonomi hospital in the Free State to inspect the level\nof readiness of health facilities for the FIFA World Cup, said the\ndisease posed no threat to the event. \"I would like to place it on\nrecord that this occurrence does not constitute a crisis. The\noutbreak is being contained,\" he said.\n\nRVF is a communicable virus, endemic in South Africa and other\nAfrican countries. In animals, the virus is transmitted by mosquitoes\nand causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths of young sheep, cattle\nand goats. It [can be] transmitted to humans through contact with\ninfected livestock through direct or indirect contact with blood or\norgans of infected animals; the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering of animals or assisting with animal\nbirths; conducting veterinary services or through being cut by\ninfected knives or needles among other things.\n\nSefularo said 15 farms had reported laboratory confirmed animal cases\nwith extensive livestock deaths. The affected farms were primarily\nclustered around the Lejweleputswa District in the Bultfontein area.\nHe said no human-to-human transmission had occurred. Symptoms of the\nvirus were mild fever, headaches and muscle pain.\n\nSefularo appealed to farming communities in the Free State and\nNorthern Cape to avoid high risk husbandry procedures and\nslaughtering practices by using gloves and protective clothing and to\navoid the consumption of fresh blood, raw milk or animal tissue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported elsewhere\nin Africa.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, abbatoir\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular disease (0.5-2\npercent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or\nhaemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality\nrate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has\nbeen less than 1 percent in those documented. Most fatalities occur\nin patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nAs outbreaks of RVF in animals precede human cases, the establishment\nof an active animal health surveillance system to detect new cases is\nessential in providing early warning for veterinary and human public\nhealth authorities. Further information can be obtained at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa, showing the adjacent\nprovinces of the Free State and North Cape, can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported elsewhere\nin Africa.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, abbatoir\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular disease (0.5-2\npercent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or\nhaemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality\nrate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has\nbeen less than 1 percent in those documented. Most fatalities occur\nin patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nAs outbreaks of RVF in animals precede human cases, the establishment\nof an active animal health surveillance system to detect new cases is\nessential in providing early warning for veterinary and human public\nhealth authorities. Further information can be obtained at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa, showing the adjacent\nprovinces of the Free State and North Cape, can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n----\nRift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype 20091120.3999\n................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=398856", "date": "2010-03-09 23:00:57", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA: (FREE STATE, NORTH CAPE)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nSource: News 24.com, SAPA report [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/77cc2a21b8314490ba8d3dd07ccf2708/08-03-2010-05-02/Rift_Valley_Fever_outbreak>\n\n\nRift Valley Fever outbreak\n--------------------------\nThere were 7 confirmed cases of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in the Free\nState and Northern Cape and one death reported, the deputy minister\nof health said on Monday [8 Mar 2010].\n\n\"A 45-year-old patient who was admitted to a mine hospital on 26 Feb\n2010 with a provisional diagnosis of Congo fever, died a day later\nand confirmation of RVF was made on 4 Mar 2010,\" said Molefi Sefularo\nin a statement. \"The 6 others, who had mild disease, continue to be\nunder observation and treatment.\" Sefularo, who was on an inspection\ntour of the Pelonomi hospital in the Free State to inspect the level\nof readiness of health facilities for the FIFA World Cup, said the\ndisease posed no threat to the event. \"I would like to place it on\nrecord that this occurrence does not constitute a crisis. The\noutbreak is being contained,\" he said.\n\nRVF is a communicable virus, endemic in South Africa and other\nAfrican countries. In animals, the virus is transmitted by mosquitoes\nand causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths of young sheep, cattle\nand goats. It [can be] transmitted to humans through contact with\ninfected livestock through direct or indirect contact with blood or\norgans of infected animals; the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering of animals or assisting with animal\nbirths; conducting veterinary services or through being cut by\ninfected knives or needles among other things.\n\nSefularo said 15 farms had reported laboratory confirmed animal cases\nwith extensive livestock deaths. The affected farms were primarily\nclustered around the Lejweleputswa District in the Bultfontein area.\nHe said no human-to-human transmission had occurred. Symptoms of the\nvirus were mild fever, headaches and muscle pain.\n\nSefularo appealed to farming communities in the Free State and\nNorthern Cape to avoid high risk husbandry procedures and\nslaughtering practices by using gloves and protective clothing and to\navoid the consumption of fresh blood, raw milk or animal tissue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported elsewhere\nin Africa.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, abbatoir\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular disease (0.5-2\npercent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or\nhaemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality\nrate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has\nbeen less than 1 percent in those documented. Most fatalities occur\nin patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nAs outbreaks of RVF in animals precede human cases, the establishment\nof an active animal health surveillance system to detect new cases is\nessential in providing early warning for veterinary and human public\nhealth authorities. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-02-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pelonomi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "the Free State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "387788", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=387788", "date": "2009-03-10 23:01:07", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, ANIMALS - SOUTH AFRICA: (KWAZULU-NATAL)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 3 Mar 2009\nSource: SAPA via News24 [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/South_Africa/News/0,,2-7-1442_2479358,00.html>\n\nRift Valley Fever under control\n-------------------------------\nThe contagious Rift Valley Fever in KwaZulu-Natal's Creighton farm\narea was under control, Agriculture and Environmental Affairs MEC\nMtholephi Mthimkhulu said on Tuesday [3 Mar 2009]. \"We sent people to\nCreighton to put the disease under control. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.\"\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 20080701.2012\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\n1999\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02) 19990311.0369\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 19990208.0177\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ANIMALS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Creighton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "336113", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever virus - South Africa: (NC), novel genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=336113", "date": "2009-03-10 23:01:07", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, ANIMALS - SOUTH AFRICA: (KWAZULU-NATAL)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 3 Mar 2009\nSource: SAPA via News24 [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/South_Africa/News/0,,2-7-1442_2479358,00.html>\n\nRift Valley Fever under control\n-------------------------------\nThe contagious Rift Valley Fever in KwaZulu-Natal's Creighton farm\narea was under control, Agriculture and Environmental Affairs MEC\nMtholephi Mthimkhulu said on Tuesday [3 Mar 2009]. \"We sent people to\nCreighton to put the disease under control. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.\"\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 20080701.2012\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\n1999\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02) 19990311.0369\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 19990208.0177\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.\"\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 20080701.2012\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\n1999\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02) 19990311.0369\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 19990208.0177\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.\"\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 20080701.2012\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\n1999\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02) 19990311.0369\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 19990208.0177\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.\"\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n\"When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,\" said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 20080701.2012\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\n1999\n----\nRift Valley fever - South Africa (02) 19990311.0369\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 19990208.0177\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mayotte: 2007-2008", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151298", "date": "2008-07-29 22:00:27", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE - SWAZILAND: OIE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 29 Jul 2008\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database),\nimmediate notification report [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/reports/en_imm_0000007226_20080728_172858.pdf>\n\n\nRift Valley fever, Swaziland\n----------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 28 Jul 2008 from Mr Robert S.\nThwala, director of Veterinary and Livestock Services, Veterinary and\nLivestock Services, Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives,\nMbabane, Swaziland\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 5 Jun 2008\nDate of first confirmation of the event: 14 Jul 2008\nReport date: 28 Jul 2008\nDate submitted to OIE: 28 Jul 2008\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nOutbreak 1: Serec, Hhohho\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jun 2008\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: cattle\nSusceptible: 170\nCases: 22\nDeaths: 10\nDestroyed: 0\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: dairy animals kept intensively. All ages are\naffected. 12 animals aborted at 7-8 months and 10 calves died of\npneumonia at 6-12 weeks. The herd was vaccinated against RVF on 1 Jun\n2008.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: virus isolation was unsuccessful.\nInvestigations are underway to determine if there is natural\ninfection in view of the history of vaccination. [Apparently 5 days\nprior to the reported start of the outbreak. - Mod.AS]\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Golden Vetpath (IDEXX) (private Laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: histological test\nTest date: 16 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute\n(regional reference laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)\nTest date: 14 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st official report on RVF in Swaziland. The disease was\nreported from neighboring Mpumalanga, in South Africa, earlier this\nyear (2008). South Africa and Mozambique, Swaziland's neighbors, are\nknown to be long infected: S. Africa since 1950, Mozambique since\n1969. It will be of importance to note if human cases have been\nrecorded in Swaziland.\n\nHas the vaccination been undertaken in view of the RVF outbreak in\nneighboring Mpumalanga?\n\nSee map of both territories at\n<http://www.portfoliocollection.com/destinations/Mpumalanga/mpumalanga-map.gif>.\n\nResults of the investigation into the \"naturalness\" of the infection,\nexcluding possible involvement of the vaccine, are anticipated with\ninterest. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. All ages are\naffected. 12 animals aborted at 7-8 months and 10 calves died of\npneumonia at 6-12 weeks. The herd was vaccinated against RVF on 1 Jun\n2008.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: virus isolation was unsuccessful.\nInvestigations are underway to determine if there is natural\ninfection in view of the history of vaccination. [Apparently 5 days\nprior to the reported start of the outbreak. - Mod.AS]\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Golden Vetpath (IDEXX) (private Laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: histological test\nTest date: 16 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute\n(regional reference laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)\nTest date: 14 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st official report on RVF in Swaziland. The disease was\nreported from neighboring Mpumalanga, in South Africa, earlier this\nyear (2008). South Africa and Mozambique, Swaziland's neighbors, are\nknown to be long infected: S. Africa since 1950, Mozambique since\n1969. It will be of importance to note if human cases have been\nrecorded in Swaziland.\n\nHas the vaccination been undertaken in view of the RVF outbreak in\nneighboring Mpumalanga?\n\nSee map of both territories at\n<http://www.portfoliocollection.com/destinations/Mpumalanga/mpumalanga-map.gif>.\n\nResults of the investigation into the \"naturalness\" of the infection,\nexcluding possible involvement of the vaccine, are anticipated with\ninterest. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. All ages are\naffected. 12 animals aborted at 7-8 months and 10 calves died of\npneumonia at 6-12 weeks. The herd was vaccinated against RVF on 1 Jun\n2008.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: virus isolation was unsuccessful.\nInvestigations are underway to determine if there is natural\ninfection in view of the history of vaccination. [Apparently 5 days\nprior to the reported start of the outbreak. - Mod.AS]\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Golden Vetpath (IDEXX) (private Laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: histological test\nTest date: 16 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute\n(regional reference laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)\nTest date: 14 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st official report on RVF in Swaziland. The disease was\nreported from neighboring Mpumalanga, in South Africa, earlier this\nyear (2008). South Africa and Mozambique, Swaziland's neighbors, are\nknown to be long infected: S. Africa since 1950, Mozambique since\n1969. It will be of importance to note if human cases have been\nrecorded in Swaziland.\n\nHas the vaccination been undertaken in view of the RVF outbreak in\nneighboring Mpumalanga?\n\nSee map of both territories at\n<http://www.portfoliocollection.com/destinations/Mpumalanga/mpumalanga-map.gif>.\n\nResults of the investigation into the \"naturalness\" of the infection,\nexcluding possible involvement of the vaccine, are anticipated with\ninterest. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. All ages are\naffected. 12 animals aborted at 7-8 months and 10 calves died of\npneumonia at 6-12 weeks. The herd was vaccinated against RVF on 1 Jun\n2008.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: virus isolation was unsuccessful.\nInvestigations are underway to determine if there is natural\ninfection in view of the history of vaccination. [Apparently 5 days\nprior to the reported start of the outbreak. - Mod.AS]\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Golden Vetpath (IDEXX) (private Laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: histological test\nTest date: 16 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute\n(regional reference laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)\nTest date: 14 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st official report on RVF in Swaziland. The disease was\nreported from neighboring Mpumalanga, in South Africa, earlier this\nyear (2008). South Africa and Mozambique, Swaziland's neighbors, are\nknown to be long infected: S. Africa since 1950, Mozambique since\n1969. It will be of importance to note if human cases have been\nrecorded in Swaziland.\n\nHas the vaccination been undertaken in view of the RVF outbreak in\nneighboring Mpumalanga?\n\nSee map of both territories at\n<http://www.portfoliocollection.com/destinations/Mpumalanga/mpumalanga-map.gif>.\n\nResults of the investigation into the \"naturalness\" of the infection,\nexcluding possible involvement of the vaccine, are anticipated with\ninterest. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. All ages are\naffected. 12 animals aborted at 7-8 months and 10 calves died of\npneumonia at 6-12 weeks. The herd was vaccinated against RVF on 1 Jun\n2008.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: virus isolation was unsuccessful.\nInvestigations are underway to determine if there is natural\ninfection in view of the history of vaccination. [Apparently 5 days\nprior to the reported start of the outbreak. - Mod.AS]\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Golden Vetpath (IDEXX) (private Laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: histological test\nTest date: 16 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute\n(regional reference laboratory)\nSpecies: cattle\nTest: real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR)\nTest date: 14 Jul 2008\nResult: positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st official report on RVF in Swaziland. The disease was\nreported from neighboring Mpumalanga, in South Africa, earlier this\nyear (2008). South Africa and Mozambique, Swaziland's neighbors, are\nknown to be long infected: S. Africa since 1950, Mozambique since\n1969. It will be of importance to note if human cases have been\nrecorded in Swaziland.\n\nHas the vaccination been undertaken in view of the RVF outbreak in\nneighboring Mpumalanga?\n\nSee map of both territories at\n<http://www.portfoliocollection.com/destinations/Mpumalanga/mpumalanga-map.gif>.\n\nResults of the investigation into the \"naturalness\" of the infection,\nexcluding possible involvement of the vaccine, are anticipated with\ninterest. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, buffalo - South Africa: (Mpumalanga), OIE 20080210.0541\nRift Valley fever, livestock - South Africa: OIE 20080607.1813\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1950-03-16 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S. Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mozambique", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "95644", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Madagascar (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=95644", "date": "2008-01-22 19:00:14", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: WHO\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Jan 2008\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_01_22/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever in Sudan - WHO update\n---------------------------------------\nHuman cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Sudan have decreased continuously\nin recent weeks. As of 15 Jan 2008, a cumulative total of 698 cases,\nincluding 222 deaths, has been reported from 6 states (Gazeera, Kassala,\nKhartoum, River Nile, Sinnar, and White Nile), yielding an overall CFR\n[case fatality rate] of 32.4 per cent.\n\nWhile active surveillance continues in all affected states, no new cases\nhave been reported since 5 Jan 2008. Only Gazeera state has reported cases\nwith date of onset in 2008, while several additional cases have been\nreported retrospectively with date of onset in November or December 2007.\nSeveral of the newly added cases evidence ocular presentation, which is\ntypically a late-occurring feature of RVF infection.\n\nCase management related interventions and health education and vector\ncontrol efforts are continuing. WHO continues to support the Sudan Ministry\nof Health in preparedness for viral haemorrhagic fever and other seasonal\noutbreaks and in the procurement of essential supplies, enhancing\nsurveillance and training activities.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO RVF Fact Sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>, parts of\nwhich are appended below.\n\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[\"Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause\nsevere disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates of disease\nand death. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to\ndeath and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n\"RVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera in\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and\nTanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen, marking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the\nAfrican continent and raising concerns that it could extend to other parts\nof Asia and Europe.\n\n\"The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. The\nvirus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound from an\ninfected knife or through contact with broken skin, or through inhalation\nof aerosols produced during the slaughter of infected animals. The aerosol\nmode of transmission has also led to infection in laboratory workers.\n\n\"While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients\ndevelop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually appears as one\nor more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 per cent of\npatients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 per cent) or haemorrhagic fever\n(less than 1 per cent). The total case fatality rate has varied widely\nbetween different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 per cent in\nthose documented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\n\"During an outbreak of RVF, close contact with animals, particularly with\ntheir body fluids, either directly or via aerosols, has been identified as\nthe most significant risk factor for RVF virus infection. In the absence of\nspecific treatment and an effective human vaccine, raising awareness of the\nrisk factors of RVF infection as well as the protective measures\nindividuals can take to prevent mosquito bites, is the only way to reduce\nhuman infection and deaths.\"\n\nA map of the states of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/Media/PDF/Sud-states-2006.pdf>. The number\nof human cases previously confirmed by WHO was 601 on 19 Dec 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (11): WHO 20071221.4108\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (10) 20071220.4096\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (09): WHO 20071122.3748\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (08): 20071121.3760\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (07): 20071118.3735\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (06): WHO 20071115.3713\nRift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04): 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03): 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\n\n.................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2008-01-22 00:00:00", "2008-01-15 00:00:00", "2008-01-05 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassala", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "91863", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=91863", "date": "2008-01-22 19:00:14", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: WHO\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Jan 2008\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_01_22/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever in Sudan - WHO update\n---------------------------------------\nHuman cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Sudan have decreased continuously\nin recent weeks. As of 15 Jan 2008, a cumulative total of 698 cases,\nincluding 222 deaths, has been reported from 6 states (Gazeera, Kassala,\nKhartoum, River Nile, Sinnar, and White Nile), yielding an overall CFR\n[case fatality rate] of 32.4 per cent.\n\nWhile active surveillance continues in all affected states, no new cases\nhave been reported since 5 Jan 2008. Only Gazeera state has reported cases\nwith date of onset in 2008, while several additional cases have been\nreported retrospectively with date of onset in November or December 2007.\nSeveral of the newly added cases evidence ocular presentation, which is\ntypically a late-occurring feature of RVF infection.\n\nCase management related interventions and health education and vector\ncontrol efforts are continuing. WHO continues to support the Sudan Ministry\nof Health in preparedness for viral haemorrhagic fever and other seasonal\noutbreaks and in the procurement of essential supplies, enhancing\nsurveillance and training activities.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO RVF Fact Sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>, parts of\nwhich are appended below.\n\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[\"Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause\nsevere disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates of disease\nand death. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to\ndeath and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n\"RVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera in\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and\nTanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen, marking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the\nAfrican continent and raising concerns that it could extend to other parts\nof Asia and Europe.\n\n\"The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. The\nvirus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound from an\ninfected knife or through contact with broken skin, or through inhalation\nof aerosols produced during the slaughter of infected animals. The aerosol\nmode of transmission has also led to infection in laboratory workers.\n\n\"While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients\ndevelop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually appears as one\nor more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 per cent of\npatients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 per cent) or haemorrhagic fever\n(less than 1 per cent). The total case fatality rate has varied widely\nbetween different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 per cent in\nthose documented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\n\"During an outbreak of RVF, close contact with animals, particularly with\ntheir body fluids, either directly or via aerosols, has been identified as\nthe most significant risk factor for RVF virus infection. In the absence of\nspecific treatment and an effective human vaccine, raising awareness of the\nrisk factors of RVF infection as well as the protective measures\nindividuals can take to prevent mosquito bites, is the only way to reduce\nhuman infection and deaths.\"\n\nA map of the states of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/Media/PDF/Sud-states-2006.pdf>. The number\nof human cases previously confirmed by WHO was 601 on 19 Dec 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (11): WHO 20071221.4108\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (10) 20071220.4096\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (09): WHO 20071122.3748\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (08): 20071121.3760\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (07): 20071118.3735\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (06): WHO 20071115.3713\nRift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04): 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03): 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\n\n.................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. WHO continues to support the Sudan Ministry\nof Health in preparedness for viral haemorrhagic fever and other seasonal\noutbreaks and in the procurement of essential supplies, enhancing\nsurveillance and training activities.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO RVF Fact Sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>, parts of\nwhich are appended below.\n\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[\"Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause\nsevere disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates of disease\nand death. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to\ndeath and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n\"RVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera in\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and\nTanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen, marking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the\nAfrican continent and raising concerns that it could extend to other parts\nof Asia and Europe.\n\n\"The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. The\nvirus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound from an\ninfected knife or through contact with broken skin, or through inhalation\nof aerosols produced during the slaughter of infected animals. The aerosol\nmode of transmission has also led to infection in laboratory workers.\n\n\"While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients\ndevelop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually appears as one\nor more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 per cent of\npatients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 per cent) or haemorrhagic fever\n(less than 1 per cent). The total case fatality rate has varied widely\nbetween different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 per cent in\nthose documented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\n\"During an outbreak of RVF, close contact with animals, particularly with\ntheir body fluids, either directly or via aerosols, has been identified as\nthe most significant risk factor for RVF virus infection. In the absence of\nspecific treatment and an effective human vaccine, raising awareness of the\nrisk factors of RVF infection as well as the protective measures\nindividuals can take to prevent mosquito bites, is the only way to reduce\nhuman infection and deaths.\"\n\nA map of the states of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/Media/PDF/Sud-states-2006.pdf>. The number\nof human cases previously confirmed by WHO was 601 on 19 Dec 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (11): WHO 20071221.4108\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (10) 20071220.4096\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (09): WHO 20071122.3748\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (08): 20071121.3760\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (07): 20071118.3735\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (06): WHO 20071115.3713\nRift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04): 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03): 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\n\n.................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
