For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2008-01-22 00:00:00", "2008-01-15 00:00:00", "2008-01-05 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassala", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "73523", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, human, bovine - Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=73523", "date": "2008-01-22 19:00:14", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN: WHO\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Jan 2008\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_01_22/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever in Sudan - WHO update\n---------------------------------------\nHuman cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Sudan have decreased continuously\nin recent weeks. As of 15 Jan 2008, a cumulative total of 698 cases,\nincluding 222 deaths, has been reported from 6 states (Gazeera, Kassala,\nKhartoum, River Nile, Sinnar, and White Nile), yielding an overall CFR\n[case fatality rate] of 32.4 per cent.\n\nWhile active surveillance continues in all affected states, no new cases\nhave been reported since 5 Jan 2008. Only Gazeera state has reported cases\nwith date of onset in 2008, while several additional cases have been\nreported retrospectively with date of onset in November or December 2007.\nSeveral of the newly added cases evidence ocular presentation, which is\ntypically a late-occurring feature of RVF infection.\n\nCase management related interventions and health education and vector\ncontrol efforts are continuing. WHO continues to support the Sudan Ministry\nof Health in preparedness for viral haemorrhagic fever and other seasonal\noutbreaks and in the procurement of essential supplies, enhancing\nsurveillance and training activities.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO RVF Fact Sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>, parts of\nwhich are appended below.\n\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[\"Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause\nsevere disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates of disease\nand death. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to\ndeath and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n\"RVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera in\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and\nTanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen, marking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the\nAfrican continent and raising concerns that it could extend to other parts\nof Asia and Europe.\n\n\"The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. The\nvirus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound from an\ninfected knife or through contact with broken skin, or through inhalation\nof aerosols produced during the slaughter of infected animals. The aerosol\nmode of transmission has also led to infection in laboratory workers.\n\n\"While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients\ndevelop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually appears as one\nor more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 per cent of\npatients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 per cent) or haemorrhagic fever\n(less than 1 per cent). The total case fatality rate has varied widely\nbetween different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 per cent in\nthose documented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\n\"During an outbreak of RVF, close contact with animals, particularly with\ntheir body fluids, either directly or via aerosols, has been identified as\nthe most significant risk factor for RVF virus infection. In the absence of\nspecific treatment and an effective human vaccine, raising awareness of the\nrisk factors of RVF infection as well as the protective measures\nindividuals can take to prevent mosquito bites, is the only way to reduce\nhuman infection and deaths.\"\n\nA map of the states of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/Media/PDF/Sud-states-2006.pdf>. The number\nof human cases previously confirmed by WHO was 601 on 19 Dec 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (11): WHO 20071221.4108\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (10) 20071220.4096\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (09): WHO 20071122.3748\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (08): 20071121.3760\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (07): 20071118.3735\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (06): WHO 20071115.3713\nRift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04): 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03): 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\n\n.................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As of 15 Jan 2008, a cumulative total of 698 cases,\nincluding 222 deaths, has been reported from 6 states (Gazeera, Kassala,\nKhartoum, River Nile, Sinnar, and White Nile), yielding an overall CFR\n[case fatality rate] of 32.4 per cent.\n\nWhile active surveillance continues in all affected states, no new cases\nhave been reported since 5 Jan 2008. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and\nTanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen, marking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the\nAfrican continent and raising concerns that it could extend to other parts\nof Asia and Europe.\n\n\"The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2008-01-22 00:00:00", "2008-01-15 00:00:00", "2008-01-05 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1931-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassala", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "44384", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (11): WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=44384", "date": "2007-11-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN (06): WHO\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2007\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2007_11_14/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) in Sudan - WHO Update 2\n-----------------------------------------\nAs of Wed 14 Nov 2007, 329 human cases, including 96 deaths\n(case-fatality rate, 29 percent) have been reported from White Nile,\nSennar, Gazeera states. Cases reported in Khartoum state are not\nindigenous cases but were imported from one of the other affected\nstates. The most rapid increase in human cases has been seen in\nGazeera state, which now accounts for more than half of the human\ncases. The cases being reported in Gazeera state are in an area close\nto irrigation canals and are linked to naturally occurring cycles\ninvolving livestock and mosquitoes which are abundant in the\nirrigation zone.\n\nOn Sun 11 Nov 2007, the Sudanese Federal Ministry of Animal Resources\nand Fisheries reported to the Office International des Epizooties\n(OIE) that Rift Valley fever had been found on 29 Oct 2007 in samples\ntaken from animals in White Nile State. It is anticipated that\nfollowing this declaration, a well-integrated control program for\nlimiting the disease in both human and animal populations will now be\nimplemented.\n\nThe Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has\ndeployed a senior animal health expert to the country to assist\nveterinary services with prevention and control measures in animals.\nThe Ministry of Health and the WHO Country Office have presented a\nplan for the prevention and control of the disease in humans to\ninternational donors in Khartoum. The WHO Eastern Mediterranean\nRegional Office and WHO headquarters are supporting the national\nresponse, mobilizing epidemiologists and working with partners to\nenhance national laboratory capacity for RVF.\n\nSocial mobilization activities are now underway to alert the local\npopulation to the human health risks associated with this disease in\nanimals. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. The most\nrapid increase in cases is occurring in the eastern state of Gazeera.\nA map of Sudan showing the location of the adjacent states of White\nNile, Sennar, and Gazeera, south of the capital Khartoum, is\navailable at\n<http://www.rightsmaps.com/html/sudmap1.html>,\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>.\n\nThe extent of the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in livestock in the\nCentral/Eastern states of Sudan remains confused and unclear, as\ndiscussed in detail in ProMED-mail posts: Rift Valley fever, bovine,\novine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694 and Rift Valley fever -\nSudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663. Further information is\nawaited.\n\nFor further information on Rift Valley fever in animals, see the WHO\nFact Sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04) 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03) 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\nYellow fever - Sudan: susp., RFI 20071020.3419\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\n2004\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Kenya (Western Province): RFI 20040624.1681\n2003\n----\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\n2002\n----\nAcute hemorrhagic fever syndrome - Sudan 20020307.3706\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20001011.1742\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20000923.1643\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\n1999\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Sudan (south) (05): Borreliasis? 19990410.0593\n....................................................cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Sennar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khartoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "38641", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (09): WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=38641", "date": "2007-11-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN (06): WHO\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2007\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2007_11_14/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) in Sudan - WHO Update 2\n-----------------------------------------\nAs of Wed 14 Nov 2007, 329 human cases, including 96 deaths\n(case-fatality rate, 29 percent) have been reported from White Nile,\nSennar, Gazeera states. Cases reported in Khartoum state are not\nindigenous cases but were imported from one of the other affected\nstates. The most rapid increase in human cases has been seen in\nGazeera state, which now accounts for more than half of the human\ncases. The cases being reported in Gazeera state are in an area close\nto irrigation canals and are linked to naturally occurring cycles\ninvolving livestock and mosquitoes which are abundant in the\nirrigation zone.\n\nOn Sun 11 Nov 2007, the Sudanese Federal Ministry of Animal Resources\nand Fisheries reported to the Office International des Epizooties\n(OIE) that Rift Valley fever had been found on 29 Oct 2007 in samples\ntaken from animals in White Nile State. It is anticipated that\nfollowing this declaration, a well-integrated control program for\nlimiting the disease in both human and animal populations will now be\nimplemented.\n\nThe Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has\ndeployed a senior animal health expert to the country to assist\nveterinary services with prevention and control measures in animals.\nThe Ministry of Health and the WHO Country Office have presented a\nplan for the prevention and control of the disease in humans to\ninternational donors in Khartoum. The WHO Eastern Mediterranean\nRegional Office and WHO headquarters are supporting the national\nresponse, mobilizing epidemiologists and working with partners to\nenhance national laboratory capacity for RVF.\n\nSocial mobilization activities are now underway to alert the local\npopulation to the human health risks associated with this disease in\nanimals. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. The most\nrapid increase in cases is occurring in the eastern state of Gazeera.\nA map of Sudan showing the location of the adjacent states of White\nNile, Sennar, and Gazeera, south of the capital Khartoum, is\navailable at\n<http://www.rightsmaps.com/html/sudmap1.html>,\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>.\n\nThe extent of the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in livestock in the\nCentral/Eastern states of Sudan remains confused and unclear, as\ndiscussed in detail in ProMED-mail posts: Rift Valley fever, bovine,\novine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694 and Rift Valley fever -\nSudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663. Further information is\nawaited.\n\nFor further information on Rift Valley fever in animals, see the WHO\nFact Sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04) 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03) 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\nYellow fever - Sudan: susp., RFI 20071020.3419\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\n2004\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Kenya (Western Province): RFI 20040624.1681\n2003\n----\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\n2002\n----\nAcute hemorrhagic fever syndrome - Sudan 20020307.3706\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20001011.1742\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20000923.1643\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\n1999\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Sudan (south) (05): Borreliasis? 19990410.0593\n....................................................cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cases reported in Khartoum state are not\nindigenous cases but were imported from one of the other affected\nstates. The most rapid increase in human cases has been seen in\nGazeera state, which now accounts for more than half of the human\ncases. The cases being reported in Gazeera state are in an area close\nto irrigation canals and are linked to naturally occurring cycles\ninvolving livestock and mosquitoes which are abundant in the\nirrigation zone.\n\nOn Sun 11 Nov 2007, the Sudanese Federal Ministry of Animal Resources\nand Fisheries reported to the Office International des Epizooties\n(OIE) that Rift Valley fever had been found on 29 Oct 2007 in samples\ntaken from animals in White Nile State. It is anticipated that\nfollowing this declaration, a well-integrated control program for\nlimiting the disease in both human and animal populations will now be\nimplemented.\n\nThe Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has\ndeployed a senior animal health expert to the country to assist\nveterinary services with prevention and control measures in animals.\nThe Ministry of Health and the WHO Country Office have presented a\nplan for the prevention and control of the disease in humans to\ninternational donors in Khartoum. The WHO Eastern Mediterranean\nRegional Office and WHO headquarters are supporting the national\nresponse, mobilizing epidemiologists and working with partners to\nenhance national laboratory capacity for RVF.\n\nSocial mobilization activities are now underway to alert the local\npopulation to the human health risks associated with this disease in\nanimals. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. The most\nrapid increase in cases is occurring in the eastern state of Gazeera.\nA map of Sudan showing the location of the adjacent states of White\nNile, Sennar, and Gazeera, south of the capital Khartoum, is\navailable at\n<http://www.rightsmaps.com/html/sudmap1.html>,\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>.\n\nThe extent of the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in livestock in the\nCentral/Eastern states of Sudan remains confused and unclear, as\ndiscussed in detail in ProMED-mail posts: Rift Valley fever, bovine,\novine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE 20071114.3694 and Rift Valley fever -\nSudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663. Further information is\nawaited.\n\nFor further information on Rift Valley fever in animals, see the WHO\nFact Sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (05): animal involvement 20071111.3663\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (04) 20071110.3648\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (03) 20071109.3643\nRift Valley fever - Sudan (02): WHO 20071106.3611\nRift Valley fever - Sudan 20071103.3570\nYellow fever - Sudan: susp., RFI 20071020.3419\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\n2004\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Kenya (Western Province): RFI 20040624.1681\n2003\n----\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\n2002\n----\nAcute hemorrhagic fever syndrome - Sudan 20020307.3706\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20001011.1742\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20000923.1643\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\n1999\n----\nUndiagnosed deaths - Sudan (south) (05): Borreliasis? 19990410.0593\n....................................................cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cases reported in Khartoum state are not\nindigenous cases but were imported from one of the other affected\nstates. It is anticipated that\nfollowing this declaration, a well-integrated control program for\nlimiting the disease in both human and animal populations will now be\nimplemented.\n\nThe Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has\ndeployed a senior animal health expert to the country to assist\nveterinary services with prevention and control measures in animals.\nThe Ministry of Health and the WHO Country Office have presented a\nplan for the prevention and control of the disease in humans to\ninternational donors in Khartoum. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Sennar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khartoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "37049", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Sudan: (West Nile), OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=37049", "date": "2007-10-11 22:00:08", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE, OVINE - IRAQ: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). \"We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,\" said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. \"A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.\" [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. \"A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,\" he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. \"We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,\" Sulaiman said.\n\"Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,\" he added. \"We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,\" Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. \"Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,\" said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. \"All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,\" Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. \"We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,\" Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the illness can\nprogress to haemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhaemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular diseases.\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalised\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. In previous RVF cases in the Middle East, cases in humans\npreceded the reporting of animal disease.\nRVF has never been diagnosed in Iraq; the only countries in the Near\nEast which have been affected by RVF in the past are Egypt, Yemen and\nSaudi Arabia. During the late 1970's, RVF was reportedly suspected in\nEgyptian laborers residing in Iraq, but their eventual diagnosis was\nCongo-Crimean Haemorrhagic fever.\nThe clinical signs of RVF in animals vary with the age, species and\nbreed of the animal. In endemic regions, epidemics of Rift Valley\nfever can be recognized by high mortality rates in newborn animals\nand abortions in adults. In lambs, a biphasic fever, anorexia and\nlymphadenopathy may be followed by weakness and death within 36\nhours. Hemorrhagic diarrhea or abdominal pain can also be seen. The\nyoungest animals are most severely affected. In neonates, the\nmortality rate may reach 90 to 100 percent. However, no ovine\nneonates are expected yet in southern Iraq, where lambing is\nanticipated to commence not earlier than the end November 2007.\nSimilar symptoms occur in young calves: fever, anorexia and\ndepression are typical, with mortality rates of 10 to 70 percent.\nAbortions are the most characteristic sign in adult sheep and cattle.\nOther symptoms that may occur in adult sheep include fever, weakness,\na mucopurulent nasal discharge (sometimes bloodstained), melena,\nhemorrhagic or foul-smelling diarrhea, and vomiting. In adult cattle,\nfever, anorexia, weakness, excessive salivation, fetid diarrhea and\ndecreased milk production have been reported. Icterus may also be\nseen, particularly in cattle.\nSimilar but milder infections occur in goats. Adult camels do not\ndevelop symptoms other than abortion, but young animals may have more\nsevere disease.\nFor further details, see\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/rift_valley_fever.pdf>.\nAn extensive epizootic of RVF spread earlier this year [2007] in\neastern Africa and the Horn of Africa.\nFurther details, particularly confirmation (or otherwise) of the\ndiagnosis by a reference laboratory, are soon anticipated. Then OIE\nreference laboratory for RVF is the Onderstepoort Veterinary\nInstitute in South Africa. The NAMRU-3 laboratory in Cairo has been\nhelpful in the early diagnosis of outbreaks in the region. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\n.............................................arn/msp/lm/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-07-16 00:00:00", "2002-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dhi Qar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Nassiriyah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baghdad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36296", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36206", "date": "2007-10-11 22:00:08", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE, OVINE - IRAQ: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). \"We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,\" said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. \"A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.\" [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. \"A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,\" he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. \"We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,\" Sulaiman said.\n\"Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,\" he added. \"We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,\" Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. \"Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,\" said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. \"All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,\" Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. \"We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,\" Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the illness can\nprogress to haemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhaemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular diseases.\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalised\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. In previous RVF cases in the Middle East, cases in humans\npreceded the reporting of animal disease.\nRVF has never been diagnosed in Iraq; the only countries in the Near\nEast which have been affected by RVF in the past are Egypt, Yemen and\nSaudi Arabia. During the late 1970's, RVF was reportedly suspected in\nEgyptian laborers residing in Iraq, but their eventual diagnosis was\nCongo-Crimean Haemorrhagic fever.\nThe clinical signs of RVF in animals vary with the age, species and\nbreed of the animal. In endemic regions, epidemics of Rift Valley\nfever can be recognized by high mortality rates in newborn animals\nand abortions in adults. In lambs, a biphasic fever, anorexia and\nlymphadenopathy may be followed by weakness and death within 36\nhours. Hemorrhagic diarrhea or abdominal pain can also be seen. The\nyoungest animals are most severely affected. In neonates, the\nmortality rate may reach 90 to 100 percent. However, no ovine\nneonates are expected yet in southern Iraq, where lambing is\nanticipated to commence not earlier than the end November 2007.\nSimilar symptoms occur in young calves: fever, anorexia and\ndepression are typical, with mortality rates of 10 to 70 percent.\nAbortions are the most characteristic sign in adult sheep and cattle.\nOther symptoms that may occur in adult sheep include fever, weakness,\na mucopurulent nasal discharge (sometimes bloodstained), melena,\nhemorrhagic or foul-smelling diarrhea, and vomiting. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-07-16 00:00:00", "2002-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dhi Qar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Nassiriyah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baghdad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36204", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36204", "date": "2007-10-11 22:00:08", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE, OVINE - IRAQ: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). \"We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,\" said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. \"A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.\" [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. \"A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,\" he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. \"We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,\" Sulaiman said.\n\"Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,\" he added. \"We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,\" Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. \"Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,\" said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. \"All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,\" Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. \"We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,\" Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the illness can\nprogress to haemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhaemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular diseases.\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalised\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. In previous RVF cases in the Middle East, cases in humans\npreceded the reporting of animal disease.\nRVF has never been diagnosed in Iraq; the only countries in the Near\nEast which have been affected by RVF in the past are Egypt, Yemen and\nSaudi Arabia. During the late 1970's, RVF was reportedly suspected in\nEgyptian laborers residing in Iraq, but their eventual diagnosis was\nCongo-Crimean Haemorrhagic fever.\nThe clinical signs of RVF in animals vary with the age, species and\nbreed of the animal. In endemic regions, epidemics of Rift Valley\nfever can be recognized by high mortality rates in newborn animals\nand abortions in adults. In lambs, a biphasic fever, anorexia and\nlymphadenopathy may be followed by weakness and death within 36\nhours. Hemorrhagic diarrhea or abdominal pain can also be seen. The\nyoungest animals are most severely affected. In neonates, the\nmortality rate may reach 90 to 100 percent. However, no ovine\nneonates are expected yet in southern Iraq, where lambing is\nanticipated to commence not earlier than the end November 2007.\nSimilar symptoms occur in young calves: fever, anorexia and\ndepression are typical, with mortality rates of 10 to 70 percent.\nAbortions are the most characteristic sign in adult sheep and cattle.\nOther symptoms that may occur in adult sheep include fever, weakness,\na mucopurulent nasal discharge (sometimes bloodstained), melena,\nhemorrhagic or foul-smelling diarrhea, and vomiting. In adult cattle,\nfever, anorexia, weakness, excessive salivation, fetid diarrhea and\ndecreased milk production have been reported. Icterus may also be\nseen, particularly in cattle.\nSimilar but milder infections occur in goats. Adult camels do not\ndevelop symptoms other than abortion, but young animals may have more\nsevere disease.\nFor further details, see\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/rift_valley_fever.pdf>.\nAn extensive epizootic of RVF spread earlier this year [2007] in\neastern Africa and the Horn of Africa.\nFurther details, particularly confirmation (or otherwise) of the\ndiagnosis by a reference laboratory, are soon anticipated. Then OIE\nreference laboratory for RVF is the Onderstepoort Veterinary\nInstitute in South Africa. The NAMRU-3 laboratory in Cairo has been\nhelpful in the early diagnosis of outbreaks in the region. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\n.............................................arn/msp/lm/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. Sudan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=35159", "date": "2007-10-11 22:00:08", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE, OVINE - IRAQ: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). \"We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,\" said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. \"A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.\" [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. \"A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,\" he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. \"We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,\" Sulaiman said.\n\"Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,\" he added. \"We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,\" Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. \"Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,\" said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. \"All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,\" Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. \"We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,\" Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever", "haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-07-16 00:00:00", "2002-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dhi Qar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Nassiriyah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baghdad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "32033", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, bovine, ovine - Iraq (02): NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=32033", "date": "2007-10-11 22:00:08", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, BOVINE, OVINE - IRAQ: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). \"We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,\" said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. \"A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.\" [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. \"A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,\" he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. \"We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,\" Sulaiman said.\n\"Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,\" he added. \"We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,\" Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. \"Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,\" said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. \"All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,\" Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. \"We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,\" Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the illness can\nprogress to haemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhaemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular diseases.\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalised\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. In previous RVF cases in the Middle East, cases in humans\npreceded the reporting of animal disease.\nRVF has never been diagnosed in Iraq; the only countries in the Near\nEast which have been affected by RVF in the past are Egypt, Yemen and\nSaudi Arabia. During the late 1970's, RVF was reportedly suspected in\nEgyptian laborers residing in Iraq, but their eventual diagnosis was\nCongo-Crimean Haemorrhagic fever.\nThe clinical signs of RVF in animals vary with the age, species and\nbreed of the animal. In endemic regions, epidemics of Rift Valley\nfever can be recognized by high mortality rates in newborn animals\nand abortions in adults. In lambs, a biphasic fever, anorexia and\nlymphadenopathy may be followed by weakness and death within 36\nhours. Hemorrhagic diarrhea or abdominal pain can also be seen. The\nyoungest animals are most severely affected. In neonates, the\nmortality rate may reach 90 to 100 percent. However, no ovine\nneonates are expected yet in southern Iraq, where lambing is\nanticipated to commence not earlier than the end November 2007.\nSimilar symptoms occur in young calves: fever, anorexia and\ndepression are typical, with mortality rates of 10 to 70 percent.\nAbortions are the most characteristic sign in adult sheep and cattle.\nOther symptoms that may occur in adult sheep include fever, weakness,\na mucopurulent nasal discharge (sometimes bloodstained), melena,\nhemorrhagic or foul-smelling diarrhea, and vomiting. In adult cattle,\nfever, anorexia, weakness, excessive salivation, fetid diarrhea and\ndecreased milk production have been reported. Icterus may also be\nseen, particularly in cattle.\nSimilar but milder infections occur in goats. Adult camels do not\ndevelop symptoms other than abortion, but young animals may have more\nsevere disease.\nFor further details, see\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/rift_valley_fever.pdf>.\nAn extensive epizootic of RVF spread earlier this year [2007] in\neastern Africa and the Horn of Africa.\nFurther details, particularly confirmation (or otherwise) of the\ndiagnosis by a reference laboratory, are soon anticipated. Then OIE\nreference laboratory for RVF is the Onderstepoort Veterinary\nInstitute in South Africa. The NAMRU-3 laboratory in Cairo has been\nhelpful in the early diagnosis of outbreaks in the region. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\n.............................................arn/msp/lm/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "5580-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Dodoma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "11678", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (33): Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=11678", "date": "2007-04-22 15:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (28): TANZANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 21 Apr 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: IPP Media Ltd [edited]\n<http://www.ippmedia.com/ipp/guardian/2007/04/21/88881.html>\n\nTanzania: Rift Valley fever death toll now 89\n-----------------------------------------------\nA total of 89 people have so far died of Rift Valley fever (RVF),\nPrime Minister (PM) Edward Lowassa said yesterday [20 Apr 2007].\nAdjourning the 7th Bunge [parliament] session here yesterday, Lowassa\nsaid out of that number, 56 were from the Dodoma Region. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
