The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "5580-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Dodoma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9872", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (28): Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9872", "date": "2007-04-22 15:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (28): TANZANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 21 Apr 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: IPP Media Ltd [edited]\n<http://www.ippmedia.com/ipp/guardian/2007/04/21/88881.html>\n\nTanzania: Rift Valley fever death toll now 89\n-----------------------------------------------\nA total of 89 people have so far died of Rift Valley fever (RVF),\nPrime Minister (PM) Edward Lowassa said yesterday [20 Apr 2007].\nAdjourning the 7th Bunge [parliament] session here yesterday, Lowassa\nsaid out of that number, 56 were from the Dodoma Region. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. He said the government had\nsuspended cattle auctions and made dipping services compulsory in a\nbid to control the disease.\nThe government will continue with a public education campaign to\neducate people on how to avoid the disease.\n[Byline: Juma Thomas]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Since previous government statements, the human death toll from Rift\nValley fever has increased to 89 from a figure variously given as\n31-37 in early April 2007. It is clear that the outbreak has not yet\nbeen contained and that the Dodoma remains the most severely affected\nregion of Tanzania.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania 20070414.1252\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070323.1020\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070320.0983\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma) 20070315.0908\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania 20070212.0533\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\n1998\n----\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): animal quarantine 19980406.0642\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (03) 19980324.0550\nRift Valley Fever - Tanzania (02) 19980309.0448\nRift Valley fever - Tanzania 19980226.0373\n.......................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "5580-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Dodoma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9719", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (27): Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9719", "date": "2007-03-05 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated,\nsubsequent abortions might cause reluctance of herders to vaccinate or to\ncooperate with the vaccinators. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2153.pdf>.\nThe safer, inactivated, vaccine requires booster vaccinations and is more\nlaborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in non-endemic\nsituations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the commencement of\noutbreaks in endemic regions. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2146.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, suspected 20070304.0753\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Kenya 20070214.0545\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), cattle, sheep,\ngoats, OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n.....................arn/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-01-09 00:00:00", "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-02-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Morogoro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Kilimanjaro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arusha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Onderstepoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9196", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9196", "date": "2007-03-05 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated,\nsubsequent abortions might cause reluctance of herders to vaccinate or to\ncooperate with the vaccinators. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2153.pdf>.\nThe safer, inactivated, vaccine requires booster vaccinations and is more\nlaborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in non-endemic\nsituations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the commencement of\noutbreaks in endemic regions. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2146.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, suspected 20070304.0753\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Kenya 20070214.0545\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), cattle, sheep,\ngoats, OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n.....................arn/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-01-09 00:00:00", "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-02-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Morogoro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Kilimanjaro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arusha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Onderstepoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9147", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (24): Tanzania (Dodoma)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9147", "date": "2007-03-05 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated,\nsubsequent abortions might cause reluctance of herders to vaccinate or to\ncooperate with the vaccinators. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2153.pdf>.\nThe safer, inactivated, vaccine requires booster vaccinations and is more\nlaborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in non-endemic\nsituations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the commencement of\noutbreaks in endemic regions. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2146.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, suspected 20070304.0753\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Kenya 20070214.0545\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), cattle, sheep,\ngoats, OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n.....................arn/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-01-09 00:00:00", "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-02-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Morogoro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Kilimanjaro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arusha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Onderstepoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8883", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (22): Tanzania (Dodoma)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8883", "date": "2007-03-05 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated,\nsubsequent abortions might cause reluctance of herders to vaccinate or to\ncooperate with the vaccinators. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2153.pdf>.\nThe safer, inactivated, vaccine requires booster vaccinations and is more\nlaborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in non-endemic\nsituations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the commencement of\noutbreaks in endemic regions. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2146.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, suspected 20070304.0753\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Kenya 20070214.0545\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), cattle, sheep,\ngoats, OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n.....................arn/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Eastern Africa (21): Kenya, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8700", "date": "2007-03-05 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (20): WILDLIFE, NOT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 5 Mar 2007\nFrom: Kariuki Njenga <KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n\nTests performed on specimens from 8 dead buffalos from Baringo district\n(not Hell's Gate) in Kenya were negative for Rift Valley Fever (RVF).\nBaringo district has reported over 150 human cases of RVF, with 52 of these\nconfirmed by laboratory tests since late January 2007.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of sera from the animals was\nnegative, strongly suggesting that the death was not due to RVF. Serologic\ntesting is ongoing.\n--\nM Kariuki Njenga, PhD\nVirologist and Laboratory Director\nGDD/IEIP-Kenya, Centers for Disease Control\nOffice: +254-20-271-3008; fax 271-4745\nUS Mail: Unit 64112, APO, AE 09831-4112\n<KNjenga@ke.cdc.gov>\n[Dr Kariuki Njenga is gratefully acknowledged for this first-hand\nauthoritative information. The reported results fall in line with Dr Glyn\nDavies' comments, included in ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever -\nEastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp 20070304.0753: \"I spent a great deal of\ntime during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus) epizootic periods in Kenya\nobserving the wild ruminants on properties affected by RVFV in domestic\nanimals and also communicating with cattle and sheep farmers on RVF\naffected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see wild animals grazing\nRVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any clinical disease, which\nmight have been due to RVFV.\"\nRecent coverage of RVF in the animal domain leaves room for improvement.\nWhile humans have been reported to be sick and dying of RVF in Kenya since\nthe beginning of December 2006, the 1st official notification on cases in\nanimals (sheep, goats, cattle, and camels), which reportedly had started on\n4 Dec 2006, were submitted to the Office International des Epizooties (OIE;\nWorld Organisation for Animal Health) from Kenya on 9 Jan 2007; see\nnotification, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4487>.\nHuman cases in Somalia were initially reported on 12 Jan 2007, following\nrumors of abortions in cattle, which have, so far, not been confirmed -- by\nlaboratory tests -- to be related to RVF.\nTanzania reported outbreaks in sheep, goats, and cattle on 12 Feb 2007,\nreportedly having started on18 Jan 2007; see notification, including map,\nat\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=4782>.\nThe 1st human cases were reported from Tanzania at the beginning of\nFebruary 2007, so far without WHO confirmation. For background and past\nexperience, see also Dr Peter Roeder's contribution in ProMED-mail posting\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164.\nDomestic ruminants, namely sheep followed by goats and cattle, are known to\ndemonstrate high susceptibility, manifested by mass abortions while\nmortality in young lambs and kids expected to reach nearly 100 per cent.\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Allafrica.com, Arusha Times [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703040119.html>\n\nDistribution of vaccines against the Rift Valley Fever (RVF) has started in\ninfected areas according to the minister for livestock development, Mr\nAnthony Diallo.\nThe 1st batch of vaccines against the deadly disease arrived from South\nAfrica last Friday [2 Mar 2007]. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. \"The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,\" Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated,\nsubsequent abortions might cause reluctance of herders to vaccinate or to\ncooperate with the vaccinators. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2153.pdf>.\nThe safer, inactivated, vaccine requires booster vaccinations and is more\nlaborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in non-endemic\nsituations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the commencement of\noutbreaks in endemic regions. Directions for use are available at\n<http://bigfive.jl.co.za/pdf_files/p2146.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, suspected 20070304.0753\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine 20070219.0624\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (17): Kenya 20070214.0545\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), cattle, sheep,\ngoats, OIE 20070212.0536\nRift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania 20070206.0465\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\n.....................arn/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. Diagnosis can be made by laboratory tests.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Timely livestock vaccination will reduce economical losses of breeders; it\ncan also be an effective means of preventing cases of human RVF, if\nadequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nThe vaccine obtained by Tanzania from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine produced in Onderstepoort. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-01-09 00:00:00", "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-02-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Morogoro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Kilimanjaro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arusha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Onderstepoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8608", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (19): wildlife, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8608", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nBiosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Despite the more optimistic assessments of international agencies (see:\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (11): Kenya, Somalia 20070131.0398, and\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): Kenya 20070201.0413) local opinion\nis that the outbreak is still spreading.\nAn interactive map of Kenya locating some of the places mentioned in this\nreport can be viewed at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO&pc\nodero/js/mw>, and a map of the administrative districts of Kenya is\navailable at <http://ag.arizona.edu/OALS/ALN/aln57/bruins2.html>. - Eastern Africa (09): Kenya 20070128.0367\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (08): Kenya 20070126.0352\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (07): Somalia, susp. 20070122.0296\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (06): Kenya 20070121.0287\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): Kenya 20070119.0252\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO 20070116.0202\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning 20070115.0197\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20070114.0186\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system 20070111.0112\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province) 20070106.0058\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) (02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marigat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nakuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8199", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (18): Kenya, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8199", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marigat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nakuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7661", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (16): Tanzania (Arusha), OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7661", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nBiosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Despite the more optimistic assessments of international agencies (see:\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (11): Kenya, Somalia 20070131.0398, and\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): Kenya 20070201.0413) local opinion\nis that the outbreak is still spreading.\nAn interactive map of Kenya locating some of the places mentioned in this\nreport can be viewed at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO&pc\nodero/js/mw>, and a map of the administrative districts of Kenya is\navailable at <http://ag.arizona.edu/OALS/ALN/aln57/bruins2.html>. - Eastern Africa (09): Kenya 20070128.0367\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (08): Kenya 20070126.0352\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (07): Somalia, susp. 20070122.0296\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (06): Kenya 20070121.0287\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (05): Kenya 20070119.0252\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO 20070116.0202\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning 20070115.0197\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20070114.0186\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system 20070111.0112\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province) 20070106.0058\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) (02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
