For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marigat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nakuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7664", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (15): Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7664", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nBiosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Despite the more optimistic assessments of international agencies (see:\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (11): Kenya, Somalia 20070131.0398, and\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): Kenya 20070201.0413) local opinion\nis that the outbreak is still spreading.\nAn interactive map of Kenya locating some of the places mentioned in this\nreport can be viewed at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO&pc\nodero/js/mw>, and a map of the administrative districts of Kenya is\navailable at <http://ag.arizona.edu/OALS/ALN/aln57/bruins2.html>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marigat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nakuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7393", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, East Africa (14): Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7393", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist,\nBiosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation\nRockville MD 20852\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Despite the more optimistic assessments of international agencies (see:\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (11): Kenya, Somalia 20070131.0398, and\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (12): Kenya 20070201.0413) local opinion\nis that the outbreak is still spreading.\nAn interactive map of Kenya locating some of the places mentioned in this\nreport can be viewed at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO&pc\nodero/js/mw>, and a map of the administrative districts of Kenya is\navailable at <http://ag.arizona.edu/OALS/ALN/aln57/bruins2.html>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Marigat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nakuru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baringo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7307", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (13): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7307", "date": "2007-02-03 18:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (13): KENYA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The East African Standard (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702021002.html>\n\nSixteen people have died of Rift Valley fever in Baringo, Maragua and Taita\nTaveta districts. Eleven died in Marigat, Baringo District, while 5 others\ndied in Taita, Taveta and Maragua districts, veterinary officers said on\nFri 2 Feb 2007. This brings the death toll from the disease to 150 since\nthe 1st case was reported in North-Eastern Province in January 2007.\nPanic gripped Baringo residents as more people succumbed to the disease and\nseveral patients were admitted to hospital. Veterinary officers have\nimposed quarantine and ordered all butcheries closed after 2 more people\ndied on Thursday night. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. \"We have confirmed 4\ndeaths arising from the disease after samples we sent to the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI) tested positive,\" said Randall. Randall said a\nStandard Five pupil died while undergoing treatment at the Moi Teaching and\nReferral Hospital while a middle-aged woman died at home.\nNgambo location chief, Mr Joseph Lenasheku, said many people were unable to\nreach hospital due to heavy rains that rendered roads impassable. The body\nof a 32-year-old woman, who died after feasting on meat from a dead sheep,\ncould not be taken to the mortuary due to the bad state of the roads.\nIn Nakuru, butcheries continued to suffer losses as residents avoided meat\nfearing to contract Rift Valley fever. The manager of Gilanis Butchery, Mr\nS A Haji said sales have since gone down. However, he assured his customers\nthat the meat was inspected and stamped by certified Government officers.\nMr Samson Keitany, a supervisor with Hygienic Butchery, said business had\nbeen bad in the last 2 weeks. Keitany said he reduced his order to one cow\na week from 3. Gladys Njeri of Village Park Butchery said she reduced her\norders to 2 goats per day from 5. Butchers urged the Government to step up\nvaccination and public awareness campaigns.\nIn Taita Taveta, 2 more people have succumbed to the disease. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. The Taita Taveta District medical officer of health, Dr Shem\nPatta, said the victims died of a disease with symptoms similar to Rift\nValley fever. Dr Patta said one of those who died was treated in Tanzania\nbut died on return. The MOH said goats and cows were reportedly dying of an\nunidentified disease. Patta said samples had been taken to KEMRI for\nanalysis. He said unrestricted movement in Taita could fan the rapid spread\nof the disease. \"We have set up an isolation ward in all public health\nfacilities, equipped workers with protective gear, and notified them of the\nlatest outbreak,\" said Dr Patta. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. Samples have been taken\nto Nairobi for tests.\nIn Maragua 3 more cases of the deadly fever have been reported. The Senior\nDeputy Director of Medical Services, Mr Shanaz Sharif, said the samples\ntaken to KEMRI tested positive while those taken to Kirinyaga District\nHospital tested negative.\n[Byline: Peter Mutai And Winnie Chumo]\n--\nJoseph P. Eastern Africa (12): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7230", "date": "2007-01-19 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (05): KENYA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 18 Jan 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Reuters Health eLine [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/en/index.html>\n\nKenya: Rift Valley fever death toll rises to 95\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe death toll from the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in Kenya has risen to\n95 people, a government spokesman said on Thu [18 Jan 2007]. The contagious\ndisease hit remote areas of Kenya's North East and Coastal provinces in\nmid-December 2006 and has since spread to neighboring Somalia. The country\nhas recorded nearly 60 new human infections since the end of last week.\n\"The government has already spent 100 million shillings [USD 1.43 million]\nto provide medical care for affected areas, and 2 million heads of cattle\nhave already been vaccinated,\" Alfred Mutua, the government's spokesman\ntold a news conference. Health officials at the Kenyan Dadaab refugee camp,\na densely populated camp near the border with Somalia, said 29 cases,\nincluding 5 deaths, had been reported by Thu [18 Jan 2007].\nThe disease is transmitted to humans through mosquito bites or frequent\ncontact with contaminated animals. Although transmission from animals to\nhumans is rare, the disease develops into a much more severe illness once\nit crosses over, causing victims to abort, vomit blood or bleed to death.\nThe government asked people to avoid contact with animals, especially cows,\nto use mosquito nets and to take extra care with their personal hygiene. A\nsimilar outbreak in 1997-1998 killed hundreds of people in Kenya.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\n<joseph.p.dudley@saic.com>\n[The human death toll has increased from 82 recorded on Fri 12 Jan 2007 to\n95 on Thu 18 Jan 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO 20070116.0202\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning 20070115.0197\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20070114.0186\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system 20070111.0112\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province) 20070106.0058\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) (02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n---\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n.................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The contagious\ndisease hit remote areas of Kenya's North East and Coastal provinces in\nmid-December 2006 and has since spread to neighboring Somalia. The country\nhas recorded nearly 60 new human infections since the end of last week.\n\"The government has already spent 100 million shillings [USD 1.43 million]\nto provide medical care for affected areas, and 2 million heads of cattle\nhave already been vaccinated,\" Alfred Mutua, the government's spokesman\ntold a news conference. Although transmission from animals to\nhumans is rare, the disease develops into a much more severe illness once\nit crosses over, causing victims to abort, vomit blood or bleed to death.\nThe government asked people to avoid contact with animals, especially cows,\nto use mosquito nets and to take extra care with their personal hygiene. A\nsimilar outbreak in 1997-1998 killed hundreds of people in Kenya.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\n<joseph.p.dudley@saic.com>\n[The human death toll has increased from 82 recorded on Fri 12 Jan 2007 to\n95 on Thu 18 Jan 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO 20070116.0202\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning 20070115.0197\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20070114.0186\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system 20070111.0112\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province) 20070106.0058\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) (02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n---\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n.................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7053", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (09): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7053", "date": "2007-01-19 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (05): KENYA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 18 Jan 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Reuters Health eLine [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/en/index.html>\n\nKenya: Rift Valley fever death toll rises to 95\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe death toll from the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in Kenya has risen to\n95 people, a government spokesman said on Thu [18 Jan 2007]. The contagious\ndisease hit remote areas of Kenya's North East and Coastal provinces in\nmid-December 2006 and has since spread to neighboring Somalia. The country\nhas recorded nearly 60 new human infections since the end of last week.\n\"The government has already spent 100 million shillings [USD 1.43 million]\nto provide medical care for affected areas, and 2 million heads of cattle\nhave already been vaccinated,\" Alfred Mutua, the government's spokesman\ntold a news conference. Health officials at the Kenyan Dadaab refugee camp,\na densely populated camp near the border with Somalia, said 29 cases,\nincluding 5 deaths, had been reported by Thu [18 Jan 2007].\nThe disease is transmitted to humans through mosquito bites or frequent\ncontact with contaminated animals. Although transmission from animals to\nhumans is rare, the disease develops into a much more severe illness once\nit crosses over, causing victims to abort, vomit blood or bleed to death.\nThe government asked people to avoid contact with animals, especially cows,\nto use mosquito nets and to take extra care with their personal hygiene. A\nsimilar outbreak in 1997-1998 killed hundreds of people in Kenya.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\n<joseph.p.dudley@saic.com>\n[The human death toll has increased from 82 recorded on Fri 12 Jan 2007 to\n95 on Thu 18 Jan 2007. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO 20070116.0202\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning 20070115.0197\nRift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya 20070114.0186\nRift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164\nRift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE 20070111.0118\nRift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system 20070111.0112\nRift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI 20070109.0092\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province) 20070106.0058\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) (02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n---\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n.................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province)(02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n1998\n----\nObituary: Louise Martin, CDC (Nairobi) (02) 19980811.1577\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (07) 19981228.2447\nRift Valley fever - Kenya 19980721.1373\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (04) 19980413.0676\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Nairobi) 19980217.0309\nRift Valley fever - Kenya and Somalia (03) 19980131.0200\n.......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6653", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6618", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa (02): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6618", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province)(02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n1998\n----\nObituary: Louise Martin, CDC (Nairobi) (02) 19980811.1577\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (07) 19981228.2447\nRift Valley fever - Kenya 19980721.1373\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (04) 19980413.0676\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Nairobi) 19980217.0309\nRift Valley fever - Kenya and Somalia (03) 19980131.0200\n.......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6564", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6564", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province)(02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n1998\n----\nObituary: Louise Martin, CDC (Nairobi) (02) 19980811.1577\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (07) 19981228.2447\nRift Valley fever - Kenya 19980721.1373\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (04) 19980413.0676\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Nairobi) 19980217.0309\nRift Valley fever - Kenya and Somalia (03) 19980131.0200\n.......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6486", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, ruminants - Kenya: OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6486", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor.
