If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6478", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Kenya: early warning system", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6478", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province)(02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n1998\n----\nObituary: Louise Martin, CDC (Nairobi) (02) 19980811.1577\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (07) 19981228.2447\nRift Valley fever - Kenya 19980721.1373\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (04) 19980413.0676\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Nairobi) 19980217.0309\nRift Valley fever - Kenya and Somalia (03) 19980131.0200\n.......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6441", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-12-23 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "2006-12-07 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-01-04 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ijara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENYA", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kilifi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garissa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Eastern", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Coast Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6378", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6378", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n\"The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,\" explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, \"but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.\"\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n\"Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,\" continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n\"Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.\"\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. \"This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,\" concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. Dr. Sharif also\nreports that the outbreak is now affecting 2 districts of the Coast\nProvince of Kenya as well as the initial 3 districts of North Eastern\nprovince (see map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kenya-relief-map-towns.jpg>.\nPreliminary data suggest that unusually the disease is spreading in the\nhuman population through the consumption of raw milk from sick animals and\nthat transmission by mosquitoes may not yet be a determining factor. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province)(02) 20070103.0019\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (North Eastern Province) 20070101.0004\n2006\n----\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa) (05) 20061228.3643\nRift valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(03): WHO 20061228.3630\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf. 20061223.3590\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa): conf. 20061222.3584\nViral hemorrhagic fever - Kenya (Garissa): susp 20061221.3578\n2004\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(09): OIE 20041003.2723\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE 20031122.2901\nRift Valley Fever - Mauritania: OIE 20031020.2635\nRift Valley fever, human - Egypt (02) 20030902.2205\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n1998\n----\nObituary: Louise Martin, CDC (Nairobi) (02) 19980811.1577\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (07) 19981228.2447\nRift Valley fever - Kenya 19980721.1373\nRift Valley fever - Kenya & Somalia (04) 19980413.0676\nRift Valley fever - Kenya (Nairobi) 19980217.0309\nRift Valley fever - Kenya and Somalia (03) 19980131.0200\n.......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. M. Al Fadhl,\nDirector of Animal Quarantine, Ministry of Agriculture, Riyadh:\nDate of the report: 18 Sep 2004.\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory.\nEstimated date of primary infection: 28 Apr 2004.\nDuring routine serosurveillance for Rift Valley fever, in Jizan region, 5\nseropositive cases were detected in 4 sheep flocks, without any clinical\nevidence either on the positive cases or on the contact animals.\nDiagnosis:\nA. Laboratory where diagnosis was made: Jizan Laboratory.\nB. Diagnostic tests used: four ovines were IgM ELISA positive and the 5th\none was an IgG ELISA positive sentinel animal.\nSource of agent / origin of infection: unknown.\nControl measures:\n- control of arthropods;\n- vaccination;\n- quarantine;\n- screening.\n--\nProMED-mail0\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although this report provides more information tending to confirm the\noccurrence of Rift Valley Fever at some time, more details on further\nsurveillance testing and current follow-up epidemiologic investigation\nwould be most beneficial. - Mod.PC]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(03) 20040911.2531\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(04): susp. 20040912.2538\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(05): susp. 20040919.2594\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(06): susp. 20040925.2646\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(07): susp. 20040927.2669\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(08): susp. 20040928.2685\n..................pc/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "brucellosis", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2004-09-29 00:00:00", "2004-09-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jizan)(07", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6125", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6125", "date": "2004-10-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER- SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN) (09): OIE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 2 Oct, 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 1 Oct 2004 Vol. 17 - No. 40 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec3>\n\nRift Valley fever in Saudi Arabia -- Serological findings\nEmergency report\nInformation received on 29 Sep 2004 from Dr Abdulghaniy Y. M. Al Fadhl,\nDirector of Animal Quarantine, Ministry of Agriculture, Riyadh:\nDate of the report: 18 Sep 2004.\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory.\nEstimated date of primary infection: 28 Apr 2004.\nDuring routine serosurveillance for Rift Valley fever, in Jizan region, 5\nseropositive cases were detected in 4 sheep flocks, without any clinical\nevidence either on the positive cases or on the contact animals.\nDiagnosis:\nA. Laboratory where diagnosis was made: Jizan Laboratory.\nB. Diagnostic tests used: four ovines were IgM ELISA positive and the 5th\none was an IgG ELISA positive sentinel animal.\nSource of agent / origin of infection: unknown.\nControl measures:\n- control of arthropods;\n- vaccination;\n- quarantine;\n- screening.\n--\nProMED-mail0\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although this report provides more information tending to confirm the\noccurrence of Rift Valley Fever at some time, more details on further\nsurveillance testing and current follow-up epidemiologic investigation\nwould be most beneficial. - Mod.PC]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(03) 20040911.2531\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(04): susp. 20040912.2538\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(05): susp. 20040919.2594\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(06): susp. 20040925.2646\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(07): susp. 20040927.2669\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(08): susp. 20040928.2685\n..................pc/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. M. Al Fadhl,\nDirector of Animal Quarantine, Ministry of Agriculture, Riyadh:\nDate of the report: 18 Sep 2004.\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory.\nEstimated date of primary infection: 28 Apr 2004.\nDuring routine serosurveillance for Rift Valley fever, in Jizan region, 5\nseropositive cases were detected in 4 sheep flocks, without any clinical\nevidence either on the positive cases or on the contact animals.\nDiagnosis:\nA. Diagnostic tests used: four ovines were IgM ELISA positive and the 5th\none was an IgG ELISA positive sentinel animal.\nSource of agent / origin of infection: unknown.\nControl measures:\n- control of arthropods;\n- vaccination;\n- quarantine;\n- screening.\n--\nProMED-mail0\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although this report provides more information tending to confirm the\noccurrence of Rift Valley Fever at some time, more details on further\nsurveillance testing and current follow-up epidemiologic investigation\nwould be most beneficial. - Mod.PC]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(03) 20040911.2531\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(04): susp. 20040912.2538\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(05): susp. 20040919.2594\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(06): susp. 20040925.2646\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(07): susp. 20040927.2669\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(08): susp. 20040928.2685\n..................pc/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "brucellosis", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2004-09-29 00:00:00", "2004-09-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jizan)(07", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206649", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(08): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206649", "date": "2004-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN)(03)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 11 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\nSource: Arab News, 11 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51334&d=11&m=9&y=2004>\n\nNo RVF Cases Among Humans\n-------------------------\nNo Rift Valley Fever (RVF) cases have so far been reported among\nhumans in the southern Jizan region, the Health Ministry announced\nyesterday.\n\"We have inspected all patients admitted to King Fahd Hospital in\nJizan and the General Hospital in Aaridha. We did not find any\nsuspected RVF cases among them,\" said Dr. Tariq ibn Ahmed Madani, an\ninternist and adviser to Health Minister Dr. Hamad Al-Manie.\nMadani was a member of the ministry's team who recently visited the\nregion on the instructions of Al-Manie following reports that 5\nanimals in the region tested positive for the deadly virus.\nDr. Yaaqub Al-Mazroue, assistant deputy health minister for\npreventive medicine, also visited Jizan soon after reports of fresh\nRVF outbreak in the region.\nMazroue inspected the arrangements made by the Health Ministry to\nprevent the spread of the disease as well as the progress of work at\ndisease combat centers. Madani said his team checked all the files\nof patients admitted at Jizan hospitals for the past 3 months to make\nsure whether they were infected with RVF virus or not. The team also\nvisited the laboratory of the Agriculture Ministry and met with\nveterinarians and other experts there as well as the areas where the\n5 cases were reported.\n\"The results of field trips and clinical tests have proved that there\nare no suspected RVF cases among humans in the region,\" the Saudi\nPress Agency quoted Madani as saying.\nMadani also said there were no deaths or abortions among cattle in\nthe region as a result of the RVF outbreak. He said the numbers of\nmosquitoes had been brought down as a result of continuous spraying\nof insecticides. \"We have also intensified health awareness campaign\namong the people of Jizan,\" the official said, adding that the\nauthorities had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the\ndisease.\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim reported on Monday that 5\nanimals in Jizan (4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah) tested positive\nfor RVF during periodic examinations. \"These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,\" Balghaneim said.\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time and can surface whenever it finds a hospitable environment.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions before they spread to other parts of the\nKingdom.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in\nhumans, in whom it leads to high morbidity and mortality.\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Most of the people\ninvolved were farmers, farm laborers, and abattoir personnel. Similar\nobservations were made during the 1977/78 major outbreak in Egypt,\nthough vector transmission there became more significant than before.\nExposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. This was one of the concerns of the Saudi authorities in\n2000, in view of the massive slaughtering of ruminants during the\nMoslem holidays. Such a situation might recur during the coming Eid\nal-Fitr holiday, also called Eid al Zeghir (minor festival). Eid\nal-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting,\nand is celebrated during the first 3 days of Shawwal, the 10th month\nof the Islamic calendar. During these days, house slaughtering of\nruminants, mainly sheep and goats, is widely practiced, especially in\nrural areas. Eid al-Fitr is due this year on 14-15 November -- a\nseason characterised by intense vector activity in the Near East.\nVector control activities might help, but timely mass vaccination of\nsusceptible ruminants is essential in order to prevent the\nestablishment of RVF in animals and the subsequent public health\nhazard. - Mod.AS]\n[It is not at all clear that this is an outbreak, yet. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Abu Areesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206641", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(07): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206641", "date": "2004-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN)(03)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 11 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\nSource: Arab News, 11 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51334&d=11&m=9&y=2004>\n\nNo RVF Cases Among Humans\n-------------------------\nNo Rift Valley Fever (RVF) cases have so far been reported among\nhumans in the southern Jizan region, the Health Ministry announced\nyesterday.\n\"We have inspected all patients admitted to King Fahd Hospital in\nJizan and the General Hospital in Aaridha. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Abu Areesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206638", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(07): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206638", "date": "2004-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN)(03)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 11 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\nSource: Arab News, 11 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51334&d=11&m=9&y=2004>\n\nNo RVF Cases Among Humans\n-------------------------\nNo Rift Valley Fever (RVF) cases have so far been reported among\nhumans in the southern Jizan region, the Health Ministry announced\nyesterday.\n\"We have inspected all patients admitted to King Fahd Hospital in\nJizan and the General Hospital in Aaridha. We did not find any\nsuspected RVF cases among them,\" said Dr. Tariq ibn Ahmed Madani, an\ninternist and adviser to Health Minister Dr. Hamad Al-Manie.\nMadani was a member of the ministry's team who recently visited the\nregion on the instructions of Al-Manie following reports that 5\nanimals in the region tested positive for the deadly virus.\nDr. Yaaqub Al-Mazroue, assistant deputy health minister for\npreventive medicine, also visited Jizan soon after reports of fresh\nRVF outbreak in the region.\nMazroue inspected the arrangements made by the Health Ministry to\nprevent the spread of the disease as well as the progress of work at\ndisease combat centers. Madani said his team checked all the files\nof patients admitted at Jizan hospitals for the past 3 months to make\nsure whether they were infected with RVF virus or not. The team also\nvisited the laboratory of the Agriculture Ministry and met with\nveterinarians and other experts there as well as the areas where the\n5 cases were reported.\n\"The results of field trips and clinical tests have proved that there\nare no suspected RVF cases among humans in the region,\" the Saudi\nPress Agency quoted Madani as saying.\nMadani also said there were no deaths or abortions among cattle in\nthe region as a result of the RVF outbreak. He said the numbers of\nmosquitoes had been brought down as a result of continuous spraying\nof insecticides. \"We have also intensified health awareness campaign\namong the people of Jizan,\" the official said, adding that the\nauthorities had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the\ndisease.\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim reported on Monday that 5\nanimals in Jizan (4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah) tested positive\nfor RVF during periodic examinations. \"These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,\" Balghaneim said.\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time and can surface whenever it finds a hospitable environment.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions before they spread to other parts of the\nKingdom.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in\nhumans, in whom it leads to high morbidity and mortality.\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Most of the people\ninvolved were farmers, farm laborers, and abattoir personnel. Similar\nobservations were made during the 1977/78 major outbreak in Egypt,\nthough vector transmission there became more significant than before.\nExposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. This was one of the concerns of the Saudi authorities in\n2000, in view of the massive slaughtering of ruminants during the\nMoslem holidays. Such a situation might recur during the coming Eid\nal-Fitr holiday, also called Eid al Zeghir (minor festival). Eid\nal-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting,\nand is celebrated during the first 3 days of Shawwal, the 10th month\nof the Islamic calendar. During these days, house slaughtering of\nruminants, mainly sheep and goats, is widely practiced, especially in\nrural areas. Eid al-Fitr is due this year on 14-15 November -- a\nseason characterised by intense vector activity in the Near East.\nVector control activities might help, but timely mass vaccination of\nsusceptible ruminants is essential in order to prevent the\nestablishment of RVF in animals and the subsequent public health\nhazard. - Mod.AS]\n[It is not at all clear that this is an outbreak, yet. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Abu Areesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206624", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(06): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206624", "date": "2004-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN)(03)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 11 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\nSource: Arab News, 11 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51334&d=11&m=9&y=2004>\n\nNo RVF Cases Among Humans\n-------------------------\nNo Rift Valley Fever (RVF) cases have so far been reported among\nhumans in the southern Jizan region, the Health Ministry announced\nyesterday.\n\"We have inspected all patients admitted to King Fahd Hospital in\nJizan and the General Hospital in Aaridha. We did not find any\nsuspected RVF cases among them,\" said Dr. Tariq ibn Ahmed Madani, an\ninternist and adviser to Health Minister Dr. Hamad Al-Manie.\nMadani was a member of the ministry's team who recently visited the\nregion on the instructions of Al-Manie following reports that 5\nanimals in the region tested positive for the deadly virus.\nDr. Yaaqub Al-Mazroue, assistant deputy health minister for\npreventive medicine, also visited Jizan soon after reports of fresh\nRVF outbreak in the region.\nMazroue inspected the arrangements made by the Health Ministry to\nprevent the spread of the disease as well as the progress of work at\ndisease combat centers. Madani said his team checked all the files\nof patients admitted at Jizan hospitals for the past 3 months to make\nsure whether they were infected with RVF virus or not. The team also\nvisited the laboratory of the Agriculture Ministry and met with\nveterinarians and other experts there as well as the areas where the\n5 cases were reported.\n\"The results of field trips and clinical tests have proved that there\nare no suspected RVF cases among humans in the region,\" the Saudi\nPress Agency quoted Madani as saying.\nMadani also said there were no deaths or abortions among cattle in\nthe region as a result of the RVF outbreak. He said the numbers of\nmosquitoes had been brought down as a result of continuous spraying\nof insecticides. \"We have also intensified health awareness campaign\namong the people of Jizan,\" the official said, adding that the\nauthorities had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the\ndisease.\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim reported on Monday that 5\nanimals in Jizan (4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah) tested positive\nfor RVF during periodic examinations. \"These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,\" Balghaneim said.\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time and can surface whenever it finds a hospitable environment.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions before they spread to other parts of the\nKingdom.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in\nhumans, in whom it leads to high morbidity and mortality.\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Most of the people\ninvolved were farmers, farm laborers, and abattoir personnel. Similar\nobservations were made during the 1977/78 major outbreak in Egypt,\nthough vector transmission there became more significant than before.\nExposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. This was one of the concerns of the Saudi authorities in\n2000, in view of the massive slaughtering of ruminants during the\nMoslem holidays. Such a situation might recur during the coming Eid\nal-Fitr holiday, also called Eid al Zeghir (minor festival). Eid\nal-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting,\nand is celebrated during the first 3 days of Shawwal, the 10th month\nof the Islamic calendar. During these days, house slaughtering of\nruminants, mainly sheep and goats, is widely practiced, especially in\nrural areas. Eid al-Fitr is due this year on 14-15 November -- a\nseason characterised by intense vector activity in the Near East.\nVector control activities might help, but timely mass vaccination of\nsusceptible ruminants is essential in order to prevent the\nestablishment of RVF in animals and the subsequent public health\nhazard. - Mod.AS]\n[It is not at all clear that this is an outbreak, yet. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Abu Areesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206536", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206536", "date": "2004-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN)(03)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 11 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\nSource: Arab News, 11 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51334&d=11&m=9&y=2004>\n\nNo RVF Cases Among Humans\n-------------------------\nNo Rift Valley Fever (RVF) cases have so far been reported among\nhumans in the southern Jizan region, the Health Ministry announced\nyesterday.\n\"We have inspected all patients admitted to King Fahd Hospital in\nJizan and the General Hospital in Aaridha. We did not find any\nsuspected RVF cases among them,\" said Dr. Tariq ibn Ahmed Madani, an\ninternist and adviser to Health Minister Dr. Hamad Al-Manie.\nMadani was a member of the ministry's team who recently visited the\nregion on the instructions of Al-Manie following reports that 5\nanimals in the region tested positive for the deadly virus.\nDr. Yaaqub Al-Mazroue, assistant deputy health minister for\npreventive medicine, also visited Jizan soon after reports of fresh\nRVF outbreak in the region.\nMazroue inspected the arrangements made by the Health Ministry to\nprevent the spread of the disease as well as the progress of work at\ndisease combat centers. Madani said his team checked all the files\nof patients admitted at Jizan hospitals for the past 3 months to make\nsure whether they were infected with RVF virus or not. The team also\nvisited the laboratory of the Agriculture Ministry and met with\nveterinarians and other experts there as well as the areas where the\n5 cases were reported.\n\"The results of field trips and clinical tests have proved that there\nare no suspected RVF cases among humans in the region,\" the Saudi\nPress Agency quoted Madani as saying.\nMadani also said there were no deaths or abortions among cattle in\nthe region as a result of the RVF outbreak. He said the numbers of\nmosquitoes had been brought down as a result of continuous spraying\nof insecticides. \"We have also intensified health awareness campaign\namong the people of Jizan,\" the official said, adding that the\nauthorities had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the\ndisease.\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim reported on Monday that 5\nanimals in Jizan (4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah) tested positive\nfor RVF during periodic examinations. \"These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,\" Balghaneim said.\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time and can surface whenever it finds a hospitable environment.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions before they spread to other parts of the\nKingdom.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in\nhumans, in whom it leads to high morbidity and mortality.\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Most of the people\ninvolved were farmers, farm laborers, and abattoir personnel. Similar\nobservations were made during the 1977/78 major outbreak in Egypt,\nthough vector transmission there became more significant than before.\nExposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. This was one of the concerns of the Saudi authorities in\n2000, in view of the massive slaughtering of ruminants during the\nMoslem holidays. Such a situation might recur during the coming Eid\nal-Fitr holiday, also called Eid al Zeghir (minor festival). Eid\nal-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting,\nand is celebrated during the first 3 days of Shawwal, the 10th month\nof the Islamic calendar. During these days, house slaughtering of\nruminants, mainly sheep and goats, is widely practiced, especially in\nrural areas. Eid al-Fitr is due this year on 14-15 November -- a\nseason characterised by intense vector activity in the Near East.\nVector control activities might help, but timely mass vaccination of\nsusceptible ruminants is essential in order to prevent the\nestablishment of RVF in animals and the subsequent public health\nhazard. - Mod.AS]\n[It is not at all clear that this is an outbreak, yet. Dr Madani is quoted as\nsaying \"5 animals in Jizan... tested positive for RVF during periodic\nexaminations.\" This was presumably a serological test for antibody, which the\nanimals concerned -- depending on their ages -- might well have acquired from\nan infection in the 2001 epidemic, or they could have been imported from a\nneighboring country (such as Yemen) suffering from an unrecognised outbreak.\nThe lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02) 20040908.2504\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected 20040907.2500\n2003\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: alert 20031016.2612\nRift valley fever, prevention - Saudi Arabia 20031003.2489\nRift Valley fever - Egypt 20030827.2158\n2001\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n..........................arn/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206509", "date": "2003-08-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EGYPT\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Alert Net, 24 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L24631547.htm>\n\nDoctors say 33 die of Rift Valley fever in Egypt\n------------------------------------------------\nCAIRO: Some 33 people in the Nile Delta governorate of Kafr el-Sheikh have\ndied of Rift Valley fever, a viral disease which affects humans as well as\nlivestock, doctors in the region said on Sunday.\n\nThe news comes about a week after Health and Population Minister Mohamed\nAwad Afifi Tag el-Din said an outbreak of the fever in Kafr el-Sheikh had\nbeen brought under control, after 4 out of 35 people diagnosed with the\nfever had died.\n\nMedical sources in the governorate could not say on Sunday how many people\nin the province had caught the disease so far.\n\nRift Valley fever is primarily transmitted to humans through mosquito\nbites, and is particularly common during years with unusually heavy\nrainfall. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. AS].\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\nRift Valley fever, humans - Chad: Aug 2001 20020412.3941\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n2001\n----\nRift valley fever, livestock - Mali 20010409.0698\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20010107.0058\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20010115.0116\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20010111.0091\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20010113.0102\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20000917.1592\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen (10) 20001031.1901\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (17) 20001218.2216\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\nRift Valley fever - Yemen 20000920.1625\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (06) 20001203.2106\n....................arn/dk/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-07-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr el - Sheikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phlebovirus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205645", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: restrictions lifted", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205645", "date": "2003-08-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EGYPT\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Alert Net, 24 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L24631547.htm>\n\nDoctors say 33 die of Rift Valley fever in Egypt\n------------------------------------------------\nCAIRO: Some 33 people in the Nile Delta governorate of Kafr el-Sheikh have\ndied of Rift Valley fever, a viral disease which affects humans as well as\nlivestock, doctors in the region said on Sunday.\n\nThe news comes about a week after Health and Population Minister Mohamed\nAwad Afifi Tag el-Din said an outbreak of the fever in Kafr el-Sheikh had\nbeen brought under control, after 4 out of 35 people diagnosed with the\nfever had died.\n\nMedical sources in the governorate could not say on Sunday how many people\nin the province had caught the disease so far.\n\nRift Valley fever is primarily transmitted to humans through mosquito\nbites, and is particularly common during years with unusually heavy\nrainfall. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. AS].\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\nRift Valley fever, humans - Chad: Aug 2001 20020412.3941\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n2001\n----\nRift valley fever, livestock - Mali 20010409.0698\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20010107.0058\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20010115.0116\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20010111.0091\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20010113.0102\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20000917.1592\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen (10) 20001031.1901\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (17) 20001218.2216\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\nRift Valley fever - Yemen 20000920.1625\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (06) 20001203.2106\n....................arn/dk/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
