For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-07-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr el - Sheikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phlebovirus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204933", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204933", "date": "2003-08-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EGYPT\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Alert Net, 24 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L24631547.htm>\n\nDoctors say 33 die of Rift Valley fever in Egypt\n------------------------------------------------\nCAIRO: Some 33 people in the Nile Delta governorate of Kafr el-Sheikh have\ndied of Rift Valley fever, a viral disease which affects humans as well as\nlivestock, doctors in the region said on Sunday.\n\nThe news comes about a week after Health and Population Minister Mohamed\nAwad Afifi Tag el-Din said an outbreak of the fever in Kafr el-Sheikh had\nbeen brought under control, after 4 out of 35 people diagnosed with the\nfever had died.\n\nMedical sources in the governorate could not say on Sunday how many people\nin the province had caught the disease so far.\n\nRift Valley fever is primarily transmitted to humans through mosquito\nbites, and is particularly common during years with unusually heavy\nrainfall. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. AS].\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\nRift Valley fever, humans - Chad: Aug 2001 20020412.3941\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n2001\n----\nRift valley fever, livestock - Mali 20010409.0698\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20010107.0058\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20010115.0116\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20010111.0091\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20010113.0102\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20000917.1592\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen (10) 20001031.1901\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (17) 20001218.2216\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\nRift Valley fever - Yemen 20000920.1625\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (06) 20001203.2106\n....................arn/dk/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-07-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yemen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kafr el - Sheikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phlebovirus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204462", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Egypt", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204462", "date": "2003-08-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EGYPT\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Alert Net, 24 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L24631547.htm>\n\nDoctors say 33 die of Rift Valley fever in Egypt\n------------------------------------------------\nCAIRO: Some 33 people in the Nile Delta governorate of Kafr el-Sheikh have\ndied of Rift Valley fever, a viral disease which affects humans as well as\nlivestock, doctors in the region said on Sunday.\n\nThe news comes about a week after Health and Population Minister Mohamed\nAwad Afifi Tag el-Din said an outbreak of the fever in Kafr el-Sheikh had\nbeen brought under control, after 4 out of 35 people diagnosed with the\nfever had died.\n\nMedical sources in the governorate could not say on Sunday how many people\nin the province had caught the disease so far.\n\nRift Valley fever is primarily transmitted to humans through mosquito\nbites, and is particularly common during years with unusually heavy\nrainfall. Saudi Arabia, an importer of Egyptian livestock, has announced a\ntemporary ban on the import of live goats, sheep, camels and gazelles from\nEgypt due to reports of the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants in Africa. It is caused by a single serotype of a\nmosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The last Egyptian reporting to the OIE on the\noccurrence of RVF in animals was in July 1993; mass vaccinations in\nruminants are carried out annually, their number in 2001 reaching 5 994\n818. The main vector in Egypt was reported to be _Culex pipiens_. During\n2000/2001, the disease spread, most probably from the Horn of Africa, into\nYemen and Saudi Arabia.\n\nInformation on the occurrence of the disease in domestic ruminants in Egypt\nwill be useful. - Mod. AS].\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE 20030105.0034\n2002\n----\nRift Valley fever, human - Mauritania (Gorgol) 20021129.5927\nRift Valley fever, humans - Chad: Aug 2001 20020412.3941\nRift Valley fever, sheep, goat - Senegal: OIE (02) 20021226.6130\nRift Valley fever, sheep and goat - Senegal: OIE 20021221.6107\n2001\n----\nRift valley fever, livestock - Mali 20010409.0698\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20010107.0058\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20010115.0116\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20010111.0091\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (03) 20010113.0102\n2000\n----\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20000917.1592\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20000925.1652\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen (10) 20001031.1901\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20000921.1635\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (17) 20001218.2216\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: WHO confirmation 20000919.1612\nRift Valley fever - Yemen 20000920.1625\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (06) 20001203.2106\n....................arn/dk/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Sheikh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Phlebovirus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203124", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, livestock, human - Mauritania: OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203124", "date": "2001-07-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - IRAQ: UNCONFIRMED\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nRift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk 20010717.1386\nRift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia 20010107.0058\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia & Yemen 20010115.0116\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02) 20010111.0091\nRift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (08) 20010517.0964\n[1\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 18:05:19 +0300\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@zajil.net>\nSource: Arab News 21 Jul 2001\n\nSteps taken to check RVF recurrence\n-------------------------------\nAuthorities have taken intensive measures to prevent recurrence of\nRift Valley Fever in the Kingdom after reports that the deadly disease\nhas appeared in neighboring Iraq.\nHealth Minister Dr. Osama Shubokshi told Arab News that he had\ninstructed the agency for preventive medicine to closely follow up the\nsituation. The Kingdom shares a 814-km-long border with its\nnortheastern neighbor.\nThe disease has killed 120 people out of a total of 863 infected cases\nin the Kingdom since September [2000. It also caused a large number\nof animal deaths in southwestern parts of the country.\nAbdul Aziz Saad Al-Shathry, undersecretary at the Agriculture\nMinistry, said the Kingdom had banned import of cattle from many\ncountries as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of RVF,\nfoot-and-mouth disease and Nile fever [sic. The measures helped to\nbring the disease under control.\nDr. Omar Hashim, acting director of animal and botanical quarantine at\nthe ministry, said the Kingdom had not received any official\nconfirmation from international organizations regarding the RVF\noutbreak in Iraq. However, he said quarantine agencies along the\nborder were closely monitoring the situation and with the support of\nborder guards would prevent smuggling of infected cattle into the\ncountry. Cattle traders have said cross-border smuggling from Iraq\nhave gone down considerably due to closer monitoring.\nAl-Shathry pointed out that his ministry had inoculated all animals in\nJizan, Tihama Asir, Qunfuda, Laith, Meghwat and Qalwa after the RVF\noutbreak in the southern region last September [2000.\nMosquitoes carry the virus from infected animals to humans. In humans\nthe incubation period is 2-6 days, so the virus replicates swiftly, in\nsome cases producing no symptoms, in others causing a mild illness\nassociated with fever and liver abnormalities.\n(By Mutlaq Al-Baqami, Arab News Staff)\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving confirmation & updates on the\nsituation - Mod.JW\n*****\n[2\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 09:18:43 +0100\nFrom: \"Arnon Shimshony\" <isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n\nRe: PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nThe remarks of Dr Shamsudeen are timely and important.\nThe sero-converted UN soldiers, stationed in Pelusium (North-Western\nSinai, East of Port-Said) [in 1979 were Swedish, not Swiss. It was\nnot clear\nwhere they had been exposed.\n--\nArnon Shimshony\nIsraeli Embassy\nUK\n<isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n.....................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Kingdom shares a 814-km-long border with its\nnortheastern neighbor.\nThe disease has killed 120 people out of a total of 863 infected cases\nin the Kingdom since September [2000. It also caused a large number\nof animal deaths in southwestern parts of the country.\nAbdul Aziz Saad Al-Shathry, undersecretary at the Agriculture\nMinistry, said the Kingdom had banned import of cattle from many\ncountries as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of RVF,\nfoot-and-mouth disease and Nile fever [sic. The measures helped to\nbring the disease under control.\nDr. Omar Hashim, acting director of animal and botanical quarantine at\nthe ministry, said the Kingdom had not received any official\nconfirmation from international organizations regarding the RVF\noutbreak in Iraq. However, he said quarantine agencies along the\nborder were closely monitoring the situation and with the support of\nborder guards would prevent smuggling of infected cattle into the\ncountry. Cattle traders have said cross-border smuggling from Iraq\nhave gone down considerably due to closer monitoring.\nAl-Shathry pointed out that his ministry had inoculated all animals in\nJizan, Tihama Asir, Qunfuda, Laith, Meghwat and Qalwa after the RVF\noutbreak in the southern region last September [2000.\nMosquitoes carry the virus from infected animals to humans. In humans\nthe incubation period is 2-6 days, so the virus replicates swiftly, in\nsome cases producing no symptoms, in others causing a mild illness\nassociated with fever and liver abnormalities.\n(By Mutlaq Al-Baqami, Arab News Staff)\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving confirmation & updates on the\nsituation - Mod.JW\n*****\n[2\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 09:18:43 +0100\nFrom: \"Arnon Shimshony\" <isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n\nRe: PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nThe remarks of Dr Shamsudeen are timely and important.\nThe sero-converted UN soldiers, stationed in Pelusium (North-Western\nSinai, East of Port-Said) [in 1979 were Swedish, not Swiss. The Kingdom shares a 814-km-long border with its\nnortheastern neighbor.\nThe disease has killed 120 people out of a total of 863 infected cases\nin the Kingdom since September [2000. It also caused a large number\nof animal deaths in southwestern parts of the country.\nAbdul Aziz Saad Al-Shathry, undersecretary at the Agriculture\nMinistry, said the Kingdom had banned import of cattle from many\ncountries as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of RVF,\nfoot-and-mouth disease and Nile fever [sic. The measures helped to\nbring the disease under control.\nDr. Omar Hashim, acting director of animal and botanical quarantine at\nthe ministry, said the Kingdom had not received any official\nconfirmation from international organizations regarding the RVF\noutbreak in Iraq. However, he said quarantine agencies along the\nborder were closely monitoring the situation and with the support of\nborder guards would prevent smuggling of infected cattle into the\ncountry. Cattle traders have said cross-border smuggling from Iraq\nhave gone down considerably due to closer monitoring.\nAl-Shathry pointed out that his ministry had inoculated all animals in\nJizan, Tihama Asir, Qunfuda, Laith, Meghwat and Qalwa after the RVF\noutbreak in the southern region last September [2000.\nMosquitoes carry the virus from infected animals to humans. In humans\nthe incubation period is 2-6 days, so the virus replicates swiftly, in\nsome cases producing no symptoms, in others causing a mild illness\nassociated with fever and liver abnormalities.\n(By Mutlaq Al-Baqami, Arab News Staff)\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving confirmation & updates on the\nsituation - Mod.JW\n*****\n[2\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 09:18:43 +0100\nFrom: \"Arnon Shimshony\" <isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n\nRe: PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nThe remarks of Dr Shamsudeen are timely and important.\nThe sero-converted UN soldiers, stationed in Pelusium (North-Western\nSinai, East of Port-Said) [in 1979 were Swedish, not Swiss. It was\nnot clear\nwhere they had been exposed.\n--\nArnon Shimshony\nIsraeli Embassy\nUK\n<isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n.....................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Kingdom shares a 814-km-long border with its\nnortheastern neighbor.\nThe disease has killed 120 people out of a total of 863 infected cases\nin the Kingdom since September [2000. It also caused a large number\nof animal deaths in southwestern parts of the country.\nAbdul Aziz Saad Al-Shathry, undersecretary at the Agriculture\nMinistry, said the Kingdom had banned import of cattle from many\ncountries as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of RVF,\nfoot-and-mouth disease and Nile fever [sic. The measures helped to\nbring the disease under control.\nDr. Omar Hashim, acting director of animal and botanical quarantine at\nthe ministry, said the Kingdom had not received any official\nconfirmation from international organizations regarding the RVF\noutbreak in Iraq. However, he said quarantine agencies along the\nborder were closely monitoring the situation and with the support of\nborder guards would prevent smuggling of infected cattle into the\ncountry. Cattle traders have said cross-border smuggling from Iraq\nhave gone down considerably due to closer monitoring.\nAl-Shathry pointed out that his ministry had inoculated all animals in\nJizan, Tihama Asir, Qunfuda, Laith, Meghwat and Qalwa after the RVF\noutbreak in the southern region last September [2000.\nMosquitoes carry the virus from infected animals to humans. In humans\nthe incubation period is 2-6 days, so the virus replicates swiftly, in\nsome cases producing no symptoms, in others causing a mild illness\nassociated with fever and liver abnormalities.\n(By Mutlaq Al-Baqami, Arab News Staff)\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving confirmation & updates on the\nsituation - Mod.JW\n*****\n[2\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 09:18:43 +0100\nFrom: \"Arnon Shimshony\" <isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n\nRe: PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nThe remarks of Dr Shamsudeen are timely and important.\nThe sero-converted UN soldiers, stationed in Pelusium (North-Western\nSinai, East of Port-Said) [in 1979 were Swedish, not Swiss. It was\nnot clear\nwhere they had been exposed.\n--\nArnon Shimshony\nIsraeli Embassy\nUK\n<isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n.....................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It also caused a large number\nof animal deaths in southwestern parts of the country.\nAbdul Aziz Saad Al-Shathry, undersecretary at the Agriculture\nMinistry, said the Kingdom had banned import of cattle from many\ncountries as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of RVF,\nfoot-and-mouth disease and Nile fever [sic. The measures helped to\nbring the disease under control.\nDr. Omar Hashim, acting director of animal and botanical quarantine at\nthe ministry, said the Kingdom had not received any official\nconfirmation from international organizations regarding the RVF\noutbreak in Iraq. However, he said quarantine agencies along the\nborder were closely monitoring the situation and with the support of\nborder guards would prevent smuggling of infected cattle into the\ncountry. Cattle traders have said cross-border smuggling from Iraq\nhave gone down considerably due to closer monitoring.\nAl-Shathry pointed out that his ministry had inoculated all animals in\nJizan, Tihama Asir, Qunfuda, Laith, Meghwat and Qalwa after the RVF\noutbreak in the southern region last September [2000.\nMosquitoes carry the virus from infected animals to humans. In humans\nthe incubation period is 2-6 days, so the virus replicates swiftly, in\nsome cases producing no symptoms, in others causing a mild illness\nassociated with fever and liver abnormalities.\n(By Mutlaq Al-Baqami, Arab News Staff)\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving confirmation & updates on the\nsituation - Mod.JW\n*****\n[2\nDate: Sat, 21 Jul 2001 09:18:43 +0100\nFrom: \"Arnon Shimshony\" <isr-agri@dircon.co.uk>\n\nRe: PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever - Iraq: at risk (02) 20010720.1410\nThe remarks of Dr Shamsudeen are timely and important.\nThe sero-converted UN soldiers, stationed in Pelusium (North-Western\nSinai, East of Port-Said) [in 1979 were Swedish, not Swiss. In a statement carried by the\nSPA news agency, the Ministry stated that \"119 people had died of Rift\nValley fever up to Sun 14 Jan 2001, and 857 people in all have contracted\nthe disease, of whom 730 have left hospital after treatment.\"\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@zajil.net>\n[This outbreak appears to be contained. There have been only 2 more cases\nand one death reported since Thu 11 Jan 2001, and the number of patients\ndischarged from hospital is unchanged. Unless there is a dramatic change\nin the situation, future updates will be reduced in frequency. - Mod.CP\n....................cp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In a statement carried by the\nSPA news agency, the Ministry stated that \"119 people had died of Rift\nValley fever up to Sun 14 Jan 2001, and 857 people in all have contracted\nthe disease, of whom 730 have left hospital after treatment.\"\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@zajil.net>\n[This outbreak appears to be contained. Yemen (02) 20000925.1653\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (03) 20001004.1710, 20001005.1714\nDate: 8 Oct 2000 09:23:06 +0300\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@zajil.net>\nSource: Arab News, Sun 8 Oct 2000 [edited\n\nSaudi Arabian Outbreak Update: Suspected Cases in Jordan\n--------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to this morning's report,the Health Ministry announced that the\ndeath toll [in the current Rift Valley fever outbreak in Saudi Arabia has\nrisen to 62, with 4 more people dying in Jizan yesterday [7 Oct 2000. New\ncases [numbered 18, with 16 in Jizan and 2 in Asir. Of the total number of\n282 [officially reported cases of Rift Valley fever, 101 have recovered\nand been discharged from hospital.\nIt has also been reported in an Arabic Daily [Al-Iqtisadiah, Wed 4 Oct\n2000 that there has been a report in nearby Jordan of 6 suspected cases of\ninfection with either West Nile Virus or Rift Valley fever virus. A senior\nJordanian health official, Dr Sa'ad Kharabishah, was quoted as saying that\n3 samples had been sent to the US for examination, and a report was\nexpected in 2 days time.\nDr Sa'ad Kharabishah also stated that there had been a report of West Nile\nvirus infection in a Palestinian citizen admitted into a Jordanian\nhospital. The patient is reported to have been based in Israel where he\nworks. His situation was said to be improving and he may be discharged in 2\ndays. However, there has been no confirmation of this report in local\nEnglish and Arabic language daily newspapers.\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@zajil.net>\n[The official statements continue to understate the extent of the outbreak.\nThere has been no previous suggestion that Rift Valley fever has spread\naway from the border region between Saudi Arabia and Yemen. The probability\nis that the cases reported in Jordan are West Nile virus related because of\nthe proximity to Israel. -Mod.CP\n.....................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Yemen (02) 20000925.1653\nRift Valley fever - Yemen (03) 20001004.1710, 20001005.1714\nDate: 8 Oct 2000 09:23:06 +0300\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@zajil.net>\nSource: Arab News, Sun 8 Oct 2000 [edited\n\nSaudi Arabian Outbreak Update: Suspected Cases in Jordan\n--------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to this morning's report,the Health Ministry announced that the\ndeath toll [in the current Rift Valley fever outbreak in Saudi Arabia has\nrisen to 62, with 4 more people dying in Jizan yesterday [7 Oct 2000. New\ncases [numbered 18, with 16 in Jizan and 2 in Asir. Of the total number of\n282 [officially reported cases of Rift Valley fever, 101 have recovered\nand been discharged from hospital.\nIt has also been reported in an Arabic Daily [Al-Iqtisadiah, Wed 4 Oct\n2000 that there has been a report in nearby Jordan of 6 suspected cases of\ninfection with either West Nile Virus or Rift Valley fever virus. A senior\nJordanian health official, Dr Sa'ad Kharabishah, was quoted as saying that\n3 samples had been sent to the US for examination, and a report was\nexpected in 2 days time.\nDr Sa'ad Kharabishah also stated that there had been a report of West Nile\nvirus infection in a Palestinian citizen admitted into a Jordanian\nhospital. The patient is reported to have been based in Israel where he\nworks. His situation was said to be improving and he may be discharged in 2\ndays. However, there has been no confirmation of this report in local\nEnglish and Arabic language daily newspapers.\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@zajil.net>\n[The official statements continue to understate the extent of the outbreak.\nThere has been no previous suggestion that Rift Valley fever has spread\naway from the border region between Saudi Arabia and Yemen. The probability\nis that the cases reported in Jordan are West Nile virus related because of\nthe proximity to Israel. -Mod.CP\n.....................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Times of India, filed AFP, 26 Sep 2000 [edited\n\n[1\nSaudi closes borders with Yemen on Rift Valley fever fears\n----------------------------------------------------------\nRIYADH: Saudi Arabia has closed its borders with Yemen to prevent the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, which has left dozens dead and hundreds ill in\nboth countries, a Saudi official said on Mon 25 Sep 2000. Yemen's ambassador\nto Riyadh said he could not confirm the closure.\nThe Saudi health ministry said that 27 people in Saudi Arabia have died of\nthe fever out of a total of 129 who have been stricken with the disease. The\nJizan region was the worst affected with 105 people [affected, the ministry\nsaid. On Sun 24 Sep 200 King Fahd ordered the destruction of all livestock\ncarrying, or suspected of carrying, the deadly fever. The fever was first\nreported on 11 Sep 2000 in the south of the Kingdom near the border with\nYemen, where 30 people have since died of the disease in the Red Sea region\nof Hodeida, 225 kilometres (140 miles) west of Sana'a.\nThe Saudi and Yemeni authorities, meanwhile, are boosting cooperation in\ntheir attempts to eradicate the fever. Twenty Saudi planes sprayed\ninsecticide in the infected zones on both sides of the Saudi-Yemeni border,\nwhile the 2 countries have met to establish joint technical committees.\nInternational assistance has also been forthcoming: South African experts\narrived in Saudi Arabia on Sun 24 Sep 2000, while Yemen said teams from the\nGeneva-based World Health Organisation (WHO) and the US-based Centers for\nDisease Control (CDC) arrived Mon 25 Sep 2000 in Sana'a. The WHO and CDC\nteams aim to collect samples from the affected regions [and will analyse\nthem in CDC laboratories in Cairo and South Africa, the Yemeni news agency\nSABA said.\n******\n[2\nDate: Mon, 25 Sep 2000 10:33:48 -0500\nFrom: H. Larry Penning, MD <bevpenn@fgi.net>\nSource: Yemen Times, Issue 39, Mon 25 Sep 2000 [edited\n\nRift Valley Fever Victim Toll in the Yemen Soars\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe number of the Rift Valley fever victims in Hodeidah has shot up\nfrighteningly during the past week. 95 people have died in the Governorate\nof Hodeidah and the Yemeni-Saudi border areas, especially Harradh\". Sources\nfrom the Governorate of Hodeidah have said that the number of deaths in the\nMoor Valley had approached 60, whereas other places like \"Ubad\", \"Kudmah\",\n\"Zuhair\",\"Mahal Manih\", \"Budilah\", and \" Al Marawidh\" have become completely\ninfected. Other neighboring areas are [now becoming involved in the outbreak.\nThe sources added that hundreds of cattle had [died especially in the\n\"Zuhra\" region, which was extensively affected by the disease. Starting\nfrom today, Mon 25 Sep 2000, it is expected that Saudi airplanes will spray\nchemicals to [control spread the disease in the border region. Meanwhile 50\nground teams, accompanied by Dr. Abdu Alwali Nasher, the minister of health,\nand Mr. Ahmed Salem Al Jabali, minister of Agriculture, [are operating in\nthe same area. Attempts to control the spread of the disease are being\nhampered by high winds which disperse that thousands of mosquitoes that are\nswarming in the region due to humidity and rain.\nOfficial statements until last night [claimed that 24 deaths had occurred,\nwhereas [local sources said hat there had been more than 95 cases [deaths\n?. Until now, a regional belt around the [affected areas has not been\n[established. Some of the citizens of the unaffected areas in \"Zuhra\" and\nothers have complained that they had no [longer any source of income after\nthe death of about two thirds of their cattle. The disease had started\nspreading in districts near Hodeidah. Al-Zuhrah district has been reported\nto be an infected area. The disease had appeared in southern areas of Saudi\nArabia, then moved to Harad, Abss and to Al-Zuhrah.\nA Yemeni medical team, headed by the health director in Hodeidah, and\nanother medical/veterinary team ave been rushed to the area to work [on\ndisease control. About 40 cars sprayed insecticide in areas where\nmosquitoes are found. Official sources say that the disease has claimed the\nlives of 23 persons while other local sources indicate that the number is\nmore than 95. They indicated that most of them had died and were buried\nbefore medical teams arrived in these districts.\nThe Wadi Moor villages are home to more than 150 000 people, all of whom are\nworking in pasturing and sheep trading with neighboring countries. New\nmilitary check-points have been set up in Al-Zuhrah district and neighboring\nvillages to prevent the spread of meat or milk to Hodeidah or neighboring\nmarkets. [The arrival of modern spraying equipment from Saudi Arabia is\nexpected soon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is understandable confusion about the numbers of fatalities and the\nexact extent of the outbreak. - Mod.CP\n..............................cp/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other neighboring areas are [now becoming involved in the outbreak.\nThe sources added that hundreds of cattle had [died especially in the\n\"Zuhra\" region, which was extensively affected by the disease. Starting\nfrom today, Mon 25 Sep 2000, it is expected that Saudi airplanes will spray\nchemicals to [control spread the disease in the border region. Meanwhile 50\nground teams, accompanied by Dr. Abdu Alwali Nasher, the minister of health,\nand Mr. Ahmed Salem Al Jabali, minister of Agriculture, [are operating in\nthe same area. Attempts to control the spread of the disease are being\nhampered by high winds which disperse that thousands of mosquitoes that are\nswarming in the region due to humidity and rain.\nOfficial statements until last night [claimed that 24 deaths had occurred,\nwhereas [local sources said hat there had been more than 95 cases [deaths\n?. Until now, a regional belt around the [affected areas has not been\n[established. Some of the citizens of the unaffected areas in \"Zuhra\" and\nothers have complained that they had no [longer any source of income after\nthe death of about two thirds of their cattle. The disease had started\nspreading in districts near Hodeidah. Al-Zuhrah district has been reported\nto be an infected area. The disease had appeared in southern areas of Saudi\nArabia, then moved to Harad, Abss and to Al-Zuhrah.\nA Yemeni medical team, headed by the health director in Hodeidah, and\nanother medical/veterinary team ave been rushed to the area to work [on\ndisease control. About 40 cars sprayed insecticide in areas where\nmosquitoes are found. Official sources say that the disease has claimed the\nlives of 23 persons while other local sources indicate that the number is\nmore than 95. They indicated that most of them had died and were buried\nbefore medical teams arrived in these districts.\nThe Wadi Moor villages are home to more than 150 000 people, all of whom are\nworking in pasturing and sheep trading with neighboring countries. New\nmilitary check-points have been set up in Al-Zuhrah district and neighboring\nvillages to prevent the spread of meat or milk to Hodeidah or neighboring\nmarkets. [The arrival of modern spraying equipment from Saudi Arabia is\nexpected soon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is understandable confusion about the numbers of fatalities and the\nexact extent of the outbreak. - Mod.CP\n..............................cp/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Times of India, filed AFP, 26 Sep 2000 [edited\n\n[1\nSaudi closes borders with Yemen on Rift Valley fever fears\n----------------------------------------------------------\nRIYADH: Saudi Arabia has closed its borders with Yemen to prevent the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, which has left dozens dead and hundreds ill in\nboth countries, a Saudi official said on Mon 25 Sep 2000. Yemen's ambassador\nto Riyadh said he could not confirm the closure.\nThe Saudi health ministry said that 27 people in Saudi Arabia have died of\nthe fever out of a total of 129 who have been stricken with the disease. The\nJizan region was the worst affected with 105 people [affected, the ministry\nsaid. On Sun 24 Sep 200 King Fahd ordered the destruction of all livestock\ncarrying, or suspected of carrying, the deadly fever. The fever was first\nreported on 11 Sep 2000 in the south of the Kingdom near the border with\nYemen, where 30 people have since died of the disease in the Red Sea region\nof Hodeida, 225 kilometres (140 miles) west of Sana'a.\nThe Saudi and Yemeni authorities, meanwhile, are boosting cooperation in\ntheir attempts to eradicate the fever. Twenty Saudi planes sprayed\ninsecticide in the infected zones on both sides of the Saudi-Yemeni border,\nwhile the 2 countries have met to establish joint technical committees.\nInternational assistance has also been forthcoming: South African experts\narrived in Saudi Arabia on Sun 24 Sep 2000, while Yemen said teams from the\nGeneva-based World Health Organisation (WHO) and the US-based Centers for\nDisease Control (CDC) arrived Mon 25 Sep 2000 in Sana'a. The WHO and CDC\nteams aim to collect samples from the affected regions [and will analyse\nthem in CDC laboratories in Cairo and South Africa, the Yemeni news agency\nSABA said.\n******\n[2\nDate: Mon, 25 Sep 2000 10:33:48 -0500\nFrom: H. Larry Penning, MD <bevpenn@fgi.net>\nSource: Yemen Times, Issue 39, Mon 25 Sep 2000 [edited\n\nRift Valley Fever Victim Toll in the Yemen Soars\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe number of the Rift Valley fever victims in Hodeidah has shot up\nfrighteningly during the past week. 95 people have died in the Governorate\nof Hodeidah and the Yemeni-Saudi border areas, especially Harradh\". Sources\nfrom the Governorate of Hodeidah have said that the number of deaths in the\nMoor Valley had approached 60, whereas other places like \"Ubad\", \"Kudmah\",\n\"Zuhair\",\"Mahal Manih\", \"Budilah\", and \" Al Marawidh\" have become completely\ninfected. Other neighboring areas are [now becoming involved in the outbreak.\nThe sources added that hundreds of cattle had [died especially in the\n\"Zuhra\" region, which was extensively affected by the disease. Starting\nfrom today, Mon 25 Sep 2000, it is expected that Saudi airplanes will spray\nchemicals to [control spread the disease in the border region. Meanwhile 50\nground teams, accompanied by Dr. Abdu Alwali Nasher, the minister of health,\nand Mr. Ahmed Salem Al Jabali, minister of Agriculture, [are operating in\nthe same area. Attempts to control the spread of the disease are being\nhampered by high winds which disperse that thousands of mosquitoes that are\nswarming in the region due to humidity and rain.\nOfficial statements until last night [claimed that 24 deaths had occurred,\nwhereas [local sources said hat there had been more than 95 cases [deaths\n?. Until now, a regional belt around the [affected areas has not been\n[established. Some of the citizens of the unaffected areas in \"Zuhra\" and\nothers have complained that they had no [longer any source of income after\nthe death of about two thirds of their cattle. The disease had started\nspreading in districts near Hodeidah. Al-Zuhrah district has been reported\nto be an infected area. The disease had appeared in southern areas of Saudi\nArabia, then moved to Harad, Abss and to Al-Zuhrah.\nA Yemeni medical team, headed by the health director in Hodeidah, and\nanother medical/veterinary team ave been rushed to the area to work [on\ndisease control. About 40 cars sprayed insecticide in areas where\nmosquitoes are found. Official sources say that the disease has claimed the\nlives of 23 persons while other local sources indicate that the number is\nmore than 95. They indicated that most of them had died and were buried\nbefore medical teams arrived in these districts.\nThe Wadi Moor villages are home to more than 150 000 people, all of whom are\nworking in pasturing and sheep trading with neighboring countries. New\nmilitary check-points have been set up in Al-Zuhrah district and neighboring\nvillages to prevent the spread of meat or milk to Hodeidah or neighboring\nmarkets. [The arrival of modern spraying equipment from Saudi Arabia is\nexpected soon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is understandable confusion about the numbers of fatalities and the\nexact extent of the outbreak. - Mod.CP\n..............................cp/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Larry Penning, MD <bevpenn@fgi.net>\nSource: Yemen Times, Issue 39, Mon 25 Sep 2000 [edited\n\nRift Valley Fever Victim Toll in the Yemen Soars\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe number of the Rift Valley fever victims in Hodeidah has shot up\nfrighteningly during the past week. 95 people have died in the Governorate\nof Hodeidah and the Yemeni-Saudi border areas, especially Harradh\". Sources\nfrom the Governorate of Hodeidah have said that the number of deaths in the\nMoor Valley had approached 60, whereas other places like \"Ubad\", \"Kudmah\",\n\"Zuhair\",\"Mahal Manih\", \"Budilah\", and \" Al Marawidh\" have become completely\ninfected. Other neighboring areas are [now becoming involved in the outbreak.\nThe sources added that hundreds of cattle had [died especially in the\n\"Zuhra\" region, which was extensively affected by the disease. Starting\nfrom today, Mon 25 Sep 2000, it is expected that Saudi airplanes will spray\nchemicals to [control spread the disease in the border region. Meanwhile 50\nground teams, accompanied by Dr. Abdu Alwali Nasher, the minister of health,\nand Mr. Ahmed Salem Al Jabali, minister of Agriculture, [are operating in\nthe same area. Attempts to control the spread of the disease are being\nhampered by high winds which disperse that thousands of mosquitoes that are\nswarming in the region due to humidity and rain.\nOfficial statements until last night [claimed that 24 deaths had occurred,\nwhereas [local sources said hat there had been more than 95 cases [deaths\n?. Until now, a regional belt around the [affected areas has not been\n[established. Some of the citizens of the unaffected areas in \"Zuhra\" and\nothers have complained that they had no [longer any source of income after\nthe death of about two thirds of their cattle. The disease had started\nspreading in districts near Hodeidah. Al-Zuhrah district has been reported\nto be an infected area. The disease had appeared in southern areas of Saudi\nArabia, then moved to Harad, Abss and to Al-Zuhrah.\nA Yemeni medical team, headed by the health director in Hodeidah, and\nanother medical/veterinary team ave been rushed to the area to work [on\ndisease control. About 40 cars sprayed insecticide in areas where\nmosquitoes are found. Official sources say that the disease has claimed the\nlives of 23 persons while other local sources indicate that the number is\nmore than 95. They indicated that most of them had died and were buried\nbefore medical teams arrived in these districts.\nThe Wadi Moor villages are home to more than 150 000 people, all of whom are\nworking in pasturing and sheep trading with neighboring countries. New\nmilitary check-points have been set up in Al-Zuhrah district and neighboring\nvillages to prevent the spread of meat or milk to Hodeidah or neighboring\nmarkets. [The arrival of modern spraying equipment from Saudi Arabia is\nexpected soon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is understandable confusion about the numbers of fatalities and the\nexact extent of the outbreak. - Mod.CP\n..............................cp/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Times of India, filed AFP, 26 Sep 2000 [edited\n\n[1\nSaudi closes borders with Yemen on Rift Valley fever fears\n----------------------------------------------------------\nRIYADH: Saudi Arabia has closed its borders with Yemen to prevent the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, which has left dozens dead and hundreds ill in\nboth countries, a Saudi official said on Mon 25 Sep 2000. Yemen's ambassador\nto Riyadh said he could not confirm the closure.\nThe Saudi health ministry said that 27 people in Saudi Arabia have died of\nthe fever out of a total of 129 who have been stricken with the disease. The\nJizan region was the worst affected with 105 people [affected, the ministry\nsaid. On Sun 24 Sep 200 King Fahd ordered the destruction of all livestock\ncarrying, or suspected of carrying, the deadly fever. The fever was first\nreported on 11 Sep 2000 in the south of the Kingdom near the border with\nYemen, where 30 people have since died of the disease in the Red Sea region\nof Hodeida, 225 kilometres (140 miles) west of Sana'a.\nThe Saudi and Yemeni authorities, meanwhile, are boosting cooperation in\ntheir attempts to eradicate the fever. Twenty Saudi planes sprayed\ninsecticide in the infected zones on both sides of the Saudi-Yemeni border,\nwhile the 2 countries have met to establish joint technical committees.\nInternational assistance has also been forthcoming: South African experts\narrived in Saudi Arabia on Sun 24 Sep 2000, while Yemen said teams from the\nGeneva-based World Health Organisation (WHO) and the US-based Centers for\nDisease Control (CDC) arrived Mon 25 Sep 2000 in Sana'a. The WHO and CDC\nteams aim to collect samples from the affected regions [and will analyse\nthem in CDC laboratories in Cairo and South Africa, the Yemeni news agency\nSABA said.\n******\n[2\nDate: Mon, 25 Sep 2000 10:33:48 -0500\nFrom: H. Larry Penning, MD <bevpenn@fgi.net>\nSource: Yemen Times, Issue 39, Mon 25 Sep 2000 [edited\n\nRift Valley Fever Victim Toll in the Yemen Soars\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe number of the Rift Valley fever victims in Hodeidah has shot up\nfrighteningly during the past week. 95 people have died in the Governorate\nof Hodeidah and the Yemeni-Saudi border areas, especially Harradh\". Sources\nfrom the Governorate of Hodeidah have said that the number of deaths in the\nMoor Valley had approached 60, whereas other places like \"Ubad\", \"Kudmah\",\n\"Zuhair\",\"Mahal Manih\", \"Budilah\", and \" Al Marawidh\" have become completely\ninfected. Other neighboring areas are [now becoming involved in the outbreak.\nThe sources added that hundreds of cattle had [died especially in the\n\"Zuhra\" region, which was extensively affected by the disease. Starting\nfrom today, Mon 25 Sep 2000, it is expected that Saudi airplanes will spray\nchemicals to [control spread the disease in the border region. Meanwhile 50\nground teams, accompanied by Dr. Abdu Alwali Nasher, the minister of health,\nand Mr. Ahmed Salem Al Jabali, minister of Agriculture, [are operating in\nthe same area. Attempts to control the spread of the disease are being\nhampered by high winds which disperse that thousands of mosquitoes that are\nswarming in the region due to humidity and rain.\nOfficial statements until last night [claimed that 24 deaths had occurred,\nwhereas [local sources said hat there had been more than 95 cases [deaths\n?. Until now, a regional belt around the [affected areas has not been\n[established. Some of the citizens of the unaffected areas in \"Zuhra\" and\nothers have complained that they had no [longer any source of income after\nthe death of about two thirds of their cattle. The disease had started\nspreading in districts near Hodeidah. Al-Zuhrah district has been reported\nto be an infected area. The disease had appeared in southern areas of Saudi\nArabia, then moved to Harad, Abss and to Al-Zuhrah.\nA Yemeni medical team, headed by the health director in Hodeidah, and\nanother medical/veterinary team ave been rushed to the area to work [on\ndisease control. About 40 cars sprayed insecticide in areas where\nmosquitoes are found. Official sources say that the disease has claimed the\nlives of 23 persons while other local sources indicate that the number is\nmore than 95. They indicated that most of them had died and were buried\nbefore medical teams arrived in these districts.\nThe Wadi Moor villages are home to more than 150 000 people, all of whom are\nworking in pasturing and sheep trading with neighboring countries. New\nmilitary check-points have been set up in Al-Zuhrah district and neighboring\nvillages to prevent the spread of meat or milk to Hodeidah or neighboring\nmarkets. [The arrival of modern spraying equipment from Saudi Arabia is\nexpected soon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is understandable confusion about the numbers of fatalities and the\nexact extent of the outbreak. - Mod.CP\n..............................cp/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. On that basis, I ventured to predict that an\noutbreak of RVF would occur. Within days we had reports of buffalo\nabortions in the Kruger National Park and a waterbuck died in an adjoining\npark. On the basis of virus isolations, PCR results and sequencing,\nhistology and immunohistochemistry, and antibody findings, we were able to\nshow that both were due to RVF; a giraffe death could not be to proved to\nbe due to RVF.\nBecause of a severe heat wave and lack of rain since then, the situation\npromptly changed. Predicted bumper crops are now teetering on the brink of\nfailure.\n\nRVF has evaporated.\n--\nProf R Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Virology\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham 2131\nRSA\nTEL: +27 11 321 4200\nFAX: +27 11 882 0596\ne-mail: bobs@niv.ac.za\n[We are indebted to Bob Swanepoel for bringing this brief story to a close.\nStill, although RVF has disappeared from the area, RVF virus surely has\nnot. This is as fascinating an infectious disease story as occurs\nanywhere. Unless and until we get a grasp of virus dynamics in\ninterepidemic/interepizootic periods, as CDC appears to be doing with\nhantaviruses in the United States, we will not be able to predict outbreaks\nwith certainty. Dr. Swanepoel's willingness to go out on a limb in this\nsituation took courage. - Mod.CHC]\n......................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. On that basis, I ventured to predict that an\noutbreak of RVF would occur. Within days we had reports of buffalo\nabortions in the Kruger National Park and a waterbuck died in an adjoining\npark. Predicted bumper crops are now teetering on the brink of\nfailure.\n\nRVF has evaporated.\n--\nProf R Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Virology\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham 2131\nRSA\nTEL: +27 11 321 4200\nFAX: +27 11 882 0596\ne-mail: bobs@niv.ac.za\n[We are indebted to Bob Swanepoel for bringing this brief story to a close.\nStill, although RVF has disappeared from the area, RVF virus surely has\nnot. This is as fascinating an infectious disease story as occurs\nanywhere. Unless and until we get a grasp of virus dynamics in\ninterepidemic/interepizootic periods, as CDC appears to be doing with\nhantaviruses in the United States, we will not be able to predict outbreaks\nwith certainty. Dr. Swanepoel's willingness to go out on a limb in this\nsituation took courage. - Mod.CHC]\n......................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. On that basis, I ventured to predict that an\noutbreak of RVF would occur. Within days we had reports of buffalo\nabortions in the Kruger National Park and a waterbuck died in an adjoining\npark. On the basis of virus isolations, PCR results and sequencing,\nhistology and immunohistochemistry, and antibody findings, we were able to\nshow that both were due to RVF; a giraffe death could not be to proved to\nbe due to RVF.\nBecause of a severe heat wave and lack of rain since then, the situation\npromptly changed. Predicted bumper crops are now teetering on the brink of\nfailure.\n\nRVF has evaporated.\n--\nProf R Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Virology\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham 2131\nRSA\nTEL: +27 11 321 4200\nFAX: +27 11 882 0596\ne-mail: bobs@niv.ac.za\n[We are indebted to Bob Swanepoel for bringing this brief story to a close.\nStill, although RVF has disappeared from the area, RVF virus surely has\nnot. This is as fascinating an infectious disease story as occurs\nanywhere. Unless and until we get a grasp of virus dynamics in\ninterepidemic/interepizootic periods, as CDC appears to be doing with\nhantaviruses in the United States, we will not be able to predict outbreaks\nwith certainty. Dr. Swanepoel's willingness to go out on a limb in this\nsituation took courage. - Mod.CHC]\n......................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. On that basis, I ventured to predict that an\noutbreak of RVF would occur. Within days we had reports of buffalo\nabortions in the Kruger National Park and a waterbuck died in an adjoining\npark. On the basis of virus isolations, PCR results and sequencing,\nhistology and immunohistochemistry, and antibody findings, we were able to\nshow that both were due to RVF; a giraffe death could not be to proved to\nbe due to RVF.\nBecause of a severe heat wave and lack of rain since then, the situation\npromptly changed. Melewas, Director of\nVeterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives, Dar es Salaam:\nNature of diagnosis: clinical and laboratory.\nDate of initial detection of animal health incident: February 1998.\nEstimated date of first infection: February 1998.\nLocation No. of outbreaks\nseveral villages in Arusha and\nKilimanjaro regions (northern Tanzania) 15\n\nDescription of affected population: traditional (agro-pastoral) livestock\nsector of northern Tanzania - the Masai ecosystem. Three human cases were\nreported in two villages.\nTotal number of animals in the outbreaks:\nspecies ovine 30 cases\ncaprine 29 cases\ncamel 34 cases\nDiagnosis:\nA. Laboratory where diagnosis was made: National Institute for Virology\n(South Africa).\nB. Diagnostic tests used: haemagglutination inhibition and\nELISA(enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay).\nEpidemiology:\nA. Source of agent / origin of infection: carrier state in natural hosts and\nvectors.\nB. Mode of spread: vector (mosquito) transmission and direct contact in\nhumans.\nC. Other epidemiological details: effect of unusually heavy rains (El Nino)\ncausing massive build up of insect vectors.\nControl measures during reporting period: quarantine and movement control\ninside the country; testing; control of arthropods.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Those attending the Emerging Diseases Conference in Atlanta might want to\nask Bob Swanepoel about this investigation. - Mod.MHJ\n...........................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Diagnostic tests used: haemagglutination inhibition and\nELISA(enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay).\nEpidemiology:\nA. Source of agent / origin of infection: carrier state in natural hosts and\nvectors.\nB. Mode of spread: vector (mosquito) transmission and direct contact in\nhumans.\nC. Other epidemiological details: effect of unusually heavy rains (El Nino)\ncausing massive build up of insect vectors.\nControl measures during reporting period: quarantine and movement control\ninside the country; testing; control of arthropods.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Those attending the Emerging Diseases Conference in Atlanta might want to\nask Bob Swanepoel about this investigation. - Mod.MHJ\n...........................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Melewas, Director of\nVeterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives, Dar es Salaam:\nNature of diagnosis: clinical and laboratory.\nDate of initial detection of animal health incident: February 1998.\nEstimated date of first infection: February 1998.\nLocation No. of outbreaks\nseveral villages in Arusha and\nKilimanjaro regions (northern Tanzania) 15\n\nDescription of affected population: traditional (agro-pastoral) livestock\nsector of northern Tanzania - the Masai ecosystem. Three human cases were\nreported in two villages.\nTotal number of animals in the outbreaks:\nspecies ovine 30 cases\ncaprine 29 cases\ncamel 34 cases\nDiagnosis:\nA. Laboratory where diagnosis was made: National Institute for Virology\n(South Africa).\nB. Diagnostic tests used: haemagglutination inhibition and\nELISA(enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay).\nEpidemiology:\nA. Source of agent / origin of infection: carrier state in natural hosts and\nvectors.\nB. Mode of spread: vector (mosquito) transmission and direct contact in\nhumans.\nC. Other epidemiological details: effect of unusually heavy rains (El Nino)\ncausing massive build up of insect vectors.\nControl measures during reporting period: quarantine and movement control\ninside the country; testing; control of arthropods.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Those attending the Emerging Diseases Conference in Atlanta might want to\nask Bob Swanepoel about this investigation. - Mod.MHJ\n...........................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hargeisa\nis the entrepot for cattle from the interior of Ogaden and from southern\nSomalia as they are collected together before going down to the port of\nBerbera, 3 days walk away, for export to Saudi Arabia. Sheep, goats, and\ncamels are also exported through this port. If RVF has reached Hargeisa,\nthe risk to the Arabian Peninsula is clear.\nThe reported spread of the disease through other Kenyan provinces raises\nthe potential for spread to Tanzania.\nIf any of our readers has information on the developing situation, we would\nbe grateful to have it. Please be sure to give us sources and dates.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hargeisa\nis the entrepot for cattle from the interior of Ogaden and from southern\nSomalia as they are collected together before going down to the port of\nBerbera, 3 days walk away, for export to Saudi Arabia. Sheep, goats, and\ncamels are also exported through this port. If RVF has reached Hargeisa,\nthe risk to the Arabian Peninsula is clear.\nThe reported spread of the disease through other Kenyan provinces raises\nthe potential for spread to Tanzania.\nIf any of our readers has information on the developing situation, we would\nbe grateful to have it. Please be sure to give us sources and dates.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hargeisa\nis the entrepot for cattle from the interior of Ogaden and from southern\nSomalia as they are collected together before going down to the port of\nBerbera, 3 days walk away, for export to Saudi Arabia. Sheep, goats, and\ncamels are also exported through this port. If RVF has reached Hargeisa,\nthe risk to the Arabian Peninsula is clear.\nThe reported spread of the disease through other Kenyan provinces raises\nthe potential for spread to Tanzania.\nIf any of our readers has information on the developing situation, we would\nbe grateful to have it. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-01-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192520", "headline": "PRO> Rift Valley fever, abortigen in humans: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192520", "date": "1998-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, ABORTIGEN IN HUMANS: REQUEST FOR INFO\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Fri, 9 Jan 1998 09:35:09 MET\nFrom: G. A. Balint <BALINT@nepsy.szote.u-szeged.hu>\n\nIt is well known that Rift Valley fever virus often causes abortion in\nanimals. Any data regarding this pathological property of the virus in\nhumans?\n--\nG. A. Balint, MD,DSc\nAlbert Szent-Gyorgyi Medical University\nSzeged, Hungary\ne-mail: BALINT@nepsy.szote.u-szeged.hu\n[Within 2-6 days of RVF virus infecting a flock of sheep 90%-100% of lambs\n<7 d old die, 20%-60% of older lambs and adult sheep die, and 90%-100% of\npregnant sheep abort. The respective figures for cattle are: 10%-70% of\ncalves die, 10%-20% of adult cattle die, 80%-100% of pregnant cows abort.\nData for goats, buffaloes and camels are limited.\nA study of abortions in humans infected with RVF virus during the 1977 RVF\nepizoodemic in Egypt was not conclusive. (Abdel-Aziz AA, Meegan JM, and\nLaughlin LW (1980) Rift Valley fever as a possible cause of human\nabortions. Trans. Roy. Soc. Trop. Med. Hyg. 74:685). I know of no other\ndata regarding abortions in humans. - Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
